questions.text: In a menstrual cycle, the primary oocyte undergoes meiotic division to produce 2 unequal daughter cells under the influence of the mid-cycle LH surge. What is the cause of LH surge? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol

 

Sustained peak level of estrogen for 24–48 hours in the late follicular phase results in LH surge from the anterior pituitary (positive feedback effect). Effective LH surge persists for about 24 hours.

 

The growing follicles produce Estradiol which results in positive Feedback causing the Midcycle LH surge

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FSH: At the beginning of the follicular phase, the FSH levels produced by the anterior pituitary begin to rise. The FSH threshold is the level of FSH needed for follicular recruitment to take place and FSH Window is the duration of time the FSH remains above threshold

 

Option C. LH: The LH surge is responsible for ovulation which is accompanied by the expulsion of the first polar body.

 

Option D. Progesterone: following ovulation there is luteinizations of the follicle which results in increased production of progesterone

 

*Kindly note that the second polar body is extruded at the time of fertilization of the ovum by the sperm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sustained peak level of estrogen for 24–48 hours in the late follicular phase results in LH surge from the anterior pituitary

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynaecology page 68

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought by his son because he was not using his left arm for day-to-day functioning. He has an unkempt appearance on the left side of his body and has a history of bumping into door frames while walking through them. The evaluation performed is shown below. Where does the lesion in the brain cause this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right parietal

 

The patient’s symptoms suggest left-sided hemineglect, characterized by a lack of awareness of the left side of the body and environment. This is typically caused by a lesion in the non-dominant parietal lobe, which, for most people, is the right parietal lobe. The clock drawing test, where the patient clusters numbers on one side, further supports this diagnosis of hemineglect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right parietotemporal: This could affect spatial awareness but is more specific to complex visual and spatial processing issues.

 

Option B. Left parietal: Lesions here would affect the right side of the body and typically do not cause hemineglect.

 

Option D. Right premotor cortex: Would affect motor planning but not typically cause hemineglect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided hemineglect is typically caused by a lesion in the right parietal lobe.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation at which heart rate you will start chest compression? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heart rate less than 60

 

During neonatal resuscitation chest compression start at heart rate less than 60.

 

  • Heart rate less than 100/min - PPV with bag and mask on room air, SPO2 monitoring
  • Heart rate is below 60 - chest compressions (3:1)
  • Heart rate still remains less than 60 - IV epinephrine.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions should be initiated if the heart rate falls below 60 beats per minute despite adequate positive pressure ventilation.

 

Neonatal Resuscitation algorithm-2015 update

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a 10-year history of coarse facial features and progressive enlargement of the hands and feet. Laboratory evaluation revealed elevated IGF-1 and non-suppressible growth hormone levels after the 75 g glucose challenge test. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management of this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lanreotide depot formulation

 

Acromegaly is a condition caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. The clinical features include coarse facial features and enlargement of the hands and feet. The diagnosis is confirmed with elevated IGF-1 levels and non-suppressible growth hormone levels following a glucose challenge test.

 

The first-line treatment for a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma is transsphenoidal surgery. However, when surgery is not immediately possible or has failed, medical management is necessary.

 

The preferred drugs in these situations are somatostatin receptor agonists, such as lanreotide, octreotide, and pasireotide. Lanreotide depot formulation is effective in reducing growth hormone levels and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Terlipressin: Incorrect. Terlipressin is primarily used in the management of acute variceal bleeding related to liver conditions, not in the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Incorrect. Ketoconazole is used in managing Cushing's syndrome in children due to its ability to inhibit cortisol synthesis. It is not indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option D. Leuprolide: Incorrect. Leuprolide is a GnRH analogue used in the management of gynecological conditions such as fibroids and in prostate cancer. It is not effective in treating acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred medical management for acromegaly, especially as a bridge to surgery or when surgery has failed, is the use of somatostatin receptor agonists like lanreotide depot formulation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the OPD with a painless, very slowly growing mass of the right third finger. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enchondroma

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.

 

 

  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment is by extended curettage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Option D. Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone. It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule. X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur. Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation. An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity. Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally. Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighbouring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc. Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enchondromas as painless, very slowly growing masses that commonly affect the short bones of the hand.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman has an endometrial thickness of 14 mm with an adnexal mass. A previous report of endometrial biopsy shows complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metastasis endometrial carcinoma to ovary

 

  • According to the given clinical scenario, patient most likely has Endometrial Carcinoma with metastasis to ovaries.
  • Transvaginal scan (TVS) is done in women with post-menopausal bleeding. Normal Endometrial thickness in postmenopausal women is ≤ 4mm. Endometrial biopsy is indicated in women with post menstrual bleeding with endometrial thickness > 5mm.
  • The risk of progress to endometrial carcinoma in a patient with complex hyperplasia with atypia is 29%
  • The most likely diagnosis would thus be endometrial cancer and with an adnexal mass would be an ovarian metastases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian disease: Diagnosis is based on the presence of 2 out of the following 3 criteria 1) Oligo and/or anovulation 2) Hyperandrogenism 3) Polycystic Ovaries on ultrasound.

 

Option C. Struma Ovarii: It is a rare type of ovarian teratoma containing thyroid tissue. Another type of monodermal teratoma is the strumal carcinoid secreting serotonin

 

Option D. Immature ovarian teratoma: This is a rare usually malignant germ cell tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial thickness > 5 mm in postmenopausal women with bleeding should prompt an endometrial biopsy, especially if complex hyperplasia with atypia is suspected due to the high risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Dutta Textbook of Gynaecology page 329, 460, 294

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker, male presented with painless hematuria. On further investigation he is diagnosed with bladder cancer extending upto the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice in this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cystectomy

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for a patient with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer.

 

Radical Cystectomy (Option C):

 

  • This is a surgery to remove the entire bladder and possibly nearby tissues and organs. For men, this often includes the prostate and seminal vesicles. For women, the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and part of the vagina might be removed.
  • It is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer, meaning the tumor has grown into the muscular wall of the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravesical BCG followed by chemotherapy:

 

  • BCG is a type of immunotherapy where Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (a bacterium similar to the one that causes tuberculosis) is introduced directly into the bladder. This stimulates an immune response against cancer cells.
  • This treatment is typically reserved for non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer or carcinoma in situ (CIS).

 

Option B. Systemic Chemotherapy:

 

  • This might be used before surgery to shrink the tumor or after surgery to kill any remaining cancer cells.
  • Systemic chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer but can be used in conjunction with surgery or other treatments.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy:

 

  • This uses high-energy radiation to kill cancer cells. It might be used as a primary treatment for those who aren't candidates for surgery or combined with chemotherapy as an alternative to surgery.
  • However, the gold standard treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer remains radical cystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer

questions.text: A 7-year-old male was brought to OPD by his mother with reduced hearing since 2 months. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane was observed as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myringitis Bullosa

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous otitis media: (glue ear) cases present with hearing loss and mild ear ache. Otoscopy reveals fluid level and air bubbles.

 

 

Option B. Acute otitis media: Patients present with ear ache, fever, ear discharge. Following image shows red and bulging TM.

 

 

Option D. Myringitis Granulosa: Patient usually presents with painless otorrhea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis Bullosa should be considered when a patient presents with the acute onset of ear pain accompanied by visible blisters on the tympanic membrane, particularly in the context of a recent upper respiratory infection or influenza-like illness. Management focuses on pain relief and monitoring for resolution, with antibiotics or antivirals tailored to the underlying cause if identified.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3. Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid regurgitation

 

The patient's presentation of bilateral pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, ascites, and an S3 heart sound is indicative of right heart failure. Tricuspid regurgitation leads to right heart failure because it causes blood to back up into the right atrium and subsequently into the systemic venous circulation, resulting in the observed symptoms. Chronic smoking may contribute to pulmonary hypertension, which can exacerbate right heart failure and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Typically causes left heart failure with symptoms like dyspnea and pulmonary congestion, not right heart failure.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis: Leads to left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure, primarily affecting the left side of the heart.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: Primarily affects the left side of the heart and results in pulmonary symptoms and left heart failure rather than right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tricuspid regurgitation is a common cause of right heart failure, presenting with symptoms such as pedal edema, abdominal distension, and ascites.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is a diagnosed case of depression. He is concerned about side effects of his medication and requests you to prescribe a drug least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bupropion

 

Among the given option, Bupropion has the least sexual side effects.

 

Bupropion

 

  • Atypical Antidepressant, NDRI (Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Side effects – insomnia, restlessness, seizures
  • Minimal risk of sexual side effects, weight gain or sedation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escitalopram and Option D. Fluoxetine are SSRIs and they have long-term side effects including low libido, delayed orgasm, and poor erection.

 

Option B. Venlafaxine is a SNRI. It has side effects similar to SSRI and in addition, can cause anticholinergic side effects and hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bupropion, an NDRI, is the antidepressant of choice for patients who experience or wish to avoid sexual side effects associated with serotonergic agents. It should not be used in patients with seizure disorders or eating disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with chronic heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide


Loop diuretics like furosemide do not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure.

 

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

 

  • Beta blockers
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists like spironolactone and epleronone
  • Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) like valsartan plus sacubitril
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors like empagliflozin

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing at home. Suddenly his mother found him lying on the floor choking. She suspects he has ingested a foreign body and rushes him to the casualty. An X-ray is done which shows the following picture. What is the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate Endoscopic removal

 

The X-ray shows a coin stuck in the esophagus. When the entire circumference of the coin is seen on the AP (anteroposterior) view of the chest X-ray, it indicates that the coin is likely to be in the esophagus. If the coin appears as a slit on the AP view of the X-ray, it would likely be in the trachea.

 

Based on the X-ray findings showing a coin in the esophagus and the clinical symptoms of dysphagia, drooling of saliva, and choking, the correct line of management is immediate endoscopic removal to prevent complications such as obstruction, perforation, or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Bronchoscopic removal: Incorrect. Bronchoscopic removal would be indicated if the foreign body was in the trachea or bronchi. Since the X-ray indicates the coin is in the esophagus, this is not the correct procedure.

 

Option C. Heimlich's maneuver: Incorrect. The Heimlich maneuver (or abdominal thrusts) is a first aid procedure used to treat upper airway obstructions caused by foreign objects. This would be appropriate if the child were actively choking due to an obstruction in the trachea or upper airway, but since the coin is lodged in the esophagus, this is not the correct action.

 

Option D. Wait and Watch: Incorrect. In some cases, especially with smaller, non-sharp objects that are not causing acute distress, a "wait and watch" approach might be reasonable to see if the foreign body passes naturally through the digestive system. However, given the size of the coin and the potential risks associated with a foreign body in the esophagus, this is not a recommended approach in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a foreign body such as a coin is detected in the esophagus on X-ray, immediate endoscopic removal is indicated to prevent potential complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female took aspirin for headache and she developed wheezing and breathlessness. This will be associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasal Polyp

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of a condition known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), commonly known as Samter’s triad. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyposis (particularly ethmoidal polyps)
  • Sensitivity to aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

 

When individuals with this triad ingest aspirin, they can experience severe respiratory reactions including nasal congestion, asthma attacks, and even anaphylaxis. This reaction is not mediated by IgE, which is the common pathway for allergic reactions, but through alterations in leukotriene and prostaglandin metabolism.

 

Details on Nasal Polyps:

 

  • Nasal polyps are benign growths that occur in the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses.
  • They are associated with chronic inflammation and are often seen in conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased IgE: While increased IgE is typical of allergic reactions (allergic asthma, allergic rhinitis), AERD is a non-IgE mediated reaction.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Also known as allergic asthma, it involves an IgE-mediated response to external allergens, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Drug interaction: While the symptoms can be perceived as a drug interaction, they are actually a specific pharmacological reaction to NSAIDs in patients with AERD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the link between aspirin ingestion and respiratory symptoms in patients with nasal polyps is crucial for managing their condition effectively. Patients diagnosed with AERD should avoid NSAIDs and may need specific treatments for asthma and nasal polyps, along with alternatives to NSAIDs for pain management.

 

Samter’s triad: Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity

questions.text: Which of following is less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Auditory Hallucination

 

Auditory hallucinations are predominantly associated with psychiatric conditions rather than organic brain disorders. While they can occur in organic conditions like severe intoxications or delirium, they are most commonly observed in mental health disorders such as schizophrenia or severe depression. In contrast, organic causes of mental illness often involve symptoms that are related directly to physical changes or damage in the brain, such as those caused by neurological diseases, injuries, or infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Old age: Old age is not specifically indicative of an organic or non-organic mental illness but increases susceptibility to both, including neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Option B. Acute onset: Acute onset can often suggest an organic cause, especially when linked to brain injury or sudden health changes impacting brain function.

 

Option C. Loss of consciousness: Loss of consciousness typically points to an organic cause, as it can indicate underlying neurological issues or systemic body failures impacting brain function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with psychiatric illnesses and are less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness compared to symptoms like loss of consciousness or acute neurological changes.

questions.text: In a small coastal town in Kerala, a sudden surge of gastroenteritis cases is reported within two days after a community seafood feast. Health officials suspect the seafood feast as the source of the epidemic. Which of the following statements is true regarding this type of single exposure point source epidemic? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Explosive in nature

 

Single exposure or ‘Point source’ epidemics characteristics:

 

  • ‘Sharp rise and sharp fall’ in no. of cases i.e., single wave 
  • ‘Clustering of cases’ in a narrow interval of time
  • All ‘cases develop within one incubation period’ of the disease.
  • Examples: Food poisoning, Measles, Chicken pox, Cholera, BHOPAL GAS TRAGEDY

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. With more than 1 incubation period: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics are confined to one incubation period.

 

Option C. With multiple peaks: Incorrect as single exposure epidemics typically have a single peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single exposure point source epidemics are explosive in nature with a rapid increase and decline in cases, confined to one incubation period.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. What would be the further management of this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioiodine scan

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, the usual next step is a Radioiodine scan to detect any remaining thyroid tissue and potential metastasis. Based on the findings, further therapeutic radioactive iodine might be administered. Regular follow-up, including blood tests and imaging studies, will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence or metastasis.

 

Radioiodine scan (also known as I-123 or RAI scan) is often used post-thyroidectomy to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease. This aids in planning for subsequent radioactive iodine therapy to ablate residual tissue or treat metastatic disease. The patient is usually given a dose of radioactive iodine, which is taken up by any remaining thyroid cells, and then imaging is done to determine the distribution of the radioactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiation: Incorrect in the majority of cases. External beam radiation therapy is not typically the first line of treatment for papillary thyroid cancer. It might be considered in rare situations, such as for certain anaplastic thyroid cancers or when the cancer is very aggressive, doesn't take up iodine, and other treatments haven't worked.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Incorrect. Simply monitoring without further treatment is not the standard of care for papillary thyroid cancer after surgery, especially when the cancer is of significant size, shows aggressive features, or has spread to lymph nodes or distant sites. Typically, the patient will undergo some form of adjuvant therapy or monitoring, often starting with a radioiodine scan.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy: Incorrect for early and most intermediate stages. Chemotherapy isn't a standard treatment for most thyroid cancers. However, it might be recommended for people who don't respond to standard treatments and for certain types of aggressive thyroid cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan is typically used to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease, guiding further therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: A truck driver is presenting with a painless ulcer with firm base, what is the next investigation you will prefer to do?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscopy for spirochetes

 

The presentation of a painless ulcer with a firm base is highly suggestive of a syphilitic chancre, which is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The most appropriate next investigation for diagnosing syphilis in this context is dark field microscopy.

 

 

Dark Field Microscopy:

 

  • It is used to directly visualize Treponema pallidum in fluid from the ulcer.
  • This method allows the detection of the characteristic motility of spirochetes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gram staining: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum is not effectively visualized with Gram staining due to its thin and delicate structure.

 

Option C. Tzanck smear for giant cells: Incorrect. Tzanck smear is used for diagnosing viral infections like herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which present with different clinical features such as painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Cell line culture: Incorrect. Cell culture is not routinely used for diagnosing syphilis and is more applicable for viral pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of liver. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Marked structure is Segment V of liver.

 

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments based on the Couinaud classification system. Each segment has its own vascular and biliary supply.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments according to the Couinaud classification

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linea Nigra

 

Explanation:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stria gravidarum: Stria gravidarum is a reddish stria of present pregnancy.

 

Option B. Linea Alba: The midline of the anterior abdominal wall skin. It takes on dark brown-black pigmentation to form the linea nigra.

 

 Option D. Stria albicans: Stria albicans is a silvery stria of previous pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Ref: Page no 79, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Correct about rheumatoid arthritis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autoimmunity

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin.

 

The following steps outline pathogenesis of RA:

 

  1. Genetic Predisposition: Certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class II genes, particularly the HLA-DRB1 gene, have been strongly associated with an increased risk of developing RA.
  2. Environmental Triggers: Environmental factors, such as infections, smoking, and hormonal influences, are believed to trigger the development of RA in genetically susceptible individuals.
  3. Autoimmunity: In RA, the immune system mistakenly targets and attacks the body's own tissues, particularly the synovial membrane lining the joints. Autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, are commonly present in individuals with RA. These antibodies contribute to the autoimmune response by targeting self-antigens and promoting inflammation.
  4. Synovial Inflammation: The initial inflammatory response in RA occurs within the synovium, leading to synovitis. Activated immune cells, such as T cells and macrophages, infiltrate the synovial membrane, releasing pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), interleukin-1 (IL-1), and interleukin-6 (IL-6). These cytokines promote further inflammation and contribute to the destruction of joint tissues.
  5. Pannus Formation: Prolonged synovial inflammation leads to the formation of a pannus, an invasive synovial tissue mass. The pannus consists of activated synovial fibroblasts, immune cells, and newly formed blood vessels. The pannus invades and destroys cartilage, bone, and other joint structures, leading to joint deformities and functional impairment.
  6. Bone Erosion and Cartilage Destruction: The pannus, along with the release of enzymes, such as matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), promotes the erosion and destruction of bone and cartilage. MMPs degrade the extracellular matrix components, contributing to joint damage and irreversible structural changes.
  7. Systemic Manifestations: Rheumatoid arthritis is not limited to the joints and can involve multiple organs and systems. Systemic inflammation can lead to complications such as rheumatoid nodules, rheumatoid lung disease, vasculitis, pericarditis, and involvement of other tissues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgE Mediated: IgE-mediated responses are characteristic of Type I hypersensitivity reactions, not RA.

 

Option B. Defective Cellular and Humoral Immunity: While immune dysfunction is a component of RA, it is specifically an autoimmune disorder, not just a general defect in immunity.

 

Option D. Chronic Microbial Infections: RA is not caused by chronic microbial infections, although infections can trigger its onset in genetically predisposed individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imp. Characteristic features of RA:

  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone
  • Subcutaneous nodule

choices.text: Normal leukocyte counts

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotension

 

Gaisböck syndrome, also known as stress polycythemia or stress erythrocytosis, is characterized by a chronic relative increase in red blood cell count due to reduced plasma volume, not an actual increase in RBC production. Patients typically exhibit the following features:

 

  • Hypertension, not hypotension
  • Relative erythrocytosis
  • Normal leukocyte counts
  • Obesity

 

Note – DD - Polycythemia: Patients with polycythemia typically present with splenomegaly, Patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not exhibit splenomegaly.

 

Key Features of Gaisböck Syndrome:

 

  • Relative Erythrocytosis: An apparent increase in RBC count due to decreased plasma volume.
  • Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is common in these patients.
  • Normal Leukocyte Counts: There is no increase in white blood cells.
  • Obesity: Many patients with Gaisböck syndrome are obese.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythrocytosis: Erythrocytosis is a hallmark of Gaisböck syndrome due to reduced plasma volume.

 

Option C. Normal leukocyte counts: Patients with Gaisböck syndrome typically have normal leukocyte counts.

 

Option D. Obesity: Obesity is commonly associated with Gaisböck syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is characterized by relative erythrocytosis, hypertension, normal leukocyte counts, and obesity. Hypotension & splenomegaly is not a feature of this syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema for last few months. It started on face but now it is generalized with pedal edema and ascites. He showed good response to steroids. His was RBS 112 mg/dl. On urine examination massive proteinuria was seen. On light microscopy the findings were unremarkable, on electron microscopy of kidney biopsy, effacement of podocytes was seen. Identify the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimal change disease

    

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is another cause of nephrotic syndrome but is less common in children than MCD. It typically shows segmental sclerosis on light microscopy, which was not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Membranous glomerulonephritis: This condition usually presents with subepithelial deposits and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy, which is not described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with hematuria, hypertension, and low complement levels, along with a history of recent streptococcal infection. It is not associated with the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Minimal Change Disease is characterized by generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and unremarkable light microscopy findings, with podocyte effacement seen on electron microscopy. It typically responds well to corticosteroids.

questions.text: A young female who is sexually active, presented to the OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain, bleeding, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, she had 103 ◦F fever and cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

A young, sexually active female with features like lower abdominal pain, bleeding and foul-smelling vaginal discharge and signs like fever and cervical motion tenderness, is suggestive of Pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis patient presents with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. But there is no foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option C. Adenomyosis. Adenomyosis patient presents with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and pelvic examination reveals uniformenlargement of the uterus.

 

Option D. Appendicitis: Appendicitis causes migrating pain from umbilical area to right iliac fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A young, sexually active female with features like lower abdominal pain, bleeding and foul-smelling vaginal discharge and signs like fever and cervical motion tenderness, is suggestive of Pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology pg 131-133

questions.text: Which among the following is a symptom of cannabis intake? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dreamy State

 

Dreamy State is a symptom of cannabis intake.

 

CANNABIS INTOXICATION

 

  • Euphoria, sense of slowing of time, sense of floating in the air, reddening of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, dryness of mouth.
  • Depersonalization, Derealization, synaesthesia, illusions.
  • Bad trip- An unpleasant experience after consumption of cannabis in which the person may feel restless, fearful, paranoid and anxious.

 

CANNABIS WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS

 

  • Irritability
  • Depressed mood, sleep disturbances, headaches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depressed mood:  This is a withdrawal symptom, not a feature of acute intoxication. Individuals may experience depressed mood a few days after stopping chronic cannabis use.

 

Option B. Irritability:  Irritability is also associated with cannabis withdrawal, commonly seen when long-term users discontinue use abruptly.

 

Option C. Sleep disturbance:  Sleep-related issues such as insomnia or vivid dreams typically occur during withdrawal, not intoxication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannabis intoxication leads to psychological effects like euphoria, dreamy state, altered time perception, and depersonalization, while withdrawal manifests with irritability, low mood, sleep disturbances, and cravings.

questions.text: A public health official notes that there were 60 infant deaths and 5,000 live births in the past year. What denominator should she use to calculate the infant mortality rate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1000

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated using the formula:

 

 

The denominator of 1000 is used to standardize the rate for easy comparison across different regions and populations.

 

In this case:

 

 

Remember:

 

SRS bulletin 2022 - India IMR: 28 per 1000 live births 

 

NFHS 5 (2019-21)- India IMR: 35 per 1000 live births 

 

(IMR of Kerala - 12 per 1000 live births and Japan 2 per 1000 live births)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard denominator for calculating and expressing the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is 1000 live births.

choices.text: Trying to make them think for themselves

questions.text: In the bustling streets of Mumbai, a young filmmaker is working on a documentary about the impact of media on public opinion. During his interviews with several media experts, he encounters the term "propaganda" frequently. Intrigued, he decides to explore this concept further and learns that it plays a significant role in shaping public perception. In the context of media and communication, which of the following best describes the essence of "propaganda"?(FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Appeals to emotions

 

Propaganda refers to - trying to make them think for themselves, it appeals to emotions. Propaganda is a passively acquired knowledge, which by persuasive communication leads to change in belief and attitude (brain washing).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trying to make them think for themselves: This is more aligned with education and critical thinking, not propaganda.

 

Option B. Behavior centric: While propaganda aims to change behavior, its primary method is through emotional appeal rather than focusing on behavior itself.

 

Option C. Acquiring knowledge: Propaganda often involves passive acquisition of biased information, not the active pursuit of knowledge.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anti-dyslipidemic drug work by stimulating Peroxisome proliferator activated receptor (PPAR) alpha? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gemfibrozil

 

  • Fibrates are a class of hypolipidemic drugs.

  • They include Gemfibrozil, Fenofibrate, Clofibrate.

  • They are mainly used in Hypertriglyceridemia and chylomicronemia syndromes.

  • Fibrates bind to the PPAR alpha and stimulates Lipoprotein lipase thus enhancing the clearance of VLDL.

  • Their important side effects include: Gallstones formation and Myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a statin, which is an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of cholesterol in the liver, leading to reduced levels of LDL cholesterol.

 

Option C. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe decreases the absorption of cholesterol from the small intestine. It targets and inhibits the Niemann-Pick C1-Like 1 (NPC1L1) protein, which is involved in the uptake of cholesterol.

 

Option D. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, works by decreasing hormone-sensitive lipase activity, which leads to reduced breakdown of fats in adipose tissue. This decreases the levels of free fatty acids available for hepatic triglyceride synthesis, leading to lower levels of LDL and VLDL and an increase in HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrates, including gemfibrozil, work by stimulating PPAR-α, which enhances the activity of lipoprotein lipase, leading to increased clearance of VLDL and triglycerides. This mechanism makes fibrates particularly effective in treating hypertriglyceridemia and related disorders. Other hypolipidemic drugs like atorvastatin, ezetimibe, and niacin have different mechanisms of action targeting other aspects of lipid metabolism.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with cancer is undergoing radiotherapy. She is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy daily for five days a week, for a total treatment duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What among the following explains this type of radiotherapy?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy

 

 

5 ‘R’s of Fractionated Radiotherapy

 

1. Repair - for normal surrounding cells

2. Repopulation

3. Reoxygenation

4. Reassortment /Redistribution

5. Radiosensitivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy involves delivering 1.8 to 2 Gy per day, five days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, allowing for normal tissue recovery between treatments.

questions.text: The transverse green line shown in the image corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. L5

 

Explanation:

 

The green line marked on the torso corresponds to the L5 vertebral level. This line is also known as the intertubercular plane or Tuffier's line, which is anatomically aligned with the upper border of the L5 vertebra. The intertubercular plane is significant in clinical settings as it passes through the highest points of the iliac crests, located at the L4-L5 intervertebral disc space. This reference point is crucial for procedures such as spinal anesthesia and lumbar punctures, where accurate identification of vertebral levels is essential.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • It serves as a reference point for various medical procedures, particularly those involving the lumbar spine, spinal anesthesia, and the placement of lumbar punctures (spinal taps).
  • When performing a lumbar puncture, healthcare providers often use the intertubercular plane as a landmark to identify the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the subarachnoid space.
    • Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century.
    • Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T12: Incorrect as it corresponds to the lower end of the thoracic spine.

 

Option C. L1: Incorrect and typically aligns with the lower border of the first lumbar vertebra.

 

Option D. L3: Incorrect as it corresponds to the subcostal plane, not the intertubercular plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abdominal Planes & Quadrants –

 

 

#2 Horizontal Plane -

  • Subcostal Plane (L3)
  • Trans tubercular Plane (L5- upper border)

#2 Vertical Planes

Midclavicular Line / Plane (from midpoint of clavicle till midinguinal point)

  • Trans-pyloric Plane of Addison - Lower border of L1

Supracristal Plane - L4

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least side effects with good healing of ulcers?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy
 

Duodenal ulcers can be caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, increased acid secretion, or the use of NSAIDs. When medical management is ineffective or complications arise, surgical treatment may be necessary. Among the surgical options, a highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is preferred due to its ability to effectively reduce acid secretion while causing the least side effects and offering good ulcer healing.

  • This procedure, also known as parietal cell vagotomy or proximal gastric vagotomy, targets only the vagal nerve fibers that stimulate acid-producing parietal cells in the stomach. It spares the vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus, and the remaining abdominal viscera.
  • By preserving the innervation to the antrum and pylorus, HSV maintains more normal gastric function, reducing the risk of side effects such as delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea.
  • This makes it the surgical option with the least side effects and a good rate of ulcer healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truncal Vagotomy:

 

  • Involves dividing the main trunk of the vagus nerve as it enters the abdomen, significantly reducing parasympathetic stimulation to the stomach and decreasing gastric acid secretion.
  • Although effective in reducing acid secretion, it often causes significant side effects, including delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea, due to the loss of vagal control over the entire stomach and other abdominal organs.

 

Option B. Selective Vagotomy:

 

  • Selectively cuts the vagus nerve fibers supplying the stomach while preserving the nerve supply to the pylorus, liver, and biliary system.
  • Reduces acid secretion less than truncal vagotomy but preserves more normal stomach function. However, it is still associated with more side effects compared to highly selective vagotomy.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy:

 

  • Creates a new connection between the stomach and the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum where the ulcer is located.
  • Does not reduce acid secretion and does not address the underlying cause of the ulcer. It is typically performed for ulcer complications or in combination with other procedures. It may be associated with dumping syndrome and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is the preferred surgical option for chronic duodenal ulcers due to its effective reduction of acid secretion, minimal side effects, and good ulcer healing rate.

choices.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery
It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

 

Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It can spread through both hematogenous routes and lymphatics, and treatment typically involves a combination of surgery and chemotherapy. However, while it is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, it is not the most common. That distinction belongs to neuroblastoma.

 

It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children: This statement is incorrect. While Wilms tumor is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in pediatric patients is neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spread by lymphatics: Nephroblastoma can spread via lymphatics, usually involving regional lymph nodes first. Although hematogenous spread is more common, lymphatic spread does occur.

 

Option B. Early lung metastasis: Wilms tumor often metastasizes to the lungs early in its course. Children diagnosed with Wilms tumor typically undergo chest imaging to check for lung metastasis.

 

Option C. Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery: The standard treatment for Wilms tumor involves surgical removal of the tumor followed by chemotherapy to eliminate any remaining cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroblastoma is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, not Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man visits your clinic with his 2-year-old son, expressing concerns about vaccinations due to a belief in his community that vaccinations can lead to impotency. He is fearful for his son's future but is also influenced by societal beliefs. Addressing his concerns requires overcoming which type of barrier? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cultural barrier

 

The wrong belief of vaccination leading to impotency is an example of cultural barrier. Cultural barrier includes illiteracy, knowledge and understanding, customs, beliefs, religion, economic and social class differences, language variations, and cultural difficulties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psychological barrier occurs due to emotional disturbances, levels of intelligence, language or comprehension difficulties.

 

Option B. Environmental barriers include noise, congestion etc. in the external environment which hampers understanding and communication.

 

Option C. Physiological barriers include difficulties in hearing, expression, vision etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cultural beliefs can significantly influence health decisions, and understanding these beliefs is crucial for effective healthcare communication and intervention.

questions.text: Which structure is advised to occlude in ligation of splenic artery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. D

 

Explanation:

 

Structure D will be occluded in order to ligate the splenic artery.

 

Peritoneal ligaments

 

  1. Gastrosplenic ligaments
  2. Splenorenal ligaments / Lienorenal ligaments (Extends from spleen to Left kidney)

 

Contents

 

  1. TAIL of PANCREAS
  2. SPLENIC VESSELS

 

 

 

In the ligation of the splenic artery, the primary objective is to interrupt the blood supply to the spleen. This procedure may be performed for various medical reasons, such as treating splenic artery aneurysms or managing traumatic injuries to the spleen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal Vein: The portal vein is a major blood vessel that carries nutrient-rich, oxygen-poor blood from the digestive organs (stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and spleen) to the liver. It is not advisable to occlude the portal vein during ligation of the splenic artery because doing so would disrupt blood flow to the liver, potentially leading to severe liver dysfunction and complications.

 

Option B. Hepatogastric Ligament: The hepatogastric ligament is a connective tissue structure that attaches the liver to the stomach. It does not play a significant role in the blood supply to the spleen, so occluding it would not achieve the intended goal of interrupting blood flow to the spleen.

 

Option C. Gastrosplenic Ligament: The gastrosplenic ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. Although it is in close proximity to the spleen, occluding this ligament alone would not effectively disrupt the blood supply to the spleen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament, also known as the splenorenal ligament, is the structure that connects the spleen to the kidney. It contains the splenic artery, which is the primary vessel supplying blood to the spleen. During ligation of the splenic artery, the lienorenal ligament is typically addressed, and the splenic artery within this ligament is occluded, effectively cutting off the blood supply to the spleen.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who underwent perimetry had the following visual field defect. What is the site of the lesion?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The image given above shows a bitemporal hemianopsia visual field defect, caused due to a lesion at the optic chiasma.

 

VISUAL PATHWAY - Eye (Retina) → Optic Nerve → Optic Chiasm → Optic Tract → Lateral Geniculate Nucleus → Optic Radiation → Visual Cortex

 

  1. Eye (Retina): Light enters the eye and is captured by photoreceptor cells in the retina.
  2. Optic Nerve: The photoreceptor cells in the retina send signals via the optic nerve to the brain.
  3. Optic Chiasm: The optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over at the optic chiasm.
  4. Optic Tract: The fibers continue along the optic tract, which carries visual information from each eye to the brain.
  5. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus: The optic tract fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
  6. Optic Radiation: From the lateral geniculate nucleus, the visual information is transmitted via the optic radiation fibers to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe of the brain.
  7. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex processes the visual information to create the perception of vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic tract: A lesion here would result in a homonymous hemianopsia, where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Option C. Optic radiations: A lesion in the optic radiations can cause a quadrant anopsia, affecting a specific quarter of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Occipital cortex: A lesion here could also cause homonymous hemianopsia, often with macular sparing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopsia, characterized by loss of the outer visual fields in both eyes, is typically caused by a lesion at the optic chiasma.

questions.text: The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary microadenoma

 

Cushing's disease is specifically caused by a pituitary adenoma that secretes excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). This excess ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce more cortisol, leading to the symptoms of Cushing's syndrome. In the context of Cushing's disease, the term always refers to a pituitary origin.

 

Cushing's syndrome, on the other hand, can have various causes:

 

  • Exogenous Cushing's syndrome: Due to external sources of cortisol, such as prolonged use of glucocorticoid medications.
  • Endogenous Cushing's syndrome: subdivided into – 
    • ACTH-dependent - High ACTH levels stimulate cortisol production, associated with symptoms like hyperpigmentation. (e.g. pituitary adenoma/ cushing’s disease, ectopic ACTH secretion)
    • ACTH-independent - Low or normal ACTH levels, with cortisol overproduction directly from the adrenal glands (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma).

 

Among the endogenous causes, pituitary adenomas (Cushing's disease) are the most common, responsible for about 60-65% of cases. Ectopic ACTH secretion accounts for about 20-25% of cases, and adrenal tumors are responsible for 5-10% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: Can cause ectopic ACTH syndrome but is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease.

 

Option B. Adrenal tumor: Can cause Cushing's syndrome but is less common compared to pituitary adenomas.

 

Option C. Ectopic ACTH syndrome: Can be caused by various tumors, including small-cell lung cancer, but is not as common as pituitary adenomas in causing Cushing's disease. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pituitary microadenoma is the most common cause of Cushing's disease, which is characterized by excess ACTH production from the pituitary gland.

questions.text: Which of the following compound(s) is most likely to cause diabetic cataract:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of sorbitol

 

Explanation

 

In diabetes, high levels of glucose in the lens of the eye can lead to increased production of sorbitol via the aldose reductase pathway. Sorbitol, being osmotically active, cannot easily cross cell membranes and thus accumulates in the lens, leading to an osmotic imbalance that causes swelling, opacification, and eventually, cataract formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Galactose + Glucose: While accumulation of galactose can lead to cataract formation (as seen in classic galactosemia), in the context of diabetes, the primary issue is the accumulation of sorbitol derived from glucose. Galactose is not typically elevated in diabetic patients unless there is a concurrent metabolic disorder affecting galactose metabolism.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Galactitol + Glucose: Similar to option B, while galactitol (formed from galactose) can contribute to cataract formation in conditions like galactosemia, it is not the primary concern in diabetic cataract where the key issue is sorbitol accumulation from glucose.

 

Option D. Accumulation of Glucose Only: While hyperglycemia (high glucose levels) is the underlying cause of diabetic complications, including cataracts, it's the metabolic conversion of this excess glucose to sorbitol in the lens that primarily contributes to cataract formation, not the accumulation of glucose alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Diabetes mellitus, in the lens by polyol pathway, glucose converted to sorbitol by the enzyme Aldose reductase. Excess Glucose can enter the lens of the eye and get converted to Sorbitol with the help of aldose reductase. This enzyme is a major contributor to diabetic complication due to accumulation of sorbitol which is hygroscopic sugar and causes swelling of the eye in untreated diabetic patients
  • In galactosemia, Dulcitol or Galactitol is responsible for cataract.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 200

choices.text: Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius
Right Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

questions.text: A patient was asked to stand on his left leg and his right hip falls down, which among the following muscles will be affected in this case? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

 

Left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles will be affected in this case.

 

The left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles (supplied by the left superior gluteal nerve) are primarily responsible for abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially when standing on one leg.

 

Weakness or dysfunction in these muscles on the left side could lead to a drop in the right hip when the patient tries to stand on the left leg. This is because the left hip abductors are unable to maintain proper alignment and stability of the pelvis (Positive Trendelenburg's sign)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Gluteus Maximus: The gluteus maximus is primarily responsible for hip extension and external rotation but has a lesser role in hip abduction. Weakness or dysfunction of the gluteus maximus may not be the primary cause of the right hip dropping in this specific scenario.

 

Option C. Right Gluteus Minimus and Gluteus Medius: The right gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles on the same side as the falling hip are less likely to be the primary cause of the right hip dropping when standing on the left leg. These muscles would typically work to elevate and stabilize the right hip..

 

Option D.  Quadriceps: The quadriceps muscles are located in the front of the thigh and primarily function to extend the knee. While they play a role in maintaining knee stability during activities like standing, they are not the primary muscles responsible for stabilizing the hip during single-leg stance. Therefore, weakness in the quadriceps may not directly cause the right hip to drop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness in the left gluteus minimus and medius is indicated by the positive Trendelenburg's sign, where the pelvis drops on the side of the non-weight bearing leg (right), due to inadequate stabilization by these muscles on the standing leg (left).

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented in OBG emergency with 38 weeks of amenorrhea. She is in first stage of labour and on examination, cervical dilatation is 6 cm. According to you, what will be a satisfactory dilatation rate? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.2 cm/hr

 

Explanation:

 

In a nullipara, 1.2 cm/hr is the best dilatation rate among given options.

 

First stage of labour has 2 phases:

 

 

  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h
  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a multi is 1.5 cm/h

 

 

The WHO Labour Care guide (2021) differs from the earlier partograph in the following ways:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h

 

Ref: WHO labour care guide Users Manual 2021

questions.text: A child is presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash and spots in the oral cavity as shown in the given image, what is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

The clinical presentation of fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash, and characteristic spots in the oral cavity is indicative of measles. The spots shown in the image are Koplik spots, which are pathognomonic for measles.

 

Key Points about Measles:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by an RNA paramyxovirus.
  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Koplik Spots: Small, white lesions with a red base typically found opposite the lower second molar.
    • Rash: Starts behind the ears (retroauricular) and spreads downwards.
    • Other Symptoms: Fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cough.

 

Common Complications:

 

  • Most Common: Serous otitis media.
  • Serious Complication: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a late and fatal complication.
  • Histopathology: Presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox: Incorrect. Chicken pox (varicella) presents with a vesicular rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs and face. Oral lesions are not specific to chicken pox.

 

Option C. Mumps: Incorrect. Mumps typically presents with parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) and may have associated fever and orchitis in males. Koplik spots are not a feature of mumps.

 

Option D. Rubella: Incorrect. Rubella presents with a fine, pink rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs, but it does not present with Koplik spots. It is usually milder than measles and may have postauricular lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Koplik spots, along with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and rash, is highly indicative of measles.

questions.text: CSF otorrhea can occur in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Temporal Bone fracture

 

CSF otorrhea is associated with Longitudinal Temporal Bone fracture.

 

Temporal bone fractures can be of types:

 

 

 

Battle’s sign is associated with temporal bone fracture.

 

 

Cribriform plate damage can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TM rupture due to trauma: While traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane may occur, it does not typically result in CSF otorrhea unless associated with a temporal bone fracture.

 

Option B. Stab injury in the eye: Unlikely to cause CSF otorrhea directly unless there is extensive cranial trauma involving the skull base.

 

Option C. Cribriform plate fracture: More commonly associated with CSF rhinorrhea (leakage of CSF from the nose) due to its location and relationship to the nasal cavity and sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF otorrhea is a serious condition often linked with fractures of the temporal bone. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and promote effective healing. Monitoring for signs of infection or persistent leakage is essential, as these may necessitate more aggressive interventions.

questions.text: A child is presenting with the ptosis of the eye and the following presentation. What will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capillary Hemangioma

 

Above image is showing capillary Hemangioma involving the left upper eyelid and periocular area.

 

It is a  most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood.

 

Its benign in nature caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels.

 

Types of hemangioma:

 

1. Capillary hemangioma (most common)

2. Juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma

3. Cavernous hemangioma

4. Pyogenic hemangioma.

 

Capillary hemangiomas can be small, solitary lesions or larger masses. They might lead to visual issues due to mechanical ptosis or associate with PHACE syndrome (posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities).

 

 30% of lesions resolved by the age of 3 years and 75% by the age of 7

 

Indications for treatment are:

 

  1. Visual amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion strabismus
  2. Cosmetic
  3. Optic nerve compression
  4. Exposure keratopathy

 

Capillary Hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often.

 

Treatment options include:

 

  1. Beta blockers
  2. Steroids
  3. Interferon alpha 2A and vincristine
  4. Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous hemangioma

 

  • Features: These are deeper vascular malformations filled with blood. They can be found in deeper layers of the skin or even in organs and present as soft, blue-colored swellings as shown below.

 

 

  • Cavernous hemangiomas are deeper structures, and the clinical features provided specifically mention capillary hemangioma, which is more superficial.

 

Option C. Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Option D. salmon patches or nevus simplex

 

  • Features: These are flat, pink patches that appear at birth. Commonly known as "stork bites" when on the neck and "angel kisses" when on the forehead or eyelids, they usually fade by the age of 2, especially those located on the forehead and eyelids.

 

Salmon patch

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose capillary Hemangioma by recognizing a raised, bright red lesion on the skin, which can cause distortion of local structures, such as ptosis when it occurs on the eyelid.

 

References: Ghai essential pediatrics 9th edition- page no 679

Yanoff & Duker Textbook of Ophthalmology 5th Edition Page no 1327

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e Page no 518-520

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

Explanation:

 

This instrument is Wrigley’s (Outlet) Forceps.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kielland’s Forceps: Slight pelvic curve, rotational forceps

 

Option B. Pipers Forceps: After coming head of breech, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks for the body to rest on

 

Option D. Das Forceps: It is an Indian type of long Obstetric forceps, lighter than its western counterparts, may be available with axis traction device

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrigley's (Outlet) Forceps are used for assisted vaginal delivery when the fetal head is at the perineum.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8thedition page 652,659

choices.text: Both Vocal cords involved and fixed
Both Vocal cords involved and mobile
One Vocal cord involved and fixed
One Vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.text: Mark the correct description for laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both vocal cords involved and mobile

 

T1b in Laryngeal Cancer refers to the tumor involving both vocal cords but still maintaining mobility. This indicates that the cancer is localized to the vocal cords without extending into other areas that would restrict their movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both Vocal cords involved and fixed: This would typically be classified under T3 or higher, depending on the extent of fixation and additional features.

 

Option C. One Vocal cord involved and fixed: Would be classified as T3 due to the fixation of the vocal cord, indicating more advanced local disease.

 

Option D. One Vocal cord involved and mobile: This corresponds to T1a, indicating a more limited disease confined to one vocal cord but not affecting mobility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNM staging for CA Larynx:

 

  • T1 – only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)
  • T2 – involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.
  • T3 – involving pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.
  • T4a – local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx
  • T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)
  • N0 – no cervical lymph nodes
  • N1 – single ipsilateral < 3cm
  • N2 – single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm
  • N3 – single or multiple nodes > 6cm
  • M0 – no metastasis
  • M1 – metastasis present

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. Bacillus anthracis is a brick/box car shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

 

It can cause -

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax
  • Pulmonary anthrax
  • Intestinal anthrax

 

 

Box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria monocytogens: Incorrect. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod that can cause listeriosis, but it does not have the brick/boxcar shape and is not typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option C. Bacillus cereus: Incorrect. Bacillus cereus can cause food poisoning and is a gram-positive rod, but it does not typically present with the brick/boxcar shape or cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are gram-positive cocci and do not exhibit the described morphology or cause anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

 

The utricle and saccule are part of the vestibular system in the inner ear, which is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and orientation. They do not participate in the hearing process but are involved in sensing linear accelerations.

 

  • Utricle: Senses horizontal linear movements.
  • Saccule: Senses vertical linear movements.

 

Both structures contain sensory epithelia known as the maculae, which house hair cells that respond to shifts in movement through the displacement of tiny stones called otoliths on a gel-like layer.

 

Semicircular canals sense the Angular movements.

 

Hearing is sensed by Organ of Corti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hearing high frequency sounds & C. Hearing low frequency sounds: These functions are attributed to the cochlea, where sound vibrations are converted into nerve signals that are interpreted by the brain. High and low frequency sound detection is facilitated by different regions of the cochlear basilar membrane.

 

Option D. Angular acceleration: This is the specific function of the semicircular canals, which are filled with fluid and contain sensory hair cells that respond to the rotation of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: Although Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 are derived from the same gene but are finally translated into separate proteins. This is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

Explanation:

 

The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is due to RNA editing. In the intestine, a specific cytidine in the mRNA for Apo B is deaminated to uridine, which changes the codon from one encoding amino acid to a stop codon. This results in the production of a shorter protein, Apo B 48. In the liver, this editing does not occur, so the full-length Apo B 100 is produced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA Gene Mutation in Intestines: Incorrect. The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is not due to a DNA gene mutation specific to the intestines. Both proteins are derived from the same gene, and the variation in their production is not the result of a DNA mutation.

 

Option B. Point Mutation in Liver: Incorrect. Similarly, the production of these two forms of apolipoprotein B is not due to a point mutation in the liver. The liver produces Apo B 100, but this is not because of a mutation in the hepatic DNA.

 

Option C. DNA Gene Splicing: Incorrect. While alternative splicing is a common mechanism in generating protein diversity, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 249

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for breastfeeding is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder where the body cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in breast milk and many other foods. Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose and its accumulation can lead to severe complications. Therefore, breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for infants with galactosemia, and they require a special galactose-free formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV: This option is incorrect. While HIV can be transmitted through breast milk, the transmission risk can be significantly reduced by antiretroviral therapy (ART) and other precautions. In certain situations, such as in resource-limited settings where safe alternatives to breastfeeding are not available, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the risks of HIV transmission. However, in areas where safe and affordable alternatives are accessible, avoiding breastfeeding is generally recommended for infants born to HIV-positive mothers.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B: This option is incorrect. Breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants born to mothers with hepatitis B. Transmission of hepatitis B through breast milk is considered low, and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that infants receive the hepatitis B vaccine and a dose of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth to prevent transmission. Breastfeeding can generally continue in these cases.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus infection: This option is incorrect. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted through breast milk, but the transmission risk can be reduced. In most cases, breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants with CMV infection. Precautions such as pasteurization of breast milk or using frozen breast milk from before the infection occurred can be taken to reduce the risk of transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to identify conditions where breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated. Understanding absolute contraindications for breastfeeding is crucial for ensuring the safety and health of both the neonate and the mother. In certain medical conditions, breastfeeding can pose significant health risks to the infant, necessitating alternative feeding methods.

choices.text: The efficacy of the drug b and c are equal
Drug A is the most potent drug
Drug C is less potent and equally efficacious to drug B
Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B, and equally efficacious as drug C

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B and equally efficacious as drug C

 

The above given image is that of a Log Dose-Response curve, where on the X axis we plot the Log concentration of the drug and on the Y axis we plot the Response. From this type of curve , we can know about the following 3 parameters about a drug:

 

  • Potency – Potency means the power of a drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.

  • Efficacy – It is the maximum response produced by a drug. The maximum height of the curve corresponds to the efficacy, or in other words, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug becomes.

  • Safety – The slope of the curve is related to the safety of the drug. The drug with a steeper slope is less safe than a drug with a flatter slope.

 

In the given graph:

 

Potency: D > A > B > C

 

Efficacy: A = B > C = D

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The efficacy of both drugs A and B are equal and the efficacy of drugs D and C are equal.

 

Option B. Drug D is the most potent drug

 

Option C. Drug C is less potent but equally efficacious to drug D

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the given Log Dose-Response curve, Drug D is the most potent drug but is less efficacious than drugs A and B, and equally efficacious as drug C. Potency is determined by the position of the curve along the X-axis, while efficacy is determined by the maximum height of the curve.

questions.text: In which urinary components is Tamm Horsfall protein present? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine cast

 

Tamm Horsfall protein is present in urine cast.

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein, also known as uromodulin, is a glycoprotein produced by the cells lining the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidneys. It is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

 

Other Options:
