Option B. Urine Crystal: Urine crystals are solid particles found in urine, often composed of substances like calcium oxalate, uric acid, or struvite. They are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option C. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in vertebrates. It is not associated with Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option D. Bile Salts: Bile salts are components of bile, which aid in the digestion of fats. They are not found in urine and are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein (uromodulin) is present in urine casts and is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

questions.text: For Coronary artery prevention, which needs to be given:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omega 3 FA

 

Omega-3 Fatty Acids: Correct Answer. Omega-3 fatty acids, found in fish, flaxseeds, and walnuts, are known for their cardioprotective properties. They help reduce inflammation, lower triglyceride levels, and can have a mild anticoagulant effect, all of which are beneficial for preventing coronary artery disease. They also may help reduce blood pressure and have been linked to a lower risk of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saturated Fatty Acid: Saturated fatty acids are typically found in animal fats and some plant oils. High intake of saturated fats is associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease as they can contribute to the buildup of plaque in the arteries, leading to atherosclerosis.

 

Option C. Omega-6 Fatty Acids: While omega-6 fatty acids, found in many vegetable oils, are essential fats, their excessive intake, especially in relation to omega-3 fatty acids, may be linked to increased inflammation. A balanced intake of omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids is important for heart health, but omega-6 fats alone are not specifically recommended for coronary artery disease prevention.

 

Option D. Omega-9 Fatty Acids: Omega-9 fatty acids, such as oleic acid found in olive oil, are monounsaturated fats and can be beneficial for heart health. However, they are not as actively recommended for coronary artery disease prevention as omega-3 fatty acids, which have more direct and researched benefits in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omega-3 PUFAs:

 

  • Affect membrane fluidity in a positive way
  • Help in transfer of cell signal molecules
  • Many of ω-3 metabolites are anti-inflammatory
  • Prevents conversion of ω-6 PUFAs into pro-inflammatory eicosanoids by acting as alternate substrate for enzymes such as lipoxygenase and cyclooxygenase involved in these conversions

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 209

questions.text: Following are the reasons for thiamine deficiency Except: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veganism

 

Explanation

 

While vegan diets exclude animal products, thiamine deficiency is not commonly associated with veganism, especially if the diet is well-planned and includes diverse sources of nutrients. Thiamine is found in whole grains, legumes, seeds, and some fortified foods, which are all components of a typical vegan diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic Alcoholic: Chronic alcoholism is a well-known risk factor for thiamine deficiency. Alcohol impairs thiamine absorption and increases its excretion. Furthermore, alcoholics often have poor dietary intake, contributing to a deficiency. Thiamine deficiency in alcoholics can lead to serious conditions such as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Chronic Use of Diuretics: Prolonged use of diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can lead to increased urinary excretion of thiamine, thus potentially causing or exacerbating a deficiency. This is especially relevant in patients with conditions like heart failure, where diuretics are commonly prescribed.

 

Option D. Bariatric Surgery: Bariatric surgery, especially procedures that involve bypassing parts of the stomach and small intestine, can lead to malabsorption of various nutrients, including thiamine. Patients undergoing bariatric surgery are at risk for nutritional deficiencies and require careful monitoring and supplementation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Major source of Thiamine are whole grains and cereals. So, veganism does not cause thiamine deficiency.
  • Thiamine (also known as vitamin B1) deficiency can be caused by a variety of factors, including:

 

Poor nutrition: Thiamine deficiency is most commonly caused by inadequate dietary intake of thiamine-rich foods such as whole grains, legumes, nuts, and meat.

 

Alcoholism: Chronic alcohol consumption can interfere with the absorption and utilization of thiamine in the body, leading to deficiency.

 

Malabsorption disorders: Conditions such as celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis can impair the body's ability to absorb thiamine from food.

 

Bariatric surgery  Certain types of weight loss surgery, such as gastric bypass, can reduce the body's ability to absorb thiamine.

 

Genetic disorders: Rare genetic disorders such as thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome can cause thiamine deficiency.

 

Medications: Some medications, such as diuretics and certain types of chemotherapy, can interfere with thiamine absorption and utilization.

 

Pregnancy and breastfeeding: Pregnant and breastfeeding women have increased thiamine requirements and may develop deficiency if their intake is insufficient.

 

Aging: Older adults may be at increased risk of thiamine deficiency due to decreased absorption and utilization of the vitamin.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 541-542

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with visual acuity of 6/18, which improves upon performing the pinhole test. During the examination, the presence of fibrosis in the lens nucleus is noted, and his near vision displays improvement. Based on these findings, what is the refractive error he is presenting with? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Index myopia

 

The improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is referred to as the "second sight phenomenon", given in the clinical picture, which is suggestive of index myopia. It manifests as index myopia as a result of nuclear cataract production.

 

MYOPIA - Parallel rays of light are brought into focus in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest. This is also called short sightedness or near sightedness.

 

Types –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Index hypermetropia: This would involve a decrease in the refractive index, leading to farsightedness, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. Presbyopia: This is an age-related condition causing difficulty in near vision due to the lens losing its flexibility. It does not explain the improvement in near vision or the findings of lens fibrosis.

 

Option D. Axial myopia: This is due to an increase in the length of the eyeball and would not be associated with the fibrosis of the lens nucleus or the improvement in near vision seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Index myopia is characterized by an increase in the refractive index of the lens nucleus, often associated with nuclear sclerosis in cataracts, and can result in the "second sight phenomenon," where near vision temporarily improves

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

 

Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection that spreads primarily through the feco-oral route, often through contaminated food and water. It is commonly associated with poor sanitation and overcrowded areas, making it prevalent in areas with inadequate food and water hygiene.

 

Key Points about Hepatitis A:

 

  • Transmission Route: Spread through the feco-oral route.
  • Symptoms: Can cause icterus (jaundice) and gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.
  • Risk Factors: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with the virus, especially in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Prevention: Good hygiene practices, proper sanitation, and vaccination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is primarily spread through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child during childbirth, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C: Incorrect. Hepatitis C is mainly transmitted through blood-to-blood contact, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D: Incorrect. Hepatitis D only occurs in those infected with Hepatitis B and is transmitted in the same ways as Hepatitis B, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route

 

Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing demographic patterns in a tribal region of Jharkhand, India. The community has high birth and death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence. In which stage of the demographic transition model is the birth rate typically the highest?  (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stage 1

 

The highest birth rate is observed in Stage 1 of the demographic cycle, characterized by both high birth and high death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence.

 

Five stages of the demographic cycle: -

 

Stage 1: (High Stationary): High Birth Rate & High Death Rate

 

Stage 2: (Early Expanding): Birth Rate Unchanged & Death Rate Decrease

 

Stage3: (Late Expanding): Birth Rate: Decreases & Death Rate: Decreases

 

Stage 4: (Late Stationary): BR: Low & DR: Low

 

Stage 5: (Declining): BR < DR/Population Decreases

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Five stages of demographic cycle

questions.text: A 35-year-old nurse in a busy city hospital is focused on infection control for general respiratory illnesses. Regular hand washing with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand rub is recommended to prevent the spread of infections. This recommendation falls under which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary

 

This is an example of primary prevention as the risk factor is already present but the disease is being prevented by handwashing. Primary prevention aims to prevent the onset of illness before the disease process begins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial:

 

  • Focuses on preventing the development of risk factors themselves, often through policy or societal changes.
  • For example, promoting a healthy lifestyle to prevent the development of high blood pressure.

 

Option C. Secondary:

 

  • Involves early detection and prompt intervention to prevent progression.
  • For example, screening programs like Pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tertiary:

 

  • Involves managing and reducing the impact of an ongoing illness.
  • For example, providing cardiac rehabilitation after a heart attack to prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levels of prevention

 

  • Primordial-Prevention of development of risk factors
  • Primary- Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • Secondary-Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • Tertiary- Complications are present, death is being prevented.

questions.text: Which structure passes through the marked opening in the given image ? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thoracic duct

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow points to the diaphragm's aortic hiatus. It is crossed by the thoracic duct.

 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are:

 

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

 

 

The diaphragm is a thin, dome-shaped muscle that separates the thoracic cavity (containing the heart and lungs) from the abdominal cavity (containing the digestive organs). It has several structures passing through it, each serving important functions. Let's discuss the structures passing through the diaphragm in detail:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vena Cava (Inferior and Superior):

 

  • The Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm, entering the right atrium just above the diaphragm.
  • The Superior Vena Cava (SVC) is another large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium. It pierces the diaphragm at the level of the 3rd thoracic vertebra.

 

Option C. Esophagus: The Esophagus is a muscular tube that carries food and liquids from the mouth to the stomach for digestion. It passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the "esophageal hiatus." The diaphragm helps prevent stomach acid from flowing back into the esophagus, contributing to the prevention of acid reflux.

 

Option D. Phrenic Nerve: The Phrenic Nerve is a paired nerve (right and left) that originates from the cervical spinal nerves (C3, C4, and C5) and descends through the neck and thorax. It supplies motor and sensory innervation to the diaphragm, enabling it to contract and control breathing. The phrenic nerves pass through the diaphragm on both sides, allowing for coordinated breathing movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Thoracic Duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body. It collects lymph from the lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen, left thorax, left upper limb, and left side of the head and neck. The thoracic duct passes through the diaphragm to drain lymphatic fluid into the venous system, connecting to the left subclavian vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a micronutrient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcium

 

Calcium: Correct Answer. Calcium is not a micronutrient; it is a macromineral. The human body requires calcium in relatively large amounts compared to trace minerals. It is essential for bone structure, nerve transmission, muscle function, and blood clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper is a micronutrient. It is required in trace amounts in the human diet and plays a role in various enzyme reactions, including those involved in iron metabolism and the functioning of the nervous system.

 

Option C. Chromium: Chromium is a micronutrient, required in very small amounts in the diet. It is involved in the metabolism of carbohydrates and lipids and enhances the action of insulin.

 

Option D. Iodine: Iodine is a micronutrient needed in small quantities. It is crucial for the synthesis of thyroid hormones, which are essential for metabolism and normal growth and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inorganic material mainly required as cofactor for many enzymes. So, they are essential in diet.

 

Classification of Minerals (Based on daily requirements)

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 97

questions.text: During which phase of cardiac cycle is the first heart sound produced? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isovolumetric contraction

 

Isovolumetric contraction is the phase during which the first heart sound (S1) is produced. This sound is primarily due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the start of ventricular contraction, which prevents the backflow of blood into the atria and generates a sound marking the beginning of systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rapid ejection phase: Incorrect because this phase follows the isovolumetric contraction and involves the ejection of blood into the aorta and pulmonary trunk as the ventricles contract further and the pressure exceeds that of the arteries. The valves are already open, and no significant sound is produced akin to S1 during this phase.

 

Option C. Slow ejection phase: Incorrect as this phase represents the tail end of the ejection process where the remaining blood is pushed out of the ventricles at a slower rate due to decreasing pressure gradients. Like the rapid ejection phase, it does not involve the opening or closing of valves that would produce a distinct heart sound.

 

Option D. Isovolumetric relaxation: Incorrect because this phase involves the relaxation of the ventricles without any change in volume, marked by the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves, which produces the second heart sound (S2), not the first

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phases of cardiac cycle -

 

  • Cardiac cycle in ventricles last for 0.8 sec
  • Ventricular Systole - 0.3 sec.  – consist of 3 phases.
  • Ventricular Diastole - 0,5 sec - consist of 5 phases.

 

Phases of ventricular Systole -

 

1st Phase - Starts with closure of Mitral valve, which produces S1 sound. This phase is called as Isovolumetric contraction, it ends by opening of aortic valve.

 

2nd Phase - Phase of Rapid ejection - 2/3rd of the stroke volume is ejected.

 

3rd Phase - Phase of Slow ejection phase: Approximately 1/3rd of the remaining stroke volume is ejected

 

Phases of ventricular Diastole -

 

1st phase (Protodiastole) – which occurs just before the beginning of diastole (last for 0.04 Sec.)

 

2nd Phase - starts with closure of aortic valve, which produces S2 sound which is taken as- beginning of diastole proper. This phase is known as Isovolumetric relaxation.

 

Volume - constant, pressure – decrease

 

3rd Phase - Early Rapid filling phase and 4th Slow filling phase (passive filling of 2/3rd of blood)

 

* S3 sound produce due to rapid filling phase. Normally Can not be heard except few Hyperdynamic condition like: exercise, Pregnancy

 

4. Active filling phase (Remaining 1/3rd of filling due to atrial contraction)

questions.text: A teacher presented with complaints of hoarseness of voice. On examination, bilateral swelling was noted on anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vocal nodule 

 

Clinical history suggests a most probable diagnosis of vocal nodule

 

Vocal Nodules (aka Singer's nodule/Teacher's nodule)

 

Pathogenesis – Trauma → submucosal oedema & hemorrhage → hyalinization & fibrosis

 

Site: appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord (Bilateral) as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma

 

Clinical feature – Hoarseness, Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation are other common symptoms.

 

Treatment - Voice rest, Speech therapy, Micro laryngeal surgery if persistent

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal Polyp is an exophytic lesion with thin mucosa, caused by sudden shouting. Presents with Hoarseness of voice, Diplophonia (double voice).

 

 

Option C. Vocal Cyst are retention cysts occur in false vocal cords.

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema is Diffuse collection of oedema fluid in sub-epithelial space, MC in smokers. On examination, saddle-bag appearance of vocal cords on laryngoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are common in individuals who frequently use their voices intensely, and they require a combination of vocal rest, speech therapy, and possibly surgical intervention to manage effectively and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist conducting a study on dietary habits of families from different religions in urban Delhi. To ensure adequate representation of each religious group, which sampling method should you use? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a method of sampling that involves the division of a population into smaller subgroups known as strata. In stratified random sampling, or stratification, the strata are formed based on members' shared attributes or characteristics

 

  • Sample is drawn from each strata at random, in proportion to its size. 
  • Best method when studying a large random non-homogenous population
  • Gives more representative sample than population compared to other methods like simple random sampling
  • None of the categories is under or over-represented     

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Snowball sampling: Snowball sampling is mainly used for hard-to-reach populations, where one participant refers others, creating a 'snowball' effect. It's typically used for hidden or rare populations, like people with rare diseases like HIV or those involved in illegal activities.

 

Option C. Cluster sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters, and a random sample of clusters is chosen. All or a random sample of members from chosen clusters are then surveyed. It's more about geographic or organizational clustering rather than characteristic clustering (like religion).

 

Option D. Systemic random sampling: In systematic sampling, you select every 'k'th member from a list. It doesn’t guarantee representation from all religious groups unless the list is perfectly ordered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling is the best method to ensure that all subgroups within a diverse population are adequately represented in the study.

questions.text: What is the type of pelvis shown below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gynecoid Pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Given image shows a Gynecoid pelvis.

 

Based on the shape of the inlet female pelvis can be divided into 4 types: Gynecoid (50%) Android (25%) Anthropoid (20%) and platypelloid (5%) (Caldwell-Molloy anatomical classification)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gynecoid pelvis, which is slightly oval or round in the transverse axis, is the most common and ideal type for childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34

questions.text: A homosexual man presented with painful defecation, foul-smelling protruding mass through anus which is non-reducible. Biopsy of the mass shows squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What will be the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiation

 

For a patient diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, the first line of management is chemoradiation (called the Nigro regimen). This approach provides good tumor control, preserves the anal sphincter function, and avoids a permanent colostomy. If chemoradiation fails or if there's a recurrence, surgical interventions like APR might be considered.

 

  • This is a combination treatment modality that uses both chemotherapy and radiation therapy to treat cancer. Chemoradiation is the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. It provides both local control of the tumor and treats potential microscopic disease. The Nigro regimen, combining 5-FU with mitomycin C or cisplatin and external beam radiation, has shown excellent results in treating this cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colostomy: Colostomy might be used as a temporary or permanent measure in cases where the anus or rectum is obstructed or needs to be bypassed. It's not the primary treatment for anal squamous cell carcinoma but may be used in certain situations to manage symptoms or complications.

 

Option C. Excision: While excision could be considered for some tumors, for anal squamous cell carcinoma, simple excision might not offer the best oncological outcomes compared to chemoradiation. Excision alone without addressing potential microscopic disease can lead to recurrence.

 

Option D. Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): This is a surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed. It results in a permanent colostomy. Abdominoperineal resection was historically the treatment for anal cancer. However, with the success of chemoradiation in treating squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, APR is now reserved for those who don't respond to chemoradiation or have recurrent disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is chemoradiation, which preserves anal sphincter function and avoids the need for a permanent colostomy.

choices.text: CT guided biopsy
Sputum for AFB

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. CXR shows a 3 cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT guided biopsy

 

The patient has several risk factors for lung cancer, including being over 40 years old, a significant smoking history, and the presence of a mass larger than 2 cm on the chest X-ray. Given these factors, the likelihood of the mass being malignant is high. A CT guided biopsy is the best next step because it allows for precise sampling of the mass to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: This would be appropriate if the mass were centrally located or if there were signs of endobronchial involvement. However, because the mass is in the upper lobe, CT guided biopsy is preferred.

 

Option C. Sputum cytology: This test can sometimes detect cancer cells in the sputum, but it is less reliable, especially for peripheral lung lesions.

 

Option D. Sputum for AFB: This test is used to detect tuberculosis. Given the patient's history and presentation, tuberculosis is less likely than lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a significant smoking history and a peripheral lung mass larger than 2 cm, a CT guided biopsy is the next best step to diagnose the nature of the mass.

choices.text: Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen
Both option a and b are correct
None of the above is correct

questions.text: What is the reason behind developing breathing difficulty at high altitudes? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen

 

  • The primary reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes is the decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2). At higher elevations, atmospheric pressure is lower, which in turn decreases the PO2. This reduction leads to a lower oxygen saturation of hemoglobin in the blood, a condition known as hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in hemoglobin concentration: Incorrect in this context. Hemoglobin concentration does not necessarily decrease at high altitudes initially; in fact, over time, the body may increase hemoglobin production as an adaptive response to chronic hypoxia.

 

Option C. Both option A and B are correct: Incorrect because only the decrease in PO2 is relevant in the immediate context of acute altitude exposure. Changes in hemoglobin concentration are more of a long-term adaptation.

 

Option D. None of the above is correct: Incorrect as option B accurately describes the reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes.

 

Physiological Adaptations at High Altitudes

 

  1. Increased Ventilation: The body compensates for lower oxygen availability by increasing respiratory rate and depth (hyperventilation) to enhance oxygen uptake.
  2. Increased Red Blood Cell Production: With prolonged exposure to high altitudes, the body increases erythropoietin production, which stimulates the production of red blood cells, increasing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Increased Hemoglobin Affinity for Oxygen: There may be physiological changes leading to an increase in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, helping it to capture more oxygen under conditions of reduced PO2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breathing difficulty at high altitudes is primarily caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to reduced atmospheric pressure, leading to insufficient oxygen availability and hypoxia. This challenges the body to adapt through various physiological mechanisms to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: The structure indicated by the arrow in the image corresponds to the course of which peripheral nerve? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Marked landmark corresponds to ulnar nerve

 

Arrow points toward the medial epicondyle and Ulnar nerve passes below it.

 

The ulnar nerve gives no branches in the arm. It runs distally through the axilla medial to the axillary artery and between it and the vein, continuing distally medial to the brachial artery as far as the midarm. Here it pierces the medial intermuscular septum, inclining medially as it descends anterior to the medial head of triceps to the interval between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon, with the superior ulnar collateral artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve enters the arm lateral to the brachial artery. Near the insertion of coracobrachialis it crosses in front of the artery, descending medial to it to the cubital fossa where it is posterior to the bicipital aponeurosis and anterior to brachialis, separated by the latter from the elbow joint.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: supplies the long head of triceps, and gives rise to the posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm which supplies the skin along the posterior surface of the upper arm. It then spirals obliquely across the back of the humerus, lying posterior to the uppermost fibres of the medial head of triceps which separate the nerve from the bone in the first part of the spiral groove. On reaching the lateral side of the humerus it pierces the lateral intermuscular septum to enter the anterior compartment; it then descends deep in a furrow between brachialis and proximally brachioradialis, then more distally extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the anterior rami (branches) of the spinal nerves C5, C6, and C7. After its origin, the musculocutaneous nerve courses downward through the axilla (armpit) alongside the axillary artery. It then enters the anterior compartment of the arm by piercing through the coracobrachialis muscle. It provide motor innervation to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. These muscles include coracobrachialis and biceps brachii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

 

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

 

Marked structure is Maxillary sinus on a non-contrast CT.

 

The Maxillary sinus is one of the largest of the paranasal sinuses and is located in the maxillary bone under the eyes, bilaterally to the nasal cavity. On imaging, such as a non-contrast CT scan, the maxillary sinus is typically visible as a large, air-filled space below the orbits (eye sockets) and lateral to the nasal cavity.

 

Following images show paranasal sinuses and related structures:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethmoid Sinus: Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • Frontal Sinus: Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.

choices.text: Hyaline membrane disease
Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. CXR showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that leads to thick, sticky mucus production, affecting the lungs and digestive system. The key features in this case are recurrent respiratory infections, thickened sputum, bronchial wall thickening seen on CXR, and steatorrhea since birth.

 

Key Features of Cystic Fibrosis:

 

  • Recurrent Respiratory Infections: Due to thick mucus obstructing airways and predisposing to infections.
  • Thickened Sputum: A hallmark of CF due to mucus gland dysfunction.
  • Bronchial Wall Thickening: Visible on CXR, indicative of chronic respiratory disease.
  • Steatorrhea: Due to pancreatic insufficiency leading to fat malabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline membrane disease: This typically presents in neonates with respiratory distress syndrome, not in a 5-year-old with chronic symptoms.

 

Option C. Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency: This condition can cause emphysema and liver disease, but it does not typically present with steatorrhea or bronchiectasis in early childhood.

 

Option D. Malabsorption syndrome: While this explains steatorrhea, it does not account for the respiratory symptoms and bronchiectasis seen in CF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis should be the first differential diagnosis in children with recurrent respiratory infections, thickened sputum, bronchial wall thickening on CXR, and steatorrhea since birth.

choices.text: It acts as a calcium chelator and reduces the availability of calcium in coagulation pathway
It binds and activates anti-thrombin 3 that accelerates its interaction with thrombin and factor Xa resulting in their degradation
It acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor that leads to inhibition of activation of clotting factors 2,7,9 and 10
It inhibits tissue plasminogen activator resulting in stoppage of conversion of plasminogen to plasmin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding mechanism of action of dicumarol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor that leads to inhibition of activation of clotting factors 2,7,9 and 10
 

The mechanism of action of dicumarol is similar to that of Warfarin. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme - Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR), which is necessary for activation of the clotting factors 2, 7, 9 and 10 by Gamma Carboxylation of their glutamate residues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as a calcium chelator and reduces the availability of calcium in the coagulation pathway: This describes the mechanism of action of EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid), which is used in laboratory settings to prevent blood clotting by chelating calcium, a necessary cofactor in the coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. It binds and activates anti-thrombin 3 that accelerates its interaction with thrombin and factor Xa resulting in their degradation: This describes the mechanism of action of heparin. Heparin enhances the activity of antithrombin III, leading to the inactivation of thrombin and factor Xa, thus preventing clot formation.

 

Option D. It inhibits tissue plasminogen activator resulting in stoppage of conversion of plasminogen to plasmin: This describes the mechanism of action of antifibrinolytic agents such as tranexamic acid or epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA), which inhibit tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and prevent the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis and stabilizing clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicumarol acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor, preventing the activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X by inhibiting the enzyme Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR). This inhibition is crucial for its anticoagulant effect, similar to that of warfarin.

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: A civil engineer in Kerala is designing a wastewater treatment facility for a growing town. He considers implementing an oxidation pond, a natural wastewater treatment system. Which of the following best describes the microbial activity of the oxidation pond? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time.

 

  • Oxidation ponds uses aerobic method during day time and anaerobic during night time.
  • Oxidation pond also known as - waste stabilization pond/redox pond/sewage lagoons
  • Oxidation ponds or sewage lagoons are a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. 
  • These are open shallow pools of around 1-1.5 m depth with an inlet and outlet. 
  • The oxidation ponds have algae, types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight-which helps in aerobic sewage treatment during day time and anaerobic treatment of sewage during night time. 
  • The effluent can be used for land irrigation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxidation ponds utilize aerobic microbial activity during the day and anaerobic activity at night to treat wastewater effectively.

questions.text: Imaging modality of choice for fistula in Ano is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Fistula-in-ano is an abnormal tract that communicates between the inner surface of the anal canal and the outer skin. The main concern with this condition is the recurrence after treatment, making accurate mapping of the fistulous tract essential.

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is the gold standard for imaging fistula-in-ano. It provides high-resolution images that can accurately detail the course, depth, and branches of a fistulous tract. MRI can also differentiate between active and inactive tracts, identify secondary extensions, and help in delineating the relationship of the fistula with the sphincter muscles. This makes it invaluable for both diagnosis and preoperative planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET-CT: PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography) is an imaging modality that is primarily used for detecting and monitoring the progression or regression of cancers.

 

Option C. Sinogram: A sinogram involves injecting contrast into the external opening of a fistula to delineate its course and internal opening on radiographs. While it can provide information about the fistula's course, it may not provide comprehensive information about secondary tracts, the condition of the surrounding tissues, or the relationship with the sphincter muscles.

 

Option D. CT: CT (Computed Tomography) can provide a detailed image of the anatomy and can be used to identify fistula-in-ano. However, it may not be as sensitive or detailed as MRI, especially when it comes to evaluating the small intricacies of the fistula tract or its relationship with the sphincter complex.

 

Fistulae are classified according to Park’s classification.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The imaging modality of choice for evaluating fistula-in-ano is MRI due to its high-resolution imaging capabilities, which provide detailed information about the course, depth, branches of the fistula tract, and its relationship with surrounding structures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has chosen to undergo vasectomy. What advice will you give this patient regarding the use of contraception post-vasectomy? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 – 16 weeks

 

After undergoing a vasectomy, it is important to understand that while the procedure is highly effective at preventing pregnancy, it is not immediately effective. Sperm can still be present in the reproductive system for some time following the surgery. Therefore, it is crucial to use an alternative form of contraception until a follow-up test confirms that there are no longer any viable sperm present. It is estimated that this sterilization technique is effective after about 3 months or 20 ejaculates to empty the stored semen. A semen analysis report confirming azoospermia is essential to confirm this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a vasectomy, alternative contraception should be used until a semen analysis confirms azoospermia, usually around 12-16 weeks post-surgery.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics page 32

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, recently married, visits a local healthcare facility with her husband for family planning counseling. The healthcare provider advises various contraceptive options and takes some details to add to a specific register. This register helps the healthcare workers monitor and provide reproductive health services to eligible couples in the region. At which level of the healthcare system is this "Eligible Couple Register" typically maintained? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subcenter

 

A couple where the female belongs to the reproductive age group of 15-49 years is considered to be an eligible couple.

 

Eligible couple register is maintained at subcenter by health worker female/ ANM.

 

‘Eligible Couple Register’ is a basic document for organizing family planning work. It is regularly updated by ANM/ HW female with the help of ASHA, for the area falling within her jurisdiction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eligible Couple Register is maintained at subcentre, primarily by female health worker/ ANM

questions.text: Which of the following is found only in cytoplasm: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycolysis

 

Explanation

 

Correct Answer. Glycolysis, the process of breaking down glucose to pyruvate, occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm. It is the first major pathway of glucose catabolism and occurs in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Glycolysis is unique among these options as being the only pathway confined to the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCA Cycle: The Tricarboxylic Acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, takes place in the mitochondria, not in the cytoplasm. It is a key metabolic pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, leading to the production of ATP.

 

Option B. Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids: Beta-oxidation, the process of breaking down fatty acids to produce acetyl-CoA, occurs in the mitochondria. In some cells, like liver cells, it can also occur in peroxisomes, but it does not take place in the cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: Although some steps of gluconeogenesis occur in the cytoplasm, it is not exclusive to this compartment. This metabolic pathway, which generates glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates, involves steps that occur in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria (and to a lesser extent, the endoplasmic reticulum).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Generally, all Anabolic Pathways occur in Cytoplasm and all Catabolic Pathways occur in Mitochondria
  • Exception: Two catabolic pathways also occur in cytoplasm.
    1. Glycolysis
    2. Glycogenolysis

 

 However, three processes occur both in cytoplasm and mitochondria.

 

  1. Heme Synthesis 
  2. Urea cycle
  3. Gluconeogenesis

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 139

questions.text: LH surge in the menstrual cycle is because of?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Estradiol

 

  • Estradiol triggers the LH surge in the menstrual cycle. This phenomenon is an example of positive feedback, where an increase in estrogen levels leads to a significant rise in luteinizing hormone (LH) levels. This LH surge is critical for ovulation, occurring about 36 hours before the egg is released from the ovary.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect as FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone), while important for follicle growth, does not directly cause the LH surge.

 

Option C. Progesterone: Incorrect because progesterone levels rise post-ovulation and thus are a consequence of the LH surge rather than its cause.

 

Option D. HCG: Incorrect as human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) is involved post-conception and does not trigger the LH surge in the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LH surge in the menstrual cycle is because of Estradiol

Increase in estrogen is responsible for increase in LH (Positive feedback)

LH surge - 36 hours before ovulation

LH peak - 8-10 hrs’ before ovulation

questions.text: A pediatrician reviews medical records of children aged 6-10 years to determine if there's a higher history of MMR vaccination in children with autism compared to those without. What type of observational study design is this? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Case control study

 

The above given example is that of a case control study, wherein two groups of children are selected- one group with autism and another one without autism. From these two groups, we want to find out the association between the history of MMR vaccination (cause) and autism (effect) by moving in a retrospective/backward direction. In case control study designs, the strength of association is found out by calculating the odds ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Follows a group over time to see how exposures affect outcomes.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Observes a population at a single point in time to find prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Examines population-level data rather than individual-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A case control study compares groups with and without a condition to identify past exposures or risk factors.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female is presenting with the special lesions as shown in the below image. What are these lesions called as?

 (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Comedones

 

Comedones are seen in ACNE VULGARIS.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

• Most common form of acne.

• Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.

• Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.

• Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comedones is identified as small, non-inflamed lesions found in acne, characterized by a plug of sebum and keratin within a hair follicle, presenting as blackheads or whiteheads.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1, 90.10, 90.13, 90.32 & 90.37

choices.text: 26 weeks and 4 weeks after commencing
30 weeks and 8 weeks after commencing

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, recently employed in a textile factory in Ludhiana, Punjab, comes for her first antenatal checkup at 8 weeks of gestation. She inquires about the duration of maternity leave according to the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of India. How long can she expect to be on maternity leave? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 26 weeks and 4 weeks after commencing

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of India, the maternity benefit includes:

 

  • 100% of wages for 26 weeks of leave for delivery.
  • 6 weeks of leave for abortion or loss of the baby.
  • 4 weeks of leave for any medical condition affecting the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Employees State Insurance (ESI)

 

It comes under the Ministry of Labour. It is not applicable for Defence Mining and Railway.

 

People with a monthly wage of less than Rs.21000/month are eligible to get the benefits.

 

The benefits include the following:

 

  • Medical Care
  • Sickness benefit (70% wages for 91 days or 3 months)
    • If extended it becomes (80% of wages for 2 years)
    • Enhanced sickness benefit (100% of the wages for sterilization procedures – 7 days for males and 14 days for females)
  • Disablement benefit is 90% wages depending on temporary or permanent disability.
  • Dependent’s benefit is also 90%
  • Under ESI Funeral expense 15,000 is also given
  • Maternity benefit: 100% of wages × 26 weeks of leave (delivery) or 6 weeks of leave (for abortions/loss of baby) or 4 weeks (for any medical condition affecting the pregnancy)

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, employed as a welder, presents with the following eye symptoms: pain, redness, and excessive tearing. What would be the appropriate next step in managing this condition?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Remove with 26G needle

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient.

 

  • Foreign bodies must be removed as soon as possible.
  • The removal technique depends on the location and nature of the foreign body.
    1. Lying loose in the lower fornix: Evert the lower lid and remove with a clean swab.
    2. The upper lid (sulcus subtarsalis): Evert and double evert with a Desmarres retractor, if required then remove with a clean swab. In case of difficulty, anaesthetize the conjunctival sac.
    3. Embedded in the bulbar conjunctiva: Remove with a foreign body spud or fine forceps under topical anaesthesia. A disposable sterile hypodermic needle may also be used.
    4. The cornea: Remove using the slit lamp or operating microscope. Anaesthetize the eye and hold the lids apart with the first and second fingers of your left hand, pressing slightly backwards so as to steady the globe.
  • First attempt to remove the foreign body by dislodging it with a sterilized spud.
  • If repeated efforts fail, a disposable hypodermic (26 or 27 gauge) needle should be used.
  • The greatest care should be taken not to scrape the epithelium more than is absolutely necessary.
  • In all cases: an antibiotic ointment should be applied and the eye kept bandaged for a day.
  • Particles of stone show a greater tendency than metal to cause infective ulceration, probably because metallic particles are often hot and therefore sterile when they enter the eye.
  • Occasionally, sharp steel and other particles penetrate deep into the cornea without perforating it. The efforts made to remove them may push them deeper or even into the anterior chamber. Special precautions should be taken if such a scenario is suspected.
  • If the particle is magnetizable, magnetic removal should be tried, but it is usually necessary to incise the cornea overlying the foreign body. However, this method may fail, particularly if the particle is small and in case the particle enters the AC, it has to be removed by other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syringing and washing: This is not typically used for embedded foreign bodies and is more appropriate for chemical injuries or superficial debris.

 

Option B. Antibiotics and steroids: While antibiotics are used post-removal to prevent infection, steroids are not the primary treatment for foreign body removal.

 

Option C. Keratoplasty: This is a surgical procedure for corneal transplants and is not indicated for foreign body removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a corneal foreign body, especially in an occupational setting like welding, involves careful removal using a sterile hypodermic needle, followed by the application of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.

questions.text: Identify the parameter seen in all types of shock: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Tissue Perfusion

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a constant feature in all types of shock. Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. Regardless of the type, the hallmark of shock is reduced blood flow to the tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery and nutrient supply to meet the cellular needs, leading to cellular and tissue hypoxia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Temperature: Increased temperature or fever is not seen in all types of shock. It is commonly seen in septic shock due to the systemic inflammatory response to infection.

 

Option B. Increased Pulse Pressure: Increased pulse pressure is not a consistent finding in all types of shock. In fact, pulse pressure often narrows in states like hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock.

 

Option C. Increased Peripheral Resistance: Increased peripheral resistance (SVR) is not present in all types of shock. For example, septic and anaphylactic shock are characterized by decreased SVR due to widespread vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a universal characteristic of all types of shock, leading to inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

questions.text: Identify the stapler in the image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linear stapler

 

The above instrument is a linear stapler.

 

Use: It is used to close the bowel completely or partially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear stapler is used to close the bowel completely or partially, providing a secure and uniform closure in gastrointestinal surgeries.

questions.text: The vasodilator Nitric oxide is synthesized by which amino acid? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L -Arginine

 

Explanation

 

Nitric oxide is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). L-arginine is converted to L-citrulline with the release of NO. This process is crucial for the regulation of vascular tone, as NO is a potent vasodilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is involved in the nitric oxide cycle, it is not the precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, it is a byproduct of NO synthesis from L-arginine. L-citrulline can be recycled back to L-arginine, which can then be used again for NO synthesis.

 

Option C.  Glycine: Glycine is a simple amino acid involved in various metabolic pathways, but it is not the precursor for nitric oxide synthesis. Glycine plays roles in the synthesis of proteins, purines, and other molecules, but not directly in the production of NO.

 

Option D.  Lysine: Lysine, an essential amino acid, is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It plays roles in protein synthesis and other metabolic processes, but NO synthesis specifically requires L-arginine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

questions.text: You are a public health officer in a remote village experiencing a rise in dog bites due to an increase in stray dogs. The local panchayat asks you to teach the villagers essential first aid steps after a dog bite. Which method would you primarily use? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Demonstration

 

Performing the method of washing the wound in front of the villagers will be the best way to teach them. This method is called Demonstration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panel discussion: Best for discussing various viewpoints but not ideal for teaching practical skills.

 

Option B. Flash cards: Useful for quick information and reminders but not as effective for demonstrating practical steps.

 

Option D. Symposium: Suitable for delivering in-depth information and discussions but not for practical demonstrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demonstration is the most effective method for teaching practical first aid steps, such as wound care after a dog bite, especially in settings with limited healthcare access.

questions.text: Which is the most suitable agent for IV regional anesthesia? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lidocaine

 

Lidocaine is the most suitable agent for intravenous (IV) regional anesthesia, commonly known as Bier's block. This technique is typically used for short surgical procedures (less than one hour) on the extremities.

 

Why Lidocaine is Preferred:

 

  • Rapid Onset: Lidocaine acts quickly, which is beneficial for short procedures.
  • Duration: It provides adequate duration of anesthesia for procedures typically performed under IV regional anesthesia.
  • Safety: Lidocaine is less cardiotoxic compared to Bupivacaine, making it safer for this type of anesthesia where high doses are confined to a limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is contraindicated for IV regional anesthesia due to its cardiotoxicity, which can be life-threatening if the tourniquet fails and the drug enters the systemic circulation.

 

Option C. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is less commonly used for IV regional anesthesia compared to Lidocaine, although it can be used in some settings.

 

Option D. Procaine: Procaine is not typically used for IV regional anesthesia due to its slower onset and shorter duration compared to Lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lidocaine is the preferred agent for IV regional anesthesia due to its rapid onset, suitable duration, and safety profile. This technique, known as Bier's block, is commonly used for short procedures on the extremities, requiring careful management to avoid systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VIPoma

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, and Achlorhydria), which is characteristic of a VIPoma. VIPomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to the clinical features described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulinoma: Insulinomas typically present with hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin secretion, not with watery diarrhea or hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: These tumors can be non-functional or present with inhibitory syndrome, which includes hyperglycemia, cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea, but not with watery diarrhea and hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Glucagonoma: These tumors present with hyperglycemia, diabetes, and a characteristic rash known as necrolytic migratory erythema (NME), rather than the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIPomas cause WDHA syndrome, characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female is brought to OPD with the following deformity. What can be inferred from this? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genu Valgum

 

GENU VALGUM

 

  • It is abnormal approximation of knees with abnormally divergent ankles.
  • It can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleolus, when the knees are touching with the patella facing forwards. It is usually < 8 cm.
  • Valgus alignment of lower extremities is normal in child between 2 and 8 years of age (Known as physiological valgus and is maximum between 2 and 4 years).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genu Varum. In Genu Varum (Bow Legs), knees are abnormally divergent (bow-like) and ankles approximated. Bilateral bow legs can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleoli when heels are touching. It should be < 6 cm to label as Genu Varum. Normally, it is 8 cm. The presence of genu varum after 2 years of age can be considered abnormal, as spontaneous resolution of the varus to neutral tibio-femoral alignment by 2 years of age and to adult valgus alignment after 3 years of age is well documented. The causes are similar to genu valgum except that the defective growth is on the medial side. The causes are physiological genu varum (most commonly), tibia vara (growth retardation at the medial aspect of proximal tibial epiphysis & physis). It is treated surgically by overcorrection of mechanical axis to at least 5 degrees valgus, with lateral translation of distal osteotomy fragment, by 4 years of age. High tibial osteotomy just distal to patellar tendon insertion with fibular osteotomy in proximal third diaphysis is recommended.

 

 

Option C. Wind swept deformity means one knee has a valgus deformity and the other knee has a varus deformity. It is classically used for knee deformity of rickets. It is seen in rickets, hereditary dysplasia (epiphyseal dysplasia) of bone and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Option D. Genu recurvatum means hyperextension at the knee joint. Polio is the commonest cause. It is commonly seen in trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, rickets, charcots. It can also be congenital due to intrauterine positioning, which is self-resolving. It is also a common presentation in congenital dislocation of the knee. In children of less than 3 years of age, its most common cause is Blount’s disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given question describes the genu valgum deformity (also called as knock knees). It is the abnormal approximation of the knees with abnormally divergent ankles.

questions.text: In PALS ABCDE all pairs are matched correctly except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D for dehydration

 

All pairs are correctly matched except D for dehydration.

 

Here it Should be D for disability

 

In Pediatric Basic and Advanced Life Support (PALS) mnemonic “ABCDE” stands for as follow -

 

A - Airway

B - Breathing

C - Circulation

D - Disability

E - Exposure

 

First, life-threatening airway problems are assessed and treated; second, life-threatening breathing problems are assessed and treated; and so on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PALS, the "D" in the ABCDE mnemonic stands for Disability, which involves assessing the child’s neurological status.

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance
Creatinine is equal to inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Creatinine clearance? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance

 

  • Creatinine clearance is often used as a measure of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) but it is important to note that it slightly overestimates GFR. This overestimation is because creatinine is not only filtered by the glomerulus but also secreted in small amounts by the renal tubules. Therefore, creatinine clearance is typically greater than inulin clearance.
  • Inulin clearance, on the other hand, is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR. Inulin is a polysaccharide that is freely filtered by the kidneys but neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Thus, it provides an accurate measure of the filtration capacity of the kidneys.

 

Clinical Relevance

 

  • Inulin clearance is an accurate measure but is seldom used in clinical practice due to the complexity and cost of the procedure.
  • Creatinine clearance, despite its limitations, is commonly used because it is simpler and cheaper to measure. It requires only serum and urine creatinine levels, making it practical for routine medical evaluations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance: Incorrect because creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR due to additional renal tubular secretion.

 

Option C. Creatinine clearance is equal to inulin clearance: Incorrect because the secretion of creatinine leads to higher clearance values compared to inulin.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as option B correctly describes the relationship between creatinine and inulin clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine clearance is commonly used to estimate GFR but it is greater than inulin clearance due to slight secretion of creatinine by the renal tubules. In contrast, inulin clearance, being neither secreted nor reabsorbed, provides a more accurate measurement of renal filtration function.

questions.text: A female presents with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Rinne’s test reveals conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, a red and bulgy mass behind the intact tympanic membrane is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glomus tumor

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tumor

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Typically presents with an effusion in the middle ear without signs of infection, leading to a dull or amber appearance of the tympanic membrane rather than a red mass.

 

Option C. Chronic otitis media: Characterized by persistent ear infections and can include a perforated tympanic membrane or cholesteatoma, not typically presenting as a red mass.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Affects the ossicles, particularly the stapes, and leads to conductive hearing loss. It does not present as a visible mass in the ear canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a red, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a glomus tympanicum tumor, requiring detailed imaging for confirmation and planning of appropriate intervention strategies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog. She had received post-exposure prophylaxis for a monkey bite two months ago. What is the appropriate management for her current rabies exposure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Wound care + IM vaccine 0,3

 

As patient has already received post-exposure prophylaxis for monkey bite, she should receive Re-exposure prophylaxis in the form of 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 along with wound care.

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP)

 

Wound Care - Immediate care 

 

Thorough washing and flushing of the wound for approximately 15 minutes, with soap or detergent and copious amounts of water, is required; Where available, an iodine-containing, or similarly viricidal, topical preparation should be applied to the wound

 

WHO Rabies Exposure Categories

 

  • Category I: Touching or feeding animals, animal licks on intact skin (no exposure)
  • Category II: Nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding (exposure)
  • Category III: Single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, contamination of mucous membrane or broken skin with saliva from animal licks, exposures due to direct contact with bats (severe exposure)

 

PEP Recommendations

 

 

Additional Information

 

Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) Administration

 

  • There are 2 types of RIG available for passive immunisation: human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG) and equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG). Both hRIG and eRIG are equally effective and safe. But eRIG is less costly than hRIG
  • Maximum dose: 20 IU (hRIG) and 40 IU (eRIG) per kg body weight
  • Given only once, as soon as possible and not beyond Day 7 after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Infiltrate as much as possible into the wound; the remainder of the calculated dose of RIG does not need to be injected IM at a distance from the wound but can be fractionated in smaller, individual syringes to be used for other patients, aseptic retention given.
  • If RIG is not available, thorough, prompt wound washing, together with immediate administration of the first vaccine dose, followed by a complete course of rabies vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld, regardless of the availability of RIG
  • If a limited amount of RIG is available, RIG allocation should be prioritized for exposed patients based on the following criteria: 
    • Multiple bites 
    • Deep wounds
    • Bites to highly innervated parts of the body (such as head, neck and hands)
    • Severe immunodeficiency
    • Biting animal is a confirmed or probable rabies case. 
    • Bites, scratches or exposures of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For individuals with a recent history of rabies vaccination (within the past three months), re-exposure prophylaxis includes wound care and two doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was brought to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing since 2 hours. A radiograph was done as shown below. What will be the next step to manage the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Esophagoscopy

 

A round metallic foreign body lies in the midline just above the aortic knob, suggestive of a foreign body within the esophagus, the coin exceeds the diameter of the trachea. Also, both lung fields appear clear.  

 

A PA and lateral view X-ray of chest and abdomen should be done.

 

Treatment – Removal of foreign body by esophagoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: Used if there is suspicion that the foreign body might have entered the respiratory tract. In this scenario, the foreign body is in the esophagus, not the trachea.

 

Option B. Tracheostomy: Not appropriate in this case as there is no indication of airway compromise that cannot be managed by less invasive means.

 

Option D. Heimlich’s Maneuver: This is used for choking due to an airway obstruction, not for foreign bodies lodged in the esophagus. It's inappropriate and could potentially cause harm by forcing the object into a more problematic position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected esophageal foreign bodies in children, esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both confirmation and removal of the object. It ensures that the foreign body is safely and effectively retrieved while minimizing risk to the patient.

questions.text: The following image is caused by infection with which virus? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CMV

 

The given image shows owl's eye inclusion bodies (intranuclear basophilic inclusions) which is characteristically seen in CMV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are characterized by koilocytes, which have a perinuclear halo and wrinkled nuclei. They do not show owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) does not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies. HIV is typically diagnosed with serological tests and does not produce specific histopathological features like CMV.

 

Option D. EBV: Incorrect. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections are associated with atypical lymphocytes, also known as Downey cells. They do not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl's eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusions, are characteristic of CMV infection. This feature helps distinguish CMV from other viral infections in histopathological examinations.

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

 

Retrocaval ureter is a rare congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava (IVC) and gets compressed, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis. This condition does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis because it only affects the right ureter.

 

Retrocaval ureter, also known as circumcaval ureter, is a condition where the right ureter passes behind the IVC, causing compression and right-sided hydronephrosis, but it does not affect the left ureter, thus not leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phimosis: Phimosis, a condition where the foreskin cannot be fully retracted over the glans penis, can lead to urinary retention and subsequent bilateral hydronephrosis if severe and left untreated.

 

Option B. Urethral Stricture: A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra which can obstruct urine flow and cause bilateral hydronephrosis if the obstruction is significant and near the bladder neck or urethra.

 

Option C. Posterior urethral valve: Posterior urethral valves are congenital obstructive membranes in the posterior male urethra. They cause significant obstruction, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retrocaval ureter is a condition that affects only the right ureter, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A nulliparous woman presented with 26 weeks of gestation for routine antenatal check-up. Her blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. What can be the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine dipstick

 

  • A pregnant woman with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation should be evaluated for gestational hypertension or Pre-eclampsia.
  • So, the next step should be looking out for proteinuria by Urine dipstick test.  (Here Proteinuria refers to urine dipstick greater than or equal to +2 (1 gm/L) on at least two random clean catch samples   or a  total 24 hour urine protein > 0.3 gm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Uric Acid: Blood changes in pre-eclampsia may not be very specific however a serum Uric acid of more than 4.5 mg/dl may be considered as a biochemical marker

 

Option B. Liver Function tests and Option C. Complete blood count: LFTs may be raised and there may altered coagulation profile and thrombocytopenia

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation, the next best step is to evaluate for proteinuria using a urine dipstick test to screen for pre-eclampsia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics page 256, 262

questions.text: Which of the following listed minerals is not typically classified as a trace nutrient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Calcium

 

  • Carbohydrates, fats and proteins are Macronutrients (Proximate principles).  
  • Micronutrients include Calcium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Sodium, Potassium, Iron, Zinc and Vitamins.
  • Trace nutrients include iron, manganese, copper, iodine, zinc, cobalt, fluoride and selenium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium is a macronutrient, needed in larger amounts. Selenium, iodine, and copper are trace nutrients, required in smaller quantities.

questions.text: Which of the following situations is not managed by using Ventouse for a delivery? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premature baby

 

Explanation:

 

Ventouse assisted delivery can cause Intracranial hemorrhage in a preterm fetus

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged second stage: Ventouse is commonly indicated for prolonged second stage of labor to assist in the delivery process.

 

Option B. Maternal Exhaustion: Maternal exhaustion is another indication for operative vaginal delivery using either forceps or ventouse to expedite delivery and reduce maternal strain.

 

Option C. Fetal Distress: Fetal distress is an indication for immediate delivery, and ventouse can be used to quickly assist in the delivery when immediate intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventouse-assisted delivery is contraindicated in premature babies due to the risk of intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Ref: D.C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 652,661

questions.text: A patient of colorectal cancer was treated with folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil and irinotecan therapy. He developed diarrhea following the regimen. Which of the following drug can be used for treatment of chemotherapy related diarrhea in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loperamide
 

Loperamide drug can be used for treatment of chemotherapy related diarrhea in this patient.


Loperamide is an opioid agonist it can be used for the treatment of chemotherapy induced diarrhea. It acts by reducing the motility of the intestine as well as decreasing the intestinal secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: It is added to loperamide like opioids to prevent the abuse potential.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin: it is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic which is effective in controlling bacillary diarrhea. Antibiotics play no role in treatment of post-chemotherapy diarrhea.

 

Option D. Metronidazole: It is an antibiotic which is effective against gram negative anerobes and parasitic infections. It is used in bacillary dysentery but not in post-chemotherapy diarhhea.


Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of chemotherapy-induced diarrhea, particularly following regimens that include drugs like irinotecan, loperamide is the appropriate choice. Loperamide effectively reduces intestinal motility and secretions, helping to control and reduce diarrhea. Other medications such as ciprofloxacin and metronidazole are used for infectious causes of diarrhea and are not suitable for chemotherapy-induced cases.

questions.text: A biopsy was taken from the lymph node. What is name of the cell found in the lymph node? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RS cell

 

In the given image Reed-Sternberg cells are seen, which is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker -

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

RS cells are large and either multi-nucleated or have a bilobed nucleus which resemble as "owl's eye"

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes that are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). There are four main types of HL, each with a different pattern of RS cell morphology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mott cell: These are plasma cells containing multiple globules of immunoglobulin and are not associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Popcorn cell: This is a variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL, not the classic type shown in the image.

 

Option D. Plasma cell: These are antibody-producing cells derived from B-lymphocytes, not the characteristic cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, identifiable by their "owl's eye" appearance, are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma and can be identified using markers like CD15, CD30, and PAX-5.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best test to arrive at a definitive diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sestamibi scan

 

The patient's symptoms of bone pain, abdominal cramps, and a history of abnormal behavior are indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. This condition is often described by the phrase "stones, bones, groans, and moans," referring to kidney stones, bone pain, abdominal symptoms, and psychological manifestations, respectively.
