Primary hyperparathyroidism is most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia. To localize the abnormal parathyroid gland(s), the Sestamibi scan is the best diagnostic test. This nuclear medicine scan uses a radiotracer that is absorbed by overactive parathyroid tissue, allowing for accurate localization.

 

Technetium-99m scan but, Sestamibi scan is better

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While useful for imaging soft tissues, it is not the best choice for localizing hyperparathyroid tissue.

 

Option B. Ultrasonogram: Can help in identifying enlarged parathyroid glands but is less sensitive and specific compared to the Sestamibi scan.

 

Option D. CT scan: Useful for detailed imaging of various structures but not the best for identifying hyperparathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sestamibi scan is the best diagnostic test for localizing abnormal parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Cherry red color staining is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbon monoxide

 

Cherry red color staining is due to Carbon monoxide poisoning. This distinctive color is due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) in the blood, which has a bright red color.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Causes dark brown or yellow post mortem staining.

 

Option B. Cyanide (HCN): Causes bright red post mortem staining.

 

Option C. H₂S (Hydrogen Sulphide): Causes bluish green post mortem staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

(In Aniline Deep blue as well as Red Brown colour can occur)

 

Ref: Simpson’s Forensic Medicine, 13th edition, page 45

 

Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 83.

choices.text: CT pulmonary angiogram

questions.text: An elderly male on bed rest for many months presented with breathlessness and chest pain. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT pulmonary angiogram

 

The patient has a history of prolonged immobilization and presents with symptoms of breathlessness and pleuritic chest pain, which are suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). Prolonged bed rest is a significant risk factor for PE due to venous stasis and the potential for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) to embolize to the lungs.

 

A CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard diagnostic test for acute pulmonary embolism. It provides a detailed image of the pulmonary arteries and can identify the presence of emboli.

 

Screening test – D-dimer

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECG: While an ECG can be performed to check for any cardiac abnormalities, the most common finding in PE is sinus tachycardia, which is not specific. It will not confirm the diagnosis of PE.

 

Option C. CT thorax: A CT thorax without angiogram will not provide the necessary details to diagnose PE.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography can show right ventricular dysfunction, which may suggest PE, but it is not definitive for diagnosing PE. It is more useful for assessing the cardiac impact of an established PE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard investigation for confirming pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Mucormycosis can be caused by following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection. This invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue and even into orbit and then cranium, black eschars are formed.

 

It can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and anti-fungal (Amphotericin-B) medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutropenia: This condition involves a lowered count of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that helps prevent and fight infections, making the body more vulnerable to fungal infections.

 

Option B. Uncontrolled Diabetes: High blood sugar levels can impair neutrophil function, making diabetics particularly susceptible to fungal infections like mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Prolonged or High-Dose Corticosteroid Therapy: Steroids suppress the immune system and reduce the body's ability to fight off fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk factors for mucormycosis are:

 

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • Post - organ transplantation
  • Neutropenia
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Prolonged hospitalization
  • Immunodeficiency

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to hospital with pain in great toe. His serum uric acid was raised. He was given a medication to relieve the pain and inflammation and after that, he was put on a drug for long term treatment of gout. Which of the following drug increases the excretion of uric acid in urine? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Probenecid

 

  • Probenecid increases the excretion of uric acid in urine by inhibiting the tubular reabsorption of uric acid. It is a uricosuric drug.

  • Examples of other uricosuric drugs are Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone and Lesinurad.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colchicine: Colchicine is used primarily for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It works by inhibiting granulocyte migration and reducing inflammation, but it does not increase the excretion of uric acid.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, similar to allopurinol. It reduces the production of uric acid by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Probenecid is a uricosuric drug that increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine by inhibiting its reabsorption in the renal tubules. This makes it effective for the long-term management of gout by lowering serum uric acid levels. Other drugs like colchicine, allopurinol, and febuxostat have different mechanisms of action and do not increase uric acid excretion in the urine.

choices.text: Proximal and Lateral displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius
Proximal and Lateral displacement of ulna
Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of fall on an outstretched hand presented in OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the right wrist. On examination, you observe a dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the correct statement regarding this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius

 

  • Dinner fork deformity is a finding in Colle’s Fracture, in which Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius is seen.

 

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • It is the fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, most commonly occurring in the post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly females, as a result of fall on outstretched hand with wrist in extension.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.
  • 6 components of colle’s:
    • Dorsal tilt
    • Dorsal displacement
    • Impaction
    • Lateral tilt
    • Lateral displacement
    • Supination
  • Most of these fractures are successfully treated non-operatively with a cast applied in pronation, palmar angulation, and ulnar deviation – also called as Hand shaking cast.

 

 

  • If prolonged immobilization is required in extreme position, or if reduction is lost early in treatment, then closed reduction followed by percutaneous K-wire fixation is done.

 

 

 

  • Complications includes:
    • Joint stiffness: finger stiffness is most common
    • Malunion is the 2nd most complication, leading to dinner fork deformity
    • Sudeck’s osteodystrophy
    • Extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome
    • Carpal instability
    • TFCC injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal and lateral displacement of radius. This is called as Smith’s fracture. It is the reverse of colle’s fracture, where there is proximal and ventral/lateral displacement of the radius. It is treated by closed reduction and immobilization in an above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dinner fork deformity is commonly seen in the colle’s fracture, which is the proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius after a fall on the outstretched hand. It is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures, this instrument is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometrial Sampling

 

Explanation:

 

Given image is for Pipelle aspirator, used to obtain endometrial sample for biopsy.

 

Endometrial aspiration is an OPD procedure, it doesn’t require cervical dilation. It’s painless, but it is a blind procedure, so tissue can be missed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilatation and curettage: It may be diagnostic or therapeutic. It involves mechanical dilatation using metallic dilators such as Hegars followed by curettage of the cavity using a curette.

 

Option B. Cervical sampling:  It may be used for screening or for cytohormonal study.  Ayres spatula made of wood or plastic may be used for collection of material from the Squamo-columnar junction. Endocervical sampling can be performed using a cytobrush or with a moist tip applicator. A cervical biopsy is used for confirmation of diagnosis.

 

Option D. Hysterosalpingography: It is a radiological procedure using contrast to assess tubal patency and tubal and uterine anatomy using sequential x-rays. Either water soluble dye diatrizoate (renografin 60) or low viscosity oil-based dye ethiodized oil (ethiodol) may be introduced slowly (5-10 ml) using an HSG cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pipelle aspirator is used to obtain endometrial sample for biopsy

 

Ref: D. C. Dutta’s Textbook of gynaecology 6th Edition page 120, 604, 110

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection that commonly affects immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV. The standard first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis involves an induction therapy phase, typically with a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days. This regimen is effective in reducing the fungal burden and improving outcomes in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: This antibiotic is used primarily for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Gram-positive bacteria. It is not effective against fungal infections such as cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is generally used after the initial induction phase with amphotericin B and flucytosine. High dose fluconazole can be part of the consolidation or maintenance therapy.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: This antifungal is primarily used for infections caused by Aspergillus species and is not the preferred treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients, the first-line induction therapy is a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness and anemia, on examination the child is hypoglycemic and no focal neurological deficit is noted, what will be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebral malaria


The clinical presentation described—sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness, anemia, and hypoglycemia—is highly suggestive of cerebral malaria. Cerebral malaria is a severe and potentially fatal complication of infection with Plasmodium falciparum, the most dangerous of the malaria-causing parasites.

 

  • High fever and loss of consciousness: These are hallmark symptoms of cerebral malaria, reflecting the severe systemic response and potential brain involvement by the parasite.
  • Anemia: Anemia is common in malaria due to hemolysis of infected red blood cells.
  • Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is a frequent complication in severe malaria, often exacerbated by the parasite's metabolism of glucose and the body's increased demand during fever and illness.
  • Absence of focal neurological deficits: This aligns with cerebral malaria, which typically presents with diffuse neurological symptoms rather than focal deficits.

 

Durck's granuloma is a pathological finding in cerebral malaria, characterized by localized areas of necrosis surrounded by a granulomatous reaction in the brain.

 

Durck granuloma seen in cerebral malaria: -

 

 

Treatment: Severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours, followed by a complete course of an effective oral antimalarial regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB meningitis: TB meningitis would typically present with chronic symptoms, such as a gradual onset of headache, fever, and neurological signs, along with CSF analysis showing low sugar, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance. The sudden onset and the specific symptoms described are more indicative of cerebral malaria.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis: While viral meningitis can present with fever and altered consciousness, it is generally less severe and does not typically cause the severe hypoglycemia and anemia seen in cerebral malaria.

 

Option D. Fungal meningitis: Fungal meningitis, such as cryptococcal meningitis, typically presents with more indolent symptoms, including headache, fever, and possibly altered mental status, but it is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals and lacks the acute, severe presentation described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Cerebral malaria is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection, characterized by sudden onset of high-grade fever, loss of consciousness, anemia, and hypoglycemia, without focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Why Hereditary Spherocytosis is Correct: Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition characterized by the presence of spherical red blood cells that are prone to hemolysis. The spleen plays a significant role in the destruction of these abnormal red blood cells. Splenectomy is the treatment of choice for hereditary spherocytosis because it reduces hemolysis and anemia, leading to an improvement in the patient’s quality of life. It is typically recommended for patients with severe hemolysis or those who are transfusion-dependent.

 

  • Most Common Defect: The most common defect in hereditary spherocytosis is in the ankyrin protein.
  • Diagnostic Test: The investigation of choice for confirming hereditary spherocytosis is flow cytometry with eosin-5-maleimide. Historically, the osmotic fragility test was used.
  • Timing of Splenectomy: Splenectomy is generally performed after the age of 6 years and is indicated in patients with transfusion dependency anemia (majorly), severe anemia or growth retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G6PD deficiency: G6PD deficiency causes hemolysis primarily due to oxidative stress. Splenectomy is not beneficial because the spleen is not the primary site of red cell destruction in this condition.

 

Option B. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH involves intravascular hemolysis due to a defect in the red cell membrane. Splenectomy is not useful as the spleen is not involved in the hemolytic process.

 

Option D. Hairy cell leukemia: While splenectomy can sometimes be part of the management for symptomatic splenomegaly in hairy cell leukemia, it is not typically the first-line treatment. The primary treatment involves chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective splenectomy is indicated in hereditary spherocytosis to decrease hemolysis and improve symptoms, particularly in patients with severe anemia or those who require frequent blood transfusions.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DC shock

 

The patient presents with atrial fibrillation (AF) characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of well-defined P waves on the ECG. His vital signs indicate hemodynamic instability, specifically a low systolic blood pressure of 84 mm Hg (<90 mm HG).

 

Why DC Shock is Correct: DC shock (synchronized cardioversion) is indicated for patients with tachyarrhythmia who are hemodynamically unstable. Hemodynamic instability is evidenced by a systolic blood pressure below 90 mm Hg, which is a critical threshold indicating the need for immediate cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and improve cardiac output.

 

Steps for Decision Making:

 

  1. Identify the Rhythm: The ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
  2. Assess Stability: The patient's systolic blood pressure is 84 mm Hg, indicating instability.
  3. Treatment Protocol: Immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is necessary for unstable tachyarrhythmias.

 

Note - The three contraindications for using synchronized DC cardioversion are:

 

  1. Sinus tachycardia
  2. Multifocal atrial tachycardia
  3. Digitalis toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is used for anticoagulation in AF to prevent thromboembolism. However, it does not address hemodynamic instability or the immediate need to correct the arrhythmia.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used for rate control in stable AF. They are inappropriate for acute management in hemodynamically unstable patients because they can further lower blood pressure and worsen instability.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used to convert AF to sinus rhythm, but it is not the first-line treatment in an unstable patient. Immediate cardioversion is preferred in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (e.g., systolic BP < 90 mm Hg), immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is the treatment of choice.

 

Rule of thumb: "If the patient is in shock, shock the patient."

questions.text: A 60-year-old shipyard worker presents with increasing shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough over the past year. He has worked with insulation materials for 35 years. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. A chest X-ray reveals a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with these findings? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asbestosis

 

Ground glass appearance on chest x ray is seen in asbestosis. In silicosis, on chest X-ray we get Nodular fibrosis and snow storm appearance.

 

Asbestosis

 

  • Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs due to: Exposure to asbestos dust. Asbestosis does not usually appear until after 5-10 years of exposure
  • Sputum shows ‘asbestos bodies’, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • Asbestos may lead to pulmonary fibrosis, carcinoma of bronchus, mesothelioma of peritoneum/ pleura and cancer of GIT.
  • Asbestos type most dangerous is ‘amphibole’.

 

Other Options: 

 

 

Bagassosis: An allergic response to the inhalation of moldy bagasse, which is sugarcane fiber residue. Bagasse dust blocks bronchioles thus leading to bronchitis and bronchopneumonia. It has been shown to be due to Thermoactinomyces sacchari. Prevention and Bagasse control measures are Keeping the moisture content > 20% and Spraying bagasse with 2% propionic acid (fungicide). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with a "ground glass" appearance on chest X-ray and occurs in workers exposed to asbestos over long periods.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is presenting with a mucous discharge involving his orbital cavity was found to be spreading from nasal cavity with. Blackish discoloration what is the organism responsible? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic invasive fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, including species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. This infection is particularly dangerous for immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes, especially if it is poorly controlled.

 

Key characteristics of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Blackish discoloration of affected tissues
  • Involvement of the nasal cavity and orbital region
  • Rapid progression
  • High mortality rate if not treated promptly

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Diabetes (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Immunocompromised states (e.g., neutropenia, organ transplantation, hematologic malignancies)
  • Prolonged corticosteroid use

 

Treatment:

 

  • The drug of choice (DOC) for mucormycosis is Amphotericin B.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue is often necessary.
  • Control of underlying conditions (e.g., diabetes) is critical to improving outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Incorrect. Histoplasmosis is typically caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a fungus that primarily affects the lungs. It does not usually present with blackish discoloration or involve the orbital cavity.

 

Option C. Aspergillosis: Incorrect. Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, can affect the sinuses and lungs but is less likely to cause the extensive blackish necrosis seen in mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are bacteria that can cause various infections but do not present with the black necrotic tissue characteristic of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients, can lead to black necrotic lesions and rapid spread from the nasal cavity to the orbital region. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with Amphotericin B and surgical debridement are essential.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with CA cervix. Investigations revealed a lesion of 3.5 cm. What can the appropriate management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 3 hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has CA cervix Stage 1B2 and the management will be Type 3 / Radical hysterectomy.

 

FIGO Revised staging of cervical cancer (2018)

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Type 1: Simple extra fascial hysterectomy

 

Type 2: Modified radical hysterectomy

 

Type3: Radical Hysterectomy

 

Type4: Extended Radical hysterectomy

 

Type 5: Partial Exenteration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 hysterectomy (Simple extra fascial hysterectomy): Suitable for Stage 1A1 (without lymph-vascular space invasion - LVSI) or conization.

 

Option B. Type 2 hysterectomy (Modified radical hysterectomy): Suitable for Stage 1A1 (with LVSI) and Stage 1A2.

 

Option D. Type 4 hysterectomy (Extended radical hysterectomy): Typically used for more advanced stages or extensive disease beyond Stage 1B2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cervical cancer staging, a lesion size between 2 to 4 cm (Stage 1B2) is best managed with a Type 3 (Radical) hysterectomy.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynaecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology 8th edition page367

questions.text: Choose the best option to define a post-term neonate: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Born after 42 weeks of gestation

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Based on the above table

 

Option A. Born after 37 weeks of gestation:  early term (37 to 38 6/7  )

 

Option B. Born after 40 weeks of gestation: Late term between 41 to 41 6/7 and  Full term: between 39 to 40 6/7  and

 

Option D. Born between 37 – 40 weeks of gestation: Term pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-term neonates are those who are born after 42 weeks / 294 days of gestation.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter on preterm labor

questions.text: Which stain is commonly used to differentiate the infarcted portion from the normal portion of the heart in a deceased patient who died due to myocardial infarction (MI)? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triphenyl Tetrazolium chloride

 

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain used to differentiate the infarct portion to the normal portion of heart following image is showing triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain where BRICK RED colour is showing normal tissue and PALE color is showing MI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylene blue: This stain is commonly used for highlighting various cell structures but is not specific for differentiating infarcted myocardial tissue.

 

Option C. Congo red: This stain is used to identify amyloid deposits in tissues, not for myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Oil red O: This is a fat-soluble dye used to stain lipids in tissues, not specific for myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain is used to differentiate infarcted myocardial tissue from normal tissue, with normal tissue appearing brick red and infarcted tissue appearing pale.

questions.text: Identify the most important risk factor for acute mastitis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cracked nipple
 

The most important risk factor for acute mastitis is the presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples. These openings provide a direct entry point for bacteria, primarily Staphylococcus aureus, which commonly inhabits the oropharynx of the nursing infant. This condition often arises during the first month of breastfeeding when the nipples are most vulnerable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Massage: While massage can sometimes be recommended to alleviate symptoms of engorgement or blocked ducts, improper or overly vigorous massage is not a significant risk factor for developing acute mastitis.

 

Option B. Breast engorgement: Breast engorgement can lead to blocked ducts and potentially contribute to mastitis if milk is not effectively removed, but it is not the most important risk factor compared to cracked nipples.

 

Option C. Lactation failure: Lactation failure can cause issues such as milk stasis and engorgement, which might predispose to infection. However, it is not as direct a risk factor as cracked nipples, which provide a clear pathway for bacterial entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples is the most important risk factor for acute mastitis due to the direct pathway it provides for bacterial entry.

questions.text: During management of a labor in case of shoulder dystocia, a maneuver was done as shown below. This maneuver is known as? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleidotomy

 

Explanation:

 

Cleidotomy is intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.

 

The table below enlists the manoeuvres used in the management of shoulder dystocia including the options A B C D

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cleidotomy is an intentional fetal clavicular fracture performed to reduce the shoulder girdle diameter in cases of shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition Page 469-470

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty and a whole-body CT scan has to be done. This CT scan will include the following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CT Limbs

 

Whole body CT scan in context of trauma includes:

 

  • NCCT Head and C-spine
  • CECT Chest
  • CECT Abdomen

 

Limb injuries can be assessed by physical examination. Imaging is done in specific cases only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A whole-body CT scan for trauma includes NCCT of the head and C-spine, and CECT of the chest and abdomen, while limb injuries are typically evaluated through physical examination and imaged only when necessary.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane and in the external auditory meatus, accompanied by features of facial nerve palsy. What is the diagnosis and which site is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

 

Clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay hunt syndrome (aka herpes zoster oticus).

 

Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay–Hunt Syndrome) - It is a viral infection (herpes zoster virus) involving geniculate ganglion of facial nerve. It is characterized by appearance of vesicles on the tympanic membrane, deep meatus, concha and retro auricular sulcus.

 

It appears as a rash of small tense blisters with surrounding erythema, preceded by pain in the ears for several days

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome and Basal Ganglion: Incorrect because Ramsay Hunt syndrome affects the geniculate ganglion, not the basal ganglion.

 

Option C. & D. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent facial nerve paralysis, swelling of the lips (cheilitis granulomatosa), and a fissured tongue. It does not involve vesicular eruptions and primarily affects the facial appearance and function without vesicular rash. Paralysis may be recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a characteristic vesicular eruption on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Early recognition and treatment are vital to prevent complications and improve recovery.

questions.text: Study of all aspects of death is called as: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thanatology

 

Thanatology is the scientific study of death, dying, and the processes surrounding them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traumatology: The study of injuries and wounds, including their medical treatment and repair.

 

Option C. Toxicology: The study of the adverse effects of chemicals on living organisms, especially the poisoning effects of drugs and chemicals.

 

Option D. Epidemiology: The study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specific populations and the application of this study to control health problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thanatology is the field that comprehensively studies death and the various aspects associated with it.

questions.text: A patient’s higher mental functions were being assessed by a psychiatrist. He was asked to serially subtract 7 from 100. Which mental function is being assessed? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concentration

 

Serial Seven Subtraction Test is used to assess concentration and immediate memory.

 

Concentration is the ability to sustain attention for a longer duration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Judgement: Incorrect, as judgement involves decision-making and reasoning about complex matters, which is not directly assessed by simple arithmetic tasks.

 

Option C. Orientation: Incorrect, orientation refers to awareness of time, place, and person, which is not relevant to the serial subtraction task.

 

Option D. Attention: Incorrect, although attention is required for this task, the specific function being tested is concentration, which is a sustained form of attention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concentration, the ability to maintain attention on a task over a period of time, is assessed through the Serial Seven Subtraction Test in mental function evaluations.

questions.text: A newborn is presenting with history of continuous drooling of saliva and frothiness in mouth, it is also associated with respiratory distress, the X ray of the child reveals the following image, what will be probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracheoesophageal fistula

 

The current clinical situation points to a tracheoesophageal fistula. An X-ray revealing a nasogastric (NG) tube in the proximal esophagus and a stomach bloated with gas are suggestive of esophageal atresia given the symptoms of frothiness and respiratory distress.

 

An improper connection between the esophagus and the trachea is known as a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is often divided into five categories, which are as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient tachypnea of newborn: Important points are: term baby born through cesarian section with tachypnea which gets settled by itself by 48-72 hours.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic eversion: Diaphragm eventration is the permanent elevation of a hemidiaphragm and can be due to congenital or acquired causes. Diaphragm eventration can become a serious condition resulting in severe respiratory distress and death if left untreated.

 

Option D. Hyaline membrane disease: Baby should be a preterm with severe distress with x ray showing white out lung.

 

Educational Objective:


A newborn with continuous drooling, frothiness in the mouth, and respiratory distress, along with an X-ray showing a coiled NG tube and gas in the stomach, is likely to have a tracheoesophageal fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Why Rheumatoid Arthritis is Correct: Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory condition that can lead to the accumulation of exudative pleural effusion. Exudative effusions are characterized by high protein content and cellular debris resulting from increased capillary permeability typically due to inflammation or injury to the pleural membranes.

 

The diagnosis of an exudative pleural effusion is confirmed using Light's criteria, which states that a pleural effusion is exudative if at least one of the following is true:

 

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal serum LDH

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart failure: Heart failure typically causes a transudative pleural effusion, which results from increased hydrostatic pressure or decreased oncotic pressure without inflammation. The pleural fluid in transudative effusions has low protein content and is generally less cellular.

 

Heart failure is currently the most common cause of pleural effusion (MC cause of transudative pleural effusion).

 

Option B. Liver failure: Liver failure leads to a transudative pleural effusion due to the accumulation of fluid in the abdomen (ascites) that moves into the pleural space, also known as hepatic hydrothorax. This is due to the RAS-activated state causing low protein content in the effusion.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome causes a transudative pleural effusion. The loss of protein in the urine leads to low serum albumin levels and decreased oncotic pressure, resulting in fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exudative pleural effusions are typically caused by conditions that involve inflammation or injury to the pleura, such as rheumatoid arthritis, while transudative effusions are usually due to systemic conditions like heart failure, liver failure, and nephrotic syndrome that affect hydrostatic or oncotic pressure.

questions.text: What is the shelf life of CuT 380 A? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 10 Yrs

 

Shelf life of CuT 380 is 10 yrs (its effectiveness is for 12 years)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shelf-life of IUDs

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Internal capsule

 

 

  • The internal capsule is a white matter structure situated between the thalamus and the basal ganglia (caudate nucleus and putamen).
  • It is critical for carrying motor and sensory information between the cerebral cortex and the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Part of the basal ganglia located lateral to the internal capsule.

 

Option B. Thalamus: A large mass of gray matter located medially to the internal capsule, involved in sensory and motor signal relay and regulation of consciousness.

 

Option D. External capsule: A thin layer of white matter lateral to the putamen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule is a key white matter structure in the brain, crucial for transmitting motor and sensory information between the cerebral cortex and the spinal cord. It is located between the thalamus and the basal ganglia

questions.text: As the member of a school health committee, you are revising the school health program to improve student well-being. Which of the following is not a standard component of school health? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Doctor on school premises

 

School health service includes all the above except the presence of a doctor in the school premises.

 

In 1961, ‘Renuka Roy School Health Committee’ laid the foundations for a comprehensive school health programme in India. School health committee (1961) in India recommended medical examination of children ‘at the time of entry and thereafter every 4 years’ [New NRHM guideline: Once every 6 months]. 

 

School health checkup comes under Secondary level of prevention

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teaching handicapped children: This is an essential part of ensuring that all students, including those with disabilities, receive appropriate education and support.

 

Option C. Dental and eye health services: Regular dental and eye check-ups are standard components of school health programs to identify and address common health issues.

 

Option D. School health records: Maintaining health records is crucial for tracking the health and well-being of students over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School Health Program includes:

 

  • Screening of general health assessment of visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up etc.
  • First-aid and emergency care
  • Education of handicapped children
  • Health education
  • Maintenance and use of school health records

questions.text: Which of the following is an Orexinergic hormone? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ghrelin

 

Explanation

 

  • Ghrelin is an orexinergic hormone primarily produced in the stomach. It plays a significant role in stimulating appetite and promoting food intake by activating orexin neurons in the hypothalamus. Orexinergic hormones are those that activate orexin receptors, which are involved in the regulation of sleep-wake cycles and feeding behaviors.

 

Orexinergic System

 

  • The orexinergic system includes hormones and neurotransmitters that affect the orexin receptors in the brain. Ghrelin is specifically known for its role in increasing hunger and is sometimes referred to as the "hunger hormone."
  • It also influences the secretion of growth hormone and insulin, and it has a broader role in energy balance and metabolic processes.
  • Some examples of orexigenic hormones: 
    • Ghrelin - Increases food intake (Hormones hunger), Growth hormone secretion, Increases insulin secretion.
    • Orexin - produced by the hypothalamus and is involved in regulating sleep and appetite. Neuropeptide Y (NPY) and Agouti-related peptide (AgRP), can also stimulate appetite and promote food intake.
    • Dysregulation of these hormones can contribute to conditions such as obesity and eating disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testosterone: Incorrect as testosterone is a steroid hormone primarily involved in the development and maintenance of male sexual characteristics and reproductive functions.

 

Option C. Progesterone: Incorrect because progesterone is a steroid hormone involved in the menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and embryogenesis of humans and other species.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect as only ghrelin among the listed options functions as an orexinergic hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ghrelin is the correct answer as it is the only hormone among the options that is classified as orexinergic, playing a critical role in stimulating appetite and regulating energy balance through its interaction with orexin neurons in the brain. This mechanism is pivotal in understanding metabolic disorders and targets for obesity treatment.

choices.text: Pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constrictive pericarditis

 

The key clinical feature in this scenario is Kussmaul's sign, which is the paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure (JVP) during inspiration. This is indicative of conditions that impede the normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, such as constrictive pericarditis.

 

Key Features of Constrictive Pericarditis:

 

  • Kussmaul's Sign: Lack of normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, or paradoxical increase, due to rigid pericardium that limits cardiac filling.
  • Dyspnea: Common due to impaired filling of the heart.
  • Absence of Murmur: Distinguishes it from valvular heart diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with a diastolic murmur and does not cause Kussmaul's sign.

 

Option C. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis can cause elevated JVP, but it is usually associated with a diastolic murmur.

 

Option D. Pulmonary arterial hypertension: Pulmonary arterial hypertension can cause elevated JVP, but it is not typically associated with Kussmaul's sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kussmaul's sign, an increase in JVP on inspiration, is indicative of constrictive pericarditis. It is not associated with murmurs or primary valvular heart diseases.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21%


During neonatal resuscitation, the initial amount of oxygen administered to a term baby is 21%, which corresponds to the concentration of oxygen in room air. The rationale behind starting with 21% oxygen is to avoid the potential risks associated with high concentrations of oxygen, such as oxidative stress and damage to the delicate tissues of a newborn, particularly the lungs and eyes.

 

Bag and mask ventilation using an AMBU (Artificial Manual Breathing Unit) bag, also known as a self-inflating bag, is the standard method used during neonatal resuscitation. The oxygen concentration delivered can vary depending on the setup:

 

  • AMBU without reservoir and without oxygen inlet: Provides 21% oxygen, as it uses room air.
  • AMBU with a reservoir and with oxygen inlet: Can deliver close to 100% oxygen.
  • AMBU with a reservoir but without an oxygen inlet: Delivers approximately 40% oxygen.

 

Given the guidelines and the need to balance adequate oxygenation with minimizing the risks of hyperoxia, resuscitation of a term newborn typically begins with 21% oxygen, with adjustments made based on the infant’s response and ongoing clinical assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 50%: Starting with 50% oxygen is not standard practice for neonatal resuscitation, as the recommendation is to start with room air (21%) and adjust as necessary.

 

Option C. 100%: High concentrations of oxygen, such as 100%, are avoided initially due to the risks of oxygen toxicity and oxidative stress, which can cause harm to the newborn, particularly to the eyes (risk of retinopathy of prematurity) and lungs.

 

Option D. 75%: Similar to 50% and 100%, 75% oxygen is not recommended as the starting concentration for neonatal resuscitation in term babies.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ENT OPD with nasal obstruction. On examination, a mulberry-shaped hypertrophied inferior turbinate was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypertrophic Rhinitis

 

Given clinical scenario suggests diagnosis of Hypertrophic rhinitis.

 

Hypertrophic Rhinitis is characterized by chronic inflammation leading to the thickening of the mucosal lining and the underlying connective tissue of the nasal turbinates, particularly the inferior turbinates. This condition can manifest as a "mulberry" appearance due to the irregular, hypertrophic mucosal surface, which is a hallmark sign of turbinate hypertrophy.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Nasal Obstruction: The primary symptom due to enlarged turbinates.
  • Mulberry Appearance of Turbinate: Visualized during nasal examination, indicating significant mucosal hypertrophy.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Chronic Inflammation: Often triggered by prolonged episodes of rhinitis, allergens, or irritants, leading to mucosal edema and fibrosis.
  • Submucosal Fibrosis: Contributes to the persistent swelling and hypertrophy of the turbinates.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Includes nasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and antihistamines if allergies are a contributing factor.
  • Surgical Intervention: Turbinectomy or turbinate reduction surgery may be required for severe cases where medical treatment fails to relieve symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common Cold: Typically presents with temporary nasal congestion and discharge, resolving without long-term hypertrophy.

 

Option B. Nasal Polyp: Polyps are soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of nasal passages or sinuses, hanging down like teardrops or grapes. They are not described as mulberry-shaped.

 

Option D. Atrophic Rhinitis: Characterized by the thinning and drying of the nasal mucosa, leading to crust formation and a foul odor, not hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic Rhinitis involves chronic inflammation leading to noticeable enlargement and characteristic textural changes in the nasal turbinates, often requiring a combination of medical and surgical treatments to manage symptoms effectively and improve nasal airflow.

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

 

  • Dysphonia is the hallmark symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • The swelling in the vocal cords alters their vibration, leading to changes in voice quality, pitch, and loudness.
  • Patients often present with a deep, husky voice, and in severe cases, speech may become effortful.

 

Reinke’s Edema is polypoid degeneration of vocal cords. It is bilateral symmetrical swelling of the whole of membranous part of the vocal cords. This is due to oedema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords.

 

 

 

Etiology – Chronic irritation of vocal cords due to misuse of voice, heavy smoking, chronic sinusitis and laryngopharyngeal reflex.

 

Clinical features – Hoarseness, Dysphonia, patient uses false cords for voice production and this gives him a low-pitched and rough voice.

 

On indirect laryngoscopy, vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

 

Treatment - Decortication of the vocal cords, Voice rest and Speech therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dysphagia to Solids and Option C. Dysphagia to Liquids:

 

These symptoms relate to difficulty swallowing, which is not typically associated with Reinke’s edema unless there is significant involvement of adjacent structures affecting the swallowing mechanism, which is rare.

 

Option D. Diplophonia:

 

  • Diplophonia (the perception of two simultaneous pitches) can occur in conditions affecting vocal cord vibration but is not a classic feature of Reinke’s edema.
  • It may be observed in some cases of vocal cord lesions, such as polyps or cysts, but it is not a primary symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • Usually diplophonia is seen in unilateral vocal cord pathologies. The affected cord vibrates at a different frequency when compared with the normal cord which vibrates at its regular frequency. This is because vibrational characteristics of affected cord gets changed due to structural changes caused by the lesion. Hence 2 cords, vibrating at 2 different frequencies, will produce 2 different sounds. This is called as diplophonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

choices.text: It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors
It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia
It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors

 

  • Labetalol is a 3rd generation beta blocker having the property of additional α and β blockade.

  • α1 receptor blockade leads to the relaxation of arterial smooth muscle and leads to vasodilation, The beta 1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure as it blocks reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia: Is direct acting vasodilators like hydralazine and minoxidil.

 

Option C. It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles: Could be nitrates because they cause primarily venodilation.

 

Option D It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle: Is the property of vasodilators.

questions.text: A patient came with pain in the abdomen and on further imaging the following is obtained. What is the best management option for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteroscopic removal

 

The given X-ray image shows a left lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for ureteric stones, specifically those present in the distal ureter.

 

  • This procedure involves passing a small scope directly into the ureter (usually via the bladder) to visualize the stone. Once the stone is located, it can be fragmented (usually with a laser) and the pieces can be removed.
  • Ureteroscopic removal is often preferred for stones located in the distal ureter, especially if they are below 6 mm in size. The advantage of this method is direct visualization and removal of the stone.
  • Potential complications can include ureteric injury, perforation, and subsequent stricture formation, although these are relatively rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy):

 

  • PCNL is an invasive procedure where a tract is created from the skin directly into the kidney. Through this tract, instruments can be inserted to fragment and extract stones.
  • This approach is most commonly used for large renal stones or when other treatments have failed. It's generally not the first-line treatment for a distal ureteric stone.

 

Option B. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy):

 

  • ESWL uses shock waves generated outside the body to fragment stones inside the urinary tract. The fragmented stone pieces can then pass out with urine.
  • ESWL is most suitable for small to medium-sized stones located in the kidney or upper ureter. It is less effective for distal ureteric stones compared to ureteroscopic removal.

 

Option D. Reassurance:

 

  • Some small stones, especially those in the lower ureter, might pass spontaneously. In such cases, if the stone isn't causing obstruction, infection, or severe pain, the patient might be advised to drink plenty of water and wait to see if the stone passes on its own.
  • Pain management and periodic follow-ups would be essential. However, for symptomatic stones, active removal is often preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For symptomatic distal ureteric stones, ureteroscopic removal is typically the best management option due to its effectiveness and minimal invasiveness.

questions.text: What is the type of inheritance shown in the Image: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AD

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted from affected father to his daughter and son. Also, it is being transmitted from affected mother to her progeny. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AR (Autosomal Recessive): Typically, AR inheritance shows disease in siblings, not across multiple generations, and both parents must be carriers.

 

Option C. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Affected fathers would transmit the disease to all daughters but not sons, and affected mothers can transmit to both sons and daughters.

 

Option D. XLR (X-linked Recessive): More common in males; females are typically carriers unless they have two affected X chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The presence of the disease in all three generations and transmission from both affected fathers and mothers to their progeny indicates autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance.

questions.text: A patient comes with silvery scaly erythematous plaques over extensors with pitting of nails and involvement of scalp is also noted, these findings are consistent with which diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis vulgaris

 

Psoriasis vulgaris is the most common type of psoriasis.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It an inflammatory non-infectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17 & Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Erythematous plaque with silvery white like scaling.
  • Extensors are commonly involved.
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails. Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis - Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

 

• P – Pitting (Most common feature)

• O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis

• L - Leukonychia

• I - Irregular pitting pattern

• S - Splinter Hemorrhage

• H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Clinical Sign

 

A defining characteristic of psoriasis is the presence of silvery white, scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knee and elbow. The Auspitz sign can be used to make a clinical diagnosis of the condition.

 

Scratching (grattage) superficial silvery scales causes them to come off attached, as if one had done so on a wax candle (wax candle scales).

 

The Bulkeley membrane, a thin membrane, can then be seen.

 

When the Bulkeley membrane is removed, the Auspitz sign, a classic pinpoint bleeding, is revealed.

 

The Auspitz sign is the name for the traditional pin-point bleeding.

 

Pin point bleeding spots noted in the below image.

 

 

The Auspitz sign is brought on by elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papillae and supra papillary epidermal thinning.

 

Auspitz Sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

 

  • Features: It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by pruritic, flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules and plaques. Wickham striae, or fine white lines, can sometimes be seen on the surface of the lesions. Oral involvement is common.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Features: A rare autoimmune blistering disease of the skin and mucous membranes. Patients develop flaccid bullae or erosions, often with a positive Nikolsky sign (skin slippage with minor friction).
  • Why it doesn't match: The description doesn't mention flaccid blisters or erosions, and the hallmark of pemphigus vulgaris is the presence of these blisters and the positive Nikolsky sign.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • Features: It's a genetic skin disorder characterized by dry, scaly skin resembling fish scales. The lower legs are often prominently affected, but the condition can also involve the arms, hands, and trunk.
  • Why it doesn't match: While ichthyosis vulgaris can present with scaly skin, it doesn't typically cause erythematous plaques, nail pitting, or specific scalp involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis vulgaris by the presence of silvery scaly erythematous plaques predominantly on extensor surfaces, associated with nail pitting and scalp involvement.

 

Reference:  ijdvl.com - Scaly signs in dermatology; Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6, 35.9 35.10; Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: A researcher is studying the spread of a new viral illness. He wants to determine the probability that a susceptible person will contract the disease after close contact with an infected person. Which measure best describes this probability? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary attack rate

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) measures the probability that a susceptible individual will contract the disease after coming into close contact with an infected individual. It is a useful measure for gauging the infectious potential of an agent within a population.

 

Infectivity is known by calculating the secondary attack rates.


SAR = (Total no. of secondary cases * 100) / (Total susceptible population-primary cases)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial interval is the average time difference between the primary and secondary case, which is similar to the median incubation period

 

Option C. Incubation period: Entry of organism in the human body till the first sign / symptom is produced.

 

Option D. The Case fatality rate = (Number of deaths due to a disease / number of cases of that particular disease) * 100

 

Case fatality rate typically is used as a measure of disease severity and is often used for prognosis. Always expressed in %. CFR of Rabies is 100%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) is a critical measure for assessing the infectious potential of a disease, indicating the likelihood that a disease will spread among susceptible individuals after exposure to an infected person.

questions.text: A HIV patient is presenting with cough without sputum, on examination his CD4 counts were <100 and chest x ray shown bilateral infiltration of lung, on further proceeding Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the organisms were positive for acid fast staining, what is the organism responsible for his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium avium complex

 

Based on the clinical presentation, CD4 count, radiographic findings, and positive acid-fast staining in the bronchoalveolar lavage, the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition is Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a group of bacteria that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that commonly causes pneumonia in people with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS. However, the cough in this case is without sputum, which is not typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia. Although PCP is common in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL, it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus is a fungus that can cause a severe lung infection and meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with a positive acid-fast stain and is not commonly associated with lung infiltrates seen on chest X-rays in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL presenting with a cough without sputum, bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray, and positive acid-fast staining, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: Most common indication for elective splenectomy is? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune thrombocytopenia

 

Most common indication for elective splenectomy is Immune thrombocytopenia. Splenectomy is performed when patients do not respond to medical therapy. ITP is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a low platelet count and increased risk of bleeding. The spleen is responsible for the destruction of platelets, and its removal helps to increase platelet count and reduce the risk of bleeding.

 

Indications for elective splenectomy include:

  • Hereditary Spherocytosis
  • Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
  • Thalassemia:
  • Hypersplenism
  • Splenic Tumors or Cysts
  • Splenic Abscess or Infarction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spherocytosis: While splenectomy is indicated in this condition, it is not the most common indication compared to ITP.

 

Option B. G6PD deficiency: Splenectomy is not a typical treatment for G6PD deficiency, which is managed by avoiding oxidative stress.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: Splenectomy may be performed in some cases of sickle cell disease, but it is not the most common indication compared to ITP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common indication for elective splenectomy is Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).

questions.text: Identify the marked rib. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4th Posterior

 

Marked rib is 4th posterior.

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior ribs on a chest X-ray are horizontally oriented, while anterior ribs are obliquely oriented.

choices.text: Renal artery stenosis

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pheochromocytoma

 

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that control heart rate, metabolism, and blood pressure. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

 

  1. Headache: Sudden and severe headaches.
  2. Palpitations: Rapid heart rate.
  3. Profuse sweating: Excessive sweating.

 

In addition to these symptoms, patients with pheochromocytoma often experience episodic hypertension (elevated blood pressure). The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrine, a metabolite of catecholamines.

 

TOC - Start with an alpha blocker, after 24 to 48 hours, add a beta blocker. The alpha blocker of choice is intravenous (IV) phentolamine. Phenoxybenzamine or prazosin can be used as alternative alpha blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Addison's disease: This condition results from adrenal insufficiency and typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Hypotension (low blood pressure) is more common, rather than hypertension.

 

Option B. Renal artery stenosis: This condition can cause secondary hypertension, but it does not present with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating. Additionally, it would not typically elevate urinary metanephrine.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: This condition can cause symptoms like palpitations and sweating, but it would not cause episodic hypertension or elevated urinary metanephrine levels. Instead, hyperthyroidism is more associated with a consistently high heart rate and other systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytoma presents with the classic triad of headache, palpitations, and sweating, along with episodic hypertension and elevated urinary metanephrine levels.

questions.text: Skull of a dead person was found during investigation. Police asked the relatives to bring the photo of deceased. Which of the following method can be used for identification of dead body? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superimposition.

 

Craniofacial superimposition is a technique used in the field of forensic anthropology to assist in the analysis of an unknown skull. The photograph of the missing person is superimposed on the photograph of the skull of a missing person. It is an exclusionary evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthropometry (Bertillon’s System, Bertillonage)

 

  1. The science of measuring the body parts constitutes Bertillon’s system  or  anthropometry.
  2. It is only applicable in adults. After the age of 21 years the skeleton stops growing and hence the measurements of various parts of the body remain constant.
  3. It is also assumed that no two people will have bones of identical dimensions.

 

Option B. Dactylography:

 

  • The study of fingerprints for identification.
  • Useful for identifying living persons or well-preserved bodies but not applicable for skeletal remains.

 

Option D. DNA Fingerprinting:

 

  • Analysis of DNA to identify individuals.
  • Highly accurate but requires biological samples such as hair, blood, or tissue, which may not be available with skeletal remains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superimposition is the appropriate method for identifying a skull using a photograph of the deceased, by comparing anatomical features to establish a match.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and increase exercise capacity of a person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pirfenidone

 

Pirfenidone is a synthetic pyridine drug that acts as an antifibrotic agent with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. It is used to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Pirfenidone helps to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and improves exercise capacity in patients with IPF. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of fibroblasts and reducing the production of pro-fibrotic cytokines, thereby slowing down the fibrotic process in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roflumilast: Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitor indicated for the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It reduces inflammation and improves lung function in patients with COPD but is not used for treating pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Option C. Imatinib: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). It works by inhibiting the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, but it does not have a role in the treatment of pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Option D. Bortezomib: Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. It inhibits the proteasome pathway, leading to cancer cell death. It is not used for treating pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pirfenidone is the drug used to decrease the progression of lung fibrosis and increase exercise capacity in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). It has antifibrotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties that help to manage this condition. Other drugs like roflumilast, imatinib, and bortezomib are used for different medical conditions and do not have the same therapeutic effects on pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Airway resistance in endotracheal tube is dependent on: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diameter of the tube

 

The diameter of the endotracheal tube is the primary factor affecting airway resistance. According to Poiseuille's law, the resistance (R) to airflow through a tube is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (r) of the tube (R ∝ 1/r^4). This means that even a small reduction in the diameter of the tube will result in a significant increase in resistance. The law can be expressed as R = 8ηL/πr^4, where η is the viscosity of the gas, L is the length of the tube, and r is the radius of the tube. Therefore, a larger diameter tube will have lower resistance and allow for easier airflow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumference of the tube: The circumference is indirectly related to the diameter, but it does not directly influence the resistance as significantly as the diameter itself.

 

Option B. Length of the tube: While the length of the tube does affect resistance (longer tubes increase resistance), it is not as impactful as the diameter. The resistance is directly proportional to the length (R ∝ L).

 

Option D. Curvature of the tube: The curvature can affect the ease of intubation and positioning but does not significantly impact resistance in a straightforward manner compared to the diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding Poiseuille's law is crucial for selecting appropriate endotracheal tubes. The diameter of the tube has the most significant impact on airway resistance. A larger diameter tube will decrease resistance, facilitating easier ventilation and oxygenation of the patient.

choices.text: It is caused by staphylococcus only
It is a case of testicular torsion

questions.text: A 40-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the correct statement about this condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The testis remains unaffected

 

The patient's presentation, along with the examination findings, suggest Fournier's gangrene. This is a life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal and genital regions requiring prompt medical and surgical intervention.

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is characterized by rapid progression and extensive tissue necrosis. It is a polymicrobial infection often involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria from gastrointestinal or genitourinary sources. Immediate treatment includes surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

The infection in Fournier's gangrene usually affects superficial tissues and skin but spares the testes due to their separate blood supply from the testicular artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by staphylococcus only: Incorrect. While Staphylococcus species can be involved, Fournier's gangrene is typically polymicrobial, involving multiple bacteria such as E. coli, Klebsiella, and anaerobes, along with staphylococci.

 

Option C. It is a self-resolving condition: Incorrect. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressing and severe condition that requires urgent surgical and medical treatment. Without intervention, it can lead to sepsis and be fatal.

 

Option D. It is a case of testicular torsion: Incorrect. Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to acute severe scrotal pain and ischemia of the testis. This condition is different from Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier's gangrene is a severe necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital regions, often sparing deeper structures like the testes. Immediate surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are critical for management.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to a health clinic with difficulty seeing in the evening and dry, irritated eyes. Her diet mainly consists of rice and lentils, with limited access to green leafy vegetables or animal products. On examination, dryness and Bitot's spots are noted on the conjunctiva. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for her symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vitamin A

 

Deficiency of Vitamin A leads to dryness of eyes or Xerophthalmia. The clinical presentation in the question aligns with the signs and symptoms of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

WHO Grading of Vitamin A Deficiency:

 

 

  • Xerophthalmia is most common in children aged 1 - 3 years
  • ‘First clinical sign’ of Vitamin-A deficiency: Conjunctival xerosis 
  • ‘First clinical symptom’ of Vitamin-A deficiency: Night blindness
  • Conjunctival xerosis in Xerophthalmia has a characteristic appearance of ‘emerging like sand banks at receding tide
  • Bitot’s Spots’ are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on bulbar conjunctiva, on either side of cornea; In young children they indicate Vitamin-A deficiency, whereas in adults they are often inactive sequelae of earlier disease

 

 

Image showing Bitot’s Spot

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to Xerophthalmia, which presents with symptoms like dryness of eyes, night blindness, and Bitot's spots. This condition is common in children with diets lacking in vitamin A-rich foods.

questions.text: An unconscious patient in ICU is on endotracheal intubation and now needs a tracheostomy. What type of tube should be considered in this situation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cuffed tracheostomy tube

 

Explanation:

 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube: This type of tube is preferred for patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation. The cuff can be inflated to:

 

  • Prevent Aspiration: The cuff acts as a barrier, preventing secretions from the upper airway from entering the trachea and lungs.
  • Maintain Positive Pressure Ventilation: The cuff ensures that air does not leak around the tracheostomy tube, which is crucial for effective mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncuffed tracheostomy tube: Not suitable for patients who are at risk of aspiration or who require positive pressure ventilation since it does not provide a seal.

 

Option C. Metallic tracheostomy tube: Typically used in long-term tracheostomies but lacks a cuff, which means it cannot prevent aspiration or maintain a seal for positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Endotracheal tube: This is used for short-term airway management and is not suitable for long-term tracheostomy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For unconscious patients in ICU requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation, a cuffed tracheostomy tube is the preferred choice. The cuff provides a seal to prevent aspiration and ensure effective positive pressure ventilation, making it safer and more effective for such patients.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and bleeding. After diagnosis, it is determined to be inverted papilloma. What is the correct description of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benign and locally invasive

 

Inverted papilloma, also known as Schneiderian papilloma or Transitional cell papilloma, is characterized by its benign nature but with a propensity for local invasiveness. This type of tumor arises from the epithelial lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses and is notable for its tendency to grow inward into the underlying stroma rather than outward.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D. Malignant/Malignant and locally invasive: These are incorrect as inverted papilloma is primarily benign, though it requires aggressive management due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Benign and non-invasive: This is incorrect because, although benign, inverted papillomas are distinctly characterized by their local invasiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor primarily affecting the nasal cavity, requiring aggressive surgical management due to its invasive characteristics and potential complications. Regular follow-up is crucial due to the risk of recurrence and rare malignant transformation.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia/ conjunctival xerosis occurs due to deficiency of which of the following vitamin:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A

 

Explanation

 

Xerophthalmia, including conjunctival xerosis (dryness of the conjunctiva), is a hallmark sign of Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of healthy epithelial tissues, including the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye.
