It also plays a crucial role in vision, particularly in low-light conditions. Deficiency can lead to dryness of the eye, night blindness, and in severe cases, can progress to keratomalacia and blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. It does not typically manifest as xerophthalmia or conjunctival xerosis, which are eye-related conditions.

 

Option B. Vitamin B3: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While dermatitis can affect the skin around the eyes, it does not cause xerophthalmia, which is specifically related to dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with bone diseases like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults due to its role in calcium and phosphate metabolism. It is not typically associated with xerophthalmia or eye disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eye manifestations of vitamin a deficiency:

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia -The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Xerophthalmia- conjunctival and corneal dryness
  • Bitot's Spots - greyish-white triangular plaques adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • All the above-mentioned ocular changes are completely reversible with vitamin A supplementation.
  • Keratomalacia -softening of the cornea

 

Table: WHO Vitamin A deficiency grading

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 536

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline
Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline

 

Vasomotor Reversal of Dale:

 

Adrenaline stimulates both α1 and β2 receptors. The α1 receptors have very strong vasoconstrictor property whereas the β2 receptors are very sensitive receptors and they cause vasodilation. Since the α1 receptors are stronger, on administration of adrenaline, they are stimulated leading to vasoconstriction. After some time, metabolism takes place and only β2 is stimulated which causes low blood pressure. This phase does not also last for a long time as metabolism happens and brings back the blood pressure to the normal level. This is the biphasic response of adrenaline (two phases in which BP increases in the first phase and decreases in the second).

 

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha blocker. So if adrenaline is administered along with it , then the alpha receptor stimulation will not happen , and there will be only stimulation of the β2 receptors leading to vasodilation and severe hypotension. This phenomenon of a patient pretreated with phentolamine developing severe hypotension on the administration of adrenaline is known as the vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure: This describes tachyphylaxis, which is a rapid decrease in response to a drug after repeated doses, not vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option B. High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces an increase in blood pressure and heart rate: This describes the pharmacological effects of acetylcholine and atropine but is unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option D. Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker that usually causes a decrease in blood pressure by blocking β1 and β2 receptors, leading to reduced cardiac output and vasodilation. This statement is incorrect and unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale occurs when a patient pre-treated with an alpha blocker like phentolamine experiences severe hypotension upon administration of adrenaline due to the unopposed stimulation of β2 receptors, leading to vasodilation instead of the usual vasoconstriction and pressor effect.

questions.text: During an ophthalmic examination, the patient is asked to direct her gaze to her right side. During this ocular movement, the right lateral rectus muscle is being used. Which of the following is its yoke muscle?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left medial rectus

 

Left medial rectus and Right lateral Rectus are yoke muscles.

 

Yoke muscle - contralaterally paired extraocular muscles that works synergistically to direct the gaze in a given direction. For example, in directing the gaze to the right, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus operate together as yoke muscles.

 

Examples:

 

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye. It is not the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Right medial rectus: This muscle is responsible for adduction of the right eye, not synergistic with the right lateral rectus during rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left lateral rectus: This muscle is responsible for abduction of the left eye and would work with the right medial rectus for leftward gaze, not rightward gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles from opposite eyes that work together to direct the gaze in a specific direction. For rightward gaze, the yoke muscles are the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with itchy lesions on the wrist and involvement of oral mucosa, and on examination, following findings were noted. What will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lichen Planus

 

The skin lesion in the preceding image features the distinctive purple, flat, polygonal papules of lichen planus.

 

Lichen planus:

 

  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia

 

  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop. It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lichen nitidus

 

  • Features: Lichen nitidus presents as tiny, flesh-coloured, shiny papules, primarily on the abdomen, chest, forearms, and genitals. It doesn't usually involve the oral mucosa.
  • Why it doesn't match: The primary presentation doesn't involve oral mucosa, and the typical presentation is different from the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Psoriasis

 

  • Features: Psoriasis often presents with sharply demarcated, erythematous, scaly plaques. Common locations include the knees, elbows, and scalp. Nail changes (like pitting) can be observed. The oral mucosa is rarely involved.
  • Why it doesn't match: While psoriasis can affect various parts of the body, involvement of the oral mucosa is uncommon. The described presentation fits lichen planus better.

 

Option D. Chicken pox

 

  • Features: Chicken pox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus and presents as an itchy rash that evolves into fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions progress to pustules and then crust over. It starts on the face and trunk and spreads outward. Oral lesions can be present but are usually ulcers.
  • Why it doesn't match: The progression and appearance of chicken pox lesions differ from the described presentation. Also, chicken pox usually has a systemic presentation with fever and malaise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen planus is recognized as the characteristic pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques, often with Wickham's striae, and the presence of lacy white lesions on the oral mucosa.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 31.24, 34.39, 35.1, 37.1, 37.4, 37.6

questions.text: Which of the following is inhalational anesthetic of choice for pediatric age group? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic of choice for pediatric patients.

 

Key Points about Sevoflurane:

 

  • Sweet Smelling: Sevoflurane has a pleasant, non-irritating odor, making it easier for children to tolerate during induction.
  • Rapid Onset and Offset: Sevoflurane has a low blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to rapid induction and recovery, which is ideal for pediatric anesthesia.
  • Safety Profile: It has a relatively favorable safety profile for use in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Halothane was once widely used in pediatric anesthesia but is now less favored due to its potential for causing arrhythmias and hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is effective but has a pungent odor and can be irritating to the respiratory tract, making it less suitable for pediatric induction.

 

Option D. Desflurane: Desflurane has a very rapid onset and offset but is highly pungent and can cause airway irritation, making it less suitable for children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational anesthetic for pediatric patients due to its rapid onset, pleasant odor, and favorable safety profile. It is particularly useful for inhalational induction, making it easier for children to tolerate the induction process.

choices.text: Inclusion body myositis

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatomyositis

 

The patient's symptoms of difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair suggest proximal muscle weakness, a key feature of myopathy. The presence of violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids, known as heliotrope rash, strongly indicates dermatomyositis.

 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by both muscle inflammation and distinctive skin rashes, and it is commonly associated with anti-Mi-2 antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inclusion body myositis: Typically presents with asymmetric muscle weakness and does not usually involve skin rashes like dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: Also involves proximal muscle weakness but lacks the characteristic skin manifestations seen in dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Scleroderma: Primarily affects the skin with hardening and tightening but does not typically present with proximal muscle weakness or the specific rash of dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal muscle weakness combined with characteristic skin rashes, such as heliotrope rash, is indicative of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with headache. Radiological examination reveals a 2 cm mass attached to the dura. Which of the following will most likely be observed on histopathology? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psammoma Bodies with Whirling

 

  • Psammoma bodies with whirling are particularly associated with certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, meningioma (a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura), and serous ovarian tumors.
  • The presence of psammoma bodies with a characteristic whirling appearance in the histopathological examination of the mass attached to the dura would strongly suggest a meningioma as the likely diagnosis.
  • It is benign tumor, arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22q

 

 

  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcific structures.
  • They appear as round, laminated calcifications under the microscope. The presence of psammoma bodies in a tumor can provide important diagnostic clues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fried Egg Appearance: This appearance is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas, not meningiomas.

 

Option B. Antony A and B Areas: These areas are characteristic of schwannomas.

 

Option C. Verrucae Bodies: These bodies are not related to meningiomas or the described clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies with a whirling appearance are characteristic of meningiomas, a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the psychiatry OPD and tells that aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his cousins. This has been going on for 7 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schizophrenia

 

Patient is having auditory hallucinations for 7 months which points to a diagnosis of Schizophrenia.

 

According to DSM-5, for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, the total duration of illness should be at least six months.

 

Out of these six months, for at least one month, the patient should have two or more of the following symptoms. At least one of these two symptoms should be (1), (2) or (3):

 

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganised speech (which is a result of formal thought disorders)
  4. Disorganised behaviour or catatonic behaviour (symptoms)
  5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

 

The ICD-11 also uses similar symptom criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia; however, the duration criterion of ICD-11 is one month and not six months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: In Delusional disorder, hallucinations are usually absent. If hallucinations are present, they have the same content as the delusion.

 

Option C. Brief psychotic disorder: If the symptoms would have been for < 1 month, then Brief psychotic disorder would be the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Mania: Mania has following symptoms:

 

  • M - Mood elevation (undue excessive happiness) or irritable mood
  • A - Activity levels increased
  • F - Flight of ideas
  • A - Abnormally increased levels of activity/energy
  • S - Sleep decreased (decreased need for sleep) (e.g. patient feels refreshed after 2 hours of sleep)
  • T - Talkativeness (overtalkativeness)
  • G - Grandiose ideas and increased self-esteem (increased self-confidence, maybe boastful, and may make big claims.
  • D – Distractibility
  • P - Painful consequences (involvement in activities with potentially painful consequences like making foolish investments)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schizophrenia is characterized by ≥6 months of psychotic symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized behavior. It differs from delusional disorder (non-bizarre delusions, no hallucinations) and brief psychotic disorder (duration <1 month).

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple painful blisters on the trunk as shown in the image. Identify the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Herpes zoster

 

The above image shows multiple painful blisters on the trunk along dermatome which is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

 

  • It is a human herpes virus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

• Painful zoster infections in adults

• Facial zoster at any age

• Immunocompromised

 

Complication of zoster:

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox (Varicella)

 

  • Features: Caused by the primary infection with varicella-zoster virus. It generally presents as an itchy, diffuse vesicular rash that starts on the face and trunk before spreading to the extremities. The rash evolves through stages, with papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts present simultaneously.
  • Why it doesn't match: While chickenpox can produce blisters on the trunk, they are typically itchy rather than painful and appear in multiple stages of healing rather than uniformly as blisters. Also, chickenpox tends to start on the face and spread, not solely localized to the trunk.

 

Option C. Measles

 

  • Features: Caused by the measles virus, it presents with a high fever, malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. Koplik spots (white spots) on the buccal mucosa are a pathognomonic sign.
  • Why it doesn't match: Measles produces a maculopapular rash, not blisters. The systemic symptoms and the pattern of rash spread also don't align with the description.

 

Option D. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

  • Features: It's a primary immunodeficiency disorder where there is a defect in both T and B cell immune responses. Infants with SCID present with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and chronic diarrhoea. They are vulnerable to opportunistic infections.
  • Why it doesn't match: SCID itself does not cause blisters. Patients with SCID are susceptible to numerous infections due to their compromised immune system, but the mere presence of blisters would not immediately point to SCID without other accompanying symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes zoster is identified as painful, unilateral vesicular lesions within a dermatomal distribution on the patient's trunk.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page no 106

choices.text: Screening and treatment for STI and RTI

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically recognized as a primary component of the RCH program? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Women education and empowerment

 

While education and empowerment of women are crucial for overall health improvement, they are not specifically listed as a primary component of the RCH program.

 

Other Options:

 

The Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program focuses on specific health services to improve the health of mothers and children. The primary components of the RCH program include:

 

Option B. Children and newborn care: Services aimed at ensuring the health and well-being of children and newborns.

 

Option C. Screening and treatment for STI and RTI: Control and prevention of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted infections (STI).

 

Option D. Safe motherhood: Initiatives to ensure the health and safety of mothers during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Component of RCH program - 

 

  • Community Needs Assessment Approach (CNAA)
  • Integrated packages of services for mother and child
  • MTP services at PHC and safe abortion
  • Control and prevention of RTI/STI
  • Adolescent health
  • Services in urban slums
  • Improving quality of services
  • Unmet needs and sub-centre action plans
  • Communication strategy
  • Gender sensitiveness
  • Greater involvement of Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs and community

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester has a 2-year-old child. She received a complete vaccination course during her last pregnancy. What tetanus immunization is recommended for her now? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Td booster dose

 

As per National Immunization Schedule, the recommendations for pregnant woman are as follows: -

 

Td-1: Early in pregnancy

 

Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1

 

Td-Booster dose: if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For pregnant women who received the complete Td vaccination course during their last pregnancy within the last three years, a Td booster dose is recommended.

questions.text: Organisms entering via enteric route into our body are countered by which cells of the liver? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

 

Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages of the liver that are responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies.

 

Pathogenesis

 

Organisms

           ↓

         Enteric Route

           ↓

       Portal Vein

           ↓

           Liver

           ↓

    Kupffer Cells (Liver Macrophages)

           ↓

   Phagocytosis and Destruction

           ↓

 Activation of Immune Response

           ↓

Recruitment of Other Immune Cells

           ↓

  Clearance of Pathogens

           ↓

  Prevention of Dissemination

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dust cells: These are alveolar macrophages found in the lungs.

 

Option C. Ito cells: These cells are concerned with the storage of vitamin A and are located in the liver.

 

Option D. Mesangial cells: These cells are found in the kidneys and support glomerular capillaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kupffer cells are the liver macrophages responsible for countering organisms entering the body via the enteric route.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

The patient's presentation includes a constellation of symptoms and laboratory findings indicative of Legionella pneumonia, also known as Legionnaires' disease. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • High-grade fever, cough, and confusion: Common symptoms of Legionella pneumonia.
  • Diarrhea: Gastrointestinal manifestations are frequently associated with Legionella infections.
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray: Legionella pneumonia typically presents with infiltrates rather than consolidation.
  • Hyponatremia (Na: 126 mEq/L): Commonly seen in Legionella due to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).
  • Elevated liver enzymes (AST: 62, ALT: 56): Transaminitis is often observed in Legionella infections.
  • Normal bilirubin and random blood sugar levels: These findings are not specific but do not rule out Legionella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus: Streptococcal pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and does not commonly cause significant gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: This organism typically affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) and presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than focal infiltrates and lacks gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option D. Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumonia usually presents with lobar consolidation and "currant jelly" sputum. It does not typically cause gastrointestinal symptoms or hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows highest concentration in the serum? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ig-G

 

IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the serum. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing pathogens, opsonizing for phagocytosis, and activating the complement system. IgG is also the only immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

 

Immunoglobulins concentration in the serum are as follow -

 

Ig-G > Ig-A > Ig-M > Ig-D > Ig-E

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ig-M: Incorrect. While IgM is the first antibody to respond to an infection, it is not the most abundant in the serum.

 

Option B. Ig-A: Incorrect. IgA is present in mucosal areas and secretions, but not in the highest concentration in the serum.

 

Option C. Ig-E: Incorrect. IgE is the least abundant in the serum and is primarily involved in allergic responses.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to OPD with complaint of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. Examination revealed finding as shown in image. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are noticed. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image showing strawberry cervix, is suggestive of Trichomoniasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial Vaginosis

 

  • Discharge: White, thin, homogenous with a foul odor.
  • Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria - clue cells on wet mount, whiff test positive, pH > 4.5, homogenous discharge.
  • Symptoms: Usually no erythema or significant irritation.

 

Option C. Chlamydial Cervicitis

 

  • Typically associated with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may not present with frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix.
  • Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Option D. Candidiasis

 

  • Discharge: Thick, curdy white with no odor.
  • Diagnosis: KOH prep revealing pseudohyphae or spores, wet mount.
  • Symptoms: Pruritis and dysuria with notable erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomoniasis is characterized by greenish-frothy vaginal discharge, a strawberry cervix, and motile organisms on saline microscopy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition page 166

questions.text: A patient is receiving chemotherapy with platinum compounds. Which of the following drugs are used for treatment of chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Granisetron, Dexamethasone and Aprepitant

 

Granisetron + Dexamethasone + Aprepitant is used to treat Chemotherapy-induced Nausea and Vomiting.

 

  • Granisetron is a 5-HT3 Receptor blocker (others being Ondansetron, Palonosetron etc.).

  • Aprepitant is NK1 /Neurokinin antagonist.

  • 5-HT3 blockers are in general the DOC for Chemotherapy induced vomiting, Radiotherapy induced vomiting and post operative vomiting.

  • Neurokinin or the substance P antagonists are the DOC for delayed vomiting by Cisplatin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metoclopramide, Dexamethasone and Domperidone: While metoclopramide and domperidone are antiemetics, they are less effective for CINV compared to 5-HT3 antagonists and NK1 antagonists. Dexamethasone is appropriate, but the combination lacks the efficacy of the preferred regimen.

 

Option C. Prochlorperazine, Granisetron and Domperidone: Prochlorperazine is an antipsychotic with antiemetic properties but is not as effective for CINV as NK1 antagonists. Granisetron is appropriate, but the combination lacks the efficacy of aprepitant.

 

Option D. Promethazine, Doxylamine and Metoclopramide: Promethazine and doxylamine are antihistamines and are less effective for CINV. Metoclopramide is also less effective compared to the preferred agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, particularly with platinum compounds like cisplatin, the combination of Granisetron (a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist), Dexamethasone (a corticosteroid), and Aprepitant (an NK1 receptor antagonist) is highly effective. This regimen targets multiple pathways involved in emesis and provides comprehensive control of both acute and delayed phases of CINV.

questions.text: A covid patient was discharged from hospital & was recovering at home. In order to join back his duties, he himself started taking excessive multivitamin supplements and he developed symptoms of nerve sensations- tingling sensations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B6 Excess

 

Vitamin B6 Excess: Correct Answer. Excessive intake of Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) can lead to neuropathy, manifesting as sensory changes such as tingling or burning sensations, especially in the hands and feet. This is due to its effect on the nervous system, where it can cause nerve damage when taken in high doses over a prolonged period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D Excess: While excessive Vitamin D can lead to toxicity, its symptoms primarily include hypercalcemia, leading to symptoms like nausea, vomiting, weakness, and frequent urination. It is not typically associated with peripheral nerve sensations or tingling.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 Excess: Vitamin B12 is a water-soluble vitamin, and its excess is usually excreted in the urine. It is not commonly associated with toxicity, and symptoms like tingling sensations are more typically associated with B12 deficiency, not excess.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 Excess: Excess of Vitamin B3 (Niacin) can cause "niacin flush," characterized by skin flushing, itching, and gastrointestinal symptoms. It is not typically associated with neuropathic symptoms like tingling sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Excessive intake of pyridoxine can lead to toxicity, which can cause a range of symptoms and health problems. The recommended daily intake of pyridoxine for adults is 1.3-1.7 mg/day, and the tolerable upper intake level (UL) is set at 100 mg/day for adults. Exceeding the UL can lead to pyridoxine toxicity.

 

Symptoms of pyridoxine toxicity can include:

 

  1. Sensory neuropathy: Numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities, which can progress to loss of sensation and muscle weakness.
  2. Ataxia: Difficulty with coordination and balance.
  3. Photosensitivity: Increased sensitivity to sunlight, which can cause skin rash and sunburn.
  4. Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  5. Impaired glucose tolerance: High doses of pyridoxine can interfere with glucose metabolism and lead to impaired glucose tolerance.
  6. Cognitive impairment: High doses of pyridoxine can cause confusion, irritability, and depression.
  7. Seizures: Rarely, high doses of pyridoxine can cause seizures.

 

Pyridoxine toxicity is rare and usually occurs only with prolonged use of high-dose supplements (usually over 1,000 mg/day) over a period of time. 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 543-544

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the site X shown in the figure? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrochlorothiazide

 

The site X in the given image represent distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is a thiazide diuretic that acts by blocking the Na-Cl symporter in the DCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle (marked B) and inhibits the Na-K-2Cl symporter.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Is an Aldosterone receptor blocker acting on the collecting ducts (marked Y).

 

Option D. Acetazolamide. Is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubules (marked A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and promoting diuresis. This makes it effective for treating conditions such as hypertension and edema. Other diuretics like furosemide, spironolactone, and acetazolamide act on different parts of the nephron and have distinct mechanisms of action.

questions.text: In a recent community health survey in Rajasthan, India, there has been a significant surge in cases of oral and lung cancers. It was found that tobacco consumption, both smoking and chewing, was a significant contributor. The government implemented legislation to curb tobacco use. This action is an example of which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary

 

The introduction of an Act to prevent the use of tobacco in community is an example of primary prevention, as it prevents the disease by bringing about a change of lifestyle, that is the use of tobacco as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial:

 

  • Prevents the development of risk factors.
  • Example: Legislation to reduce tobacco use, promoting healthy lifestyles from a young age to prevent the development of harmful habits.

 

Option C. Secondary:

 

  • Involves early detection and prompt intervention to prevent progression.
  • For example, screening programs like Pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tertiary:

 

  • Involves managing and reducing the impact of an ongoing illness.
  • For example, providing cardiac rehabilitation after a heart attack to prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Level of Prevention:

 

  • Primordial - Prevention of development of risk factors
  • Primary - Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • Secondary - Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • Tertiary - Complications are present, death is being prevented.

questions.text: Identify the given image:(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central retinal artery occlusion

 

Above image is showing cherry red spot which is seen in central retinal artery occlusion.

 

Central retinal artery occlusion - it occurs due to the blockade of Retinal Artery by thrombus or embolus at lamina cribrosa.

 

Risk factors: old age, atherosclerosis, hypertension, smoking etc.

Symptoms: Sudden painless U/L loss of vision

Signs: Retinal whitening, Cherry red spot

 

DD:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and optic disc swelling. There is no cherry red spot seen in CRVO.

 

Symptoms: Similar to CRAO with sudden, painless vision loss, but CRVO is associated with hemorrhages and more variable vision loss.

 

Management: Includes addressing complications such as macular edema and neovascularization with treatments like intravitreal injections and laser photocoagulation.

 

Option C. Branched retinal artery occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal whitening corresponding to the area of the blocked artery, but not a generalized cherry red spot.

 

Symptoms: Visual field defects in the area served by the affected artery rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Similar to CRAO but focused on the affected area, with possible treatments including ocular massage and addressing underlying causes like emboli.

 

Option D. Branched retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal hemorrhages, venous tortuosity, and possible cotton wool spots in the affected area.

 

Symptoms: Localized visual field defects rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Involves treating complications such as macular edema and monitoring for neovascularization, often with intravitreal injections and laser therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "cherry red spot" is a hallmark of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), which results from the blockage of the retinal artery and leads to retinal ischemia. Immediate management is critical to attempt to restore vision, although the prognosis is generally poor.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fever and he is diagnosed with condition caused by a lactose fermenting bacteria, he is advised for culture, Which culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mac conkey agar

 

Culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter - MacConkey agar

 

It is used to distinguish lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

it is a selective and differential culture medium

 

Contents of MacConkey agar: Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Sodium Taurocholate

 

 

Lactose fermenters seen as pink colonies, non-lactose fermenters seen as colorless or pale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bile salt agar: Incorrect. Bile salt agar is primarily used for the isolation of enteric pathogens, particularly Salmonella and Shigella, but it does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

Option C. LJ media: Incorrect. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media is used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Option D. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Incorrect. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is used for the cultivation of fungi, including yeasts and molds. It is not used to differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to distinguish lactose fermenters, which appear as pink colonies, from non-lactose fermenters, which appear as colorless or pale colonies.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with anorexia, nausea, vomiting and epigastric pain radiating towards the back. On investigation, Serum amylase is 1400; all other lab parameters are normal, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Pancreatitis

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Key symptoms and findings supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Epigastric pain radiating to the back: This is a classic symptom of acute pancreatitis. The pain is typically severe, constant, and often relieved by leaning forward.
  • Nausea and vomiting: These are common symptoms associated with acute pancreatitis.
  • Elevated serum amylase: A serum amylase level of 1400 U/L is significantly elevated, which is a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. Amylase levels typically rise within 6-12 hours of onset and can remain elevated for several days.

 

Signs and Symptoms of Acute Pancreatitis:

 

  • Pain: Acute onset of severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back.
  • Nausea and vomiting: Common accompanying symptoms.
  • Physical signs: May include hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
  • Characteristic discoloration:
    • Grey Turner's sign: Bluish discoloration of the flanks.
    • Cullen's sign: Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus.
    • Fox's sign: Discoloration below the inguinal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Cholecystitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and food aversion. Pain does not typically radiate to the back as in pancreatitis.
  • Serum Amylase: Usually not significantly elevated in acute cholecystitis.

 

Option C. Acute Appendicitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Periumbilical pain that later shifts to the right lower quadrant (McBurney's point). Pain typically does not radiate to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Chronic Hepatitis:

 

  • Symptoms: May include fatigue, jaundice, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort, but not typically severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in chronic hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute pancreatitis should be suspected in a patient with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, especially with significantly elevated serum amylase levels.

questions.text: A person is summoned by court to attend and record evidence in court. Which of the following describes the type of evidence? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral Evidence

 

Oral Evidence includes all statements which the court permits or which are required to be made before it by a witness, in relation to matters of fact under inquiry (Sec. 3 IEA).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hearsay Evidence:  Any evidence that is offered by a witness of which he does not have direct knowledge but his testimony is based on what others have said.

 

Option B. Subpoena/Summon: Is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a court of law, under penalty, on a particular day, time and place for the purpose of giving evidence.

 

Option D. Circumstantial evidence: Is the evidence consisting of collateral facts from which an inference may be drawn and are consistent with the direct evidence, such as finding blood on the clothes of the accused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral evidence refers to the statements made by a witness in court regarding matters of fact under inquiry. It is the testimony given by witnesses who have firsthand knowledge of the events in question.

choices.text: Kwashiorkor due to less energy intake
Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake
Marasmus due to less energy intake
Marasmus due to less protein intake

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by her grandmother Which of the following is correct about the given image? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

The given image is suggestive of kwashiorkor, as it shows a bulging abdomen and pedal edema along with thin limbs and prominent ribs. Kwashiorkor occurs as a result of less protein intake, whereas marasmus occurs due to less calorie intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drug acts at the site marked by arrow as shown in the diagram? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aliskiren

 

The arrow is marked at the step where Renin acts and helps in converting Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I. Angiotensin-I is converted to Angiotensin II with the help of Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE).
 

The drug Aliskiren is a direct competitive renin enzyme inhibitor. Other examples of Renin inhibitors include Remikiren, Enalkiren.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Ramipril: Is an ACE-Inhibitor. It inhibits the ACE enzyme which catalyze the conversion of Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II.

 

Option C. Losartan: Is an ARB (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker). It blocks the angiotensin receptor and inhibits its action of vasoconstriction and aldosterone release.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Is an Aldosterone blocker. It inhibits the action of Aldosterone of salt and water retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aliskiren acts at the step where renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, effectively inhibiting the renin enzyme and reducing the downstream effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This helps in managing hypertension by reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone-mediated sodium retention.

questions.text: Which of the following can be expected if division of zygote occurs between 8 – 12 days after fertilization? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic Monoamniotic

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dichorionic Diamniotic: Occurs when the division of the zygote happens within the first 3 days after fertilization.

 

Option B. Dichorionic Monoamniotic: This is not a typical classification in twin pregnancies.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: Result from the division of the zygote occurring after the 13th day of fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins result from the division of the zygote occurring between 8 to 12 days after fertilization.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 24th edition page 893

questions.text: A patient is experiencing loss of vision on both left sides of the visual fields, but retains the ability to see a small portion in the middle. Based on the history, where is the likely location of the lesion? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital cortex

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Left Macular sparing Homonymous Hemianopia which due to the lesion in Right occipital cortex.

 

VISUAL PATHWAY - Eye (Retina) → Optic Nerve → Optic Chiasm → Optic Tract → Lateral Geniculate Nucleus → Optic Radiation → Visual Cortex

 

  1. Eye (Retina): Light enters the eye and is captured by photoreceptor cells in the retina.
  2. Optic Nerve: The photoreceptor cells in the retina send signals via the optic nerve to the brain.
  3. Optic Chiasm: The optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over at the optic chiasm.
  4. Optic Tract: The fibers continue along the optic tract, which carries visual information from each eye to the brain.
  5. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus: The optic tract fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
  6. Optic Radiation: From the lateral geniculate nucleus, the visual information is transmitted via the optic radiation fibers to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe of the brain.
  7. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex processes the visual information to create the perception of vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: Lesions here typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, characterized by loss of vision in the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: Lesions here cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes, without macular sparing.

 

Option C. Optic Radiations: Lesions here can cause quadrantanopia, affecting a specific quarter of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the occipital cortex can cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, where the patient loses vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes but retains central vision due to the dual blood supply to the macular region.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a life-threatening condition characterized by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain, leading to sudden, severe headaches often described as the "worst headache of my life." This patient’s symptoms, including a severe headache of sudden onset, hypertension, and nuchal rigidity (neck stiffness), are classic signs of SAH.

 

The CT scan provided shows diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space, which is a hallmark of this condition. The presence of blood in the sulci, gyri, and ventricles, and the star-shaped appearance of the blood distribution on the CT scan (referred to as the "star of death" sign) further confirms this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cluster headache: Incorrect. While cluster headaches can be severe, they are typically unilateral and associated with autonomic symptoms such as tearing and nasal congestion, not nuchal rigidity or hypertension.

 

Option C. Encephalitis: Incorrect. Encephalitis can present with headache, fever, and altered mental status, but it does not typically cause nuchal rigidity or hypertension, and the CT findings would differ.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Incorrect. Meningitis can present with headache, fever, and nuchal rigidity, but it is usually accompanied by fever and altered mental status. The CT scan findings would show inflammation of the meninges rather than bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and hypertension. CT scan shows blood in the subarachnoid space, appearing as a "star of death."

questions.text: All the following are indications of caesarean section except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous history of macrosomia

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B, C and D are Absolute Indications for caesarean section. It means vaginal delivery is not possible

 

Absolute indications for caesarean section include:

 

  • Central placenta praevia
  • Contracted pelvis or CPD
  • Pelvic mass causing obstruction
  • Advanced CA cervix
  • Vaginal obstruction (atresia, stenosis)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous history of macrosomia is not an indication for caesarean section.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics page 670

questions.text: A combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering is called: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burking

 

Burking:

 

  1. It includes homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxiation
  2. Named after Burke and Hare
  3. Burke used to sit on the chest of victim and close his mouth and nostrils by hand and Hare used to pull him round the room by feet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gagging: Involves placing a gag in the victim’s mouth to prevent them from making noise, not necessarily causing death through asphyxia.

 

Option C. Choking: Refers to the obstruction of the airway by an internal object, preventing breathing.

 

Option D. Traumatic Asphyxia: A condition caused by severe compression of the chest, leading to impaired breathing and oxygen deprivation, but not necessarily combined with smothering.

 

Educational Objective:


Burking involves a deadly combination of traumatic asphyxia and smothering, making it a unique and specific method of homicide.

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 119.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is involved in the extrinsic pathway? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VII

 

Factor VII participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

The prothrombin time (PT) assay is done to assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway- Factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C, & D. Factor VIII, IX, and XI participate in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

Factor VIII is a protein involved in the intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is involved in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and its function can be assessed by the prothrombin time (PT) assay.

questions.text: Melanin is synthesized from which of the following amino acid? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tyrosine

 

Explanation

 

Correct Answer. Tyrosine, an amino acid, is the primary precursor for melanin synthesis. The process starts with the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA (dihydroxyphenylalanine) by the enzyme tyrosinase, followed by several steps leading to the formation of melanin. This pathway takes place in melanocytes, specialized cells found in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin and melatonin, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of melanin. Tryptophan's metabolic pathway is distinct from the pathway leading to melanin production.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Incorrect, but with a caveat. While phenylalanine itself is not directly used in melanin synthesis, it is important to note that phenylalanine can be converted into tyrosine in the body. Therefore, phenylalanine can be considered an indirect precursor to melanin. However, in the context of direct involvement in melanin synthesis, tyrosine is the correct answer.

 

Option D. Histidine: Histidine is another amino acid, but it is not involved in melanin synthesis. Instead, histidine plays roles in protein synthesis and the formation of histamine, a compound involved in immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanin is synthesized from tyrosine by following pathway.

 

 

Uses of tyrosine:

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 103

questions.text: In an automobile manufacturing company, the HR department notes an increase in absenteeism among the factory workers over the past six months. The company collaborates with a public health expert to investigate the reasons. The expert decides to use the metric of sickness absenteeism as a tool. What is the primary aspect this metric would evaluate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Health of the worker

 

Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used as an indicator of the occupational health of the employees. High sickness absenteeism indicates poor occupational health of the workers.

 

Sickness absenteeism is a ‘useful index in industry to assess the state of health of workers’, and their physical, mental and social well-being. Rate of absenteeism reported in India is 8 – 10 days per worker per year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Health of the family: Sickness absenteeism does not directly assess the health of the worker's family.

 

Option C. Industrial environment: While the industrial environment can affect absenteeism, the metric specifically evaluates worker health.

 

Option D. Community health: Sickness absenteeism focuses on the health of the workers, not the broader community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickness absenteeism primarily evaluates the health of the worker and is a key indicator of occupational health.

 

Methods of reducing sickness absenteeism:

 

  • Good factory management and practices
  • Adequate pre-placement examination
  • Good human relations
  • Application of ergonomics

questions.text: A female patient presented with pain and redness in great toe. Serum uric acid level is 9.6 mg/dL. Apart from prescribing analgesics for relieving pain, the physician prescribed a drug which can decrease the formation of uric acid. Which of the following enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Xanthine oxidase

 

Uric acid is formed from the breakdown of purines in the body which are metabolized to form Hypoxanthine. Hypoxanthine is converted to xanthine and xanthine is ultimately converted to uric acid with the help of the enzyme Xanthine Oxidase. Thus, the drugs like Allopurinol and Febuxostat that act by inhibiting this enzyme can be used in the treatment of hyperuricemia and gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thymidylate synthase: Is the enzyme which is used in production of thymidine monophosphate (TMP) from deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP). It is targeted by 5-Fluorouracil.

 

Option C. Phosphoribosyl transferase: Is the enzyme that plays a critical role in nucleotide biosynthesis, specifically in the salvage pathway. It includes HGPRT and APRT. HGPRT deficiency is seen in an autosomal recessive disorder – Lesch Nyhan Syndrome.

 

Option D. DHFR or Dihydrofolate reductase is an enzyme which is involved in Folic acid metabolism by converting dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. It is required for synthesis of thymine from uracil (methylation). It is targeted by Methotrexate, Trimethoprim, Pyrimethamine etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xanthine oxidase is the enzyme responsible for the final steps in the production of uric acid from purines. Inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol and febuxostat, are used to reduce uric acid levels and are effective treatments for hyperuricemia and gout.

questions.text: If any unsound minded person commits any crime unconsciously it won't be considered as a punishable offence. This is defined by which of the following law? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mc Naughten's rule

 

(84 IPC) Mc Naughten's rule “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.”

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Curren’s Rule states that an accused person is NOT responsible if at the time of act, he didn’t have the capacity to conform to requirements of law (psychopathy, sociopathy).

 

Option B. Durham’s Rule - An accused is NOT responsible if his unlawful act is a product of mental disease or defect.

 

Option D. Locard’s principle of exchange – whenever two objects come in contact there is exchange of physical evidence. This concept is used to detect crimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule provides the legal framework for the insanity defense, asserting that an individual who commits a crime while being incapable of understanding the nature or wrongfulness of their actions due to unsoundness of mind cannot be held criminally responsible.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient on cancer chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Filgrastim

 

Filgrastim is a G-CSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor) that can be used for chemotherapy induced neutropenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Darbepoetin: It is an Erythropoietin analogue which is used in the treatment of anemia due to CKD and bone marrow suppression.
 

Option C. Oprelvekin: It is an IL-11 analogue and stimulates the proliferation of megakaryocytes. It is useful in Thrombocytopenia.
 

Option D. Iron Dextran: It is a parenteral iron preparation which is used to treat Iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filgrastim is the drug used to increase immunity in patients with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia. It works by stimulating the production of neutrophils, thereby reducing the risk of infection. Other drugs like darbepoetin, oprelvekin, and iron dextran are used for different hematological conditions and do not directly increase neutrophil counts or improve immunity in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to emergency department with pain in right hip and is unable to walk. She gives a history of fall in bathroom. On examination, you observe that there is shortening of left lower limb and is externally rotated. There is no history of arthritis. X-ray of hip is given below. What will be the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemiarthroplasty

 

  • Patient with shortening of limb with external rotation and given x-ray suggests that this is a case of fracture neck of femur.

 

FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • In a physiologically > 60-year-old patient and with no features of arthritis, a displaced fracture neck of femur is managed by Hemiarthroplasty.
  • Features of Fracture Neck of Femur:
    • External rotation of the leg with patella facing outwards.
    • Shortening of leg
    • Tenderness in groin
    • Painful hip movements
  • Classification for Fracture Neck of Femur:

 

 

 

  • Treatment of fracture neck of femur:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Closed reduction. Non-operative treatment is usually preferred in younger patients. But it has a very limited role in them. This method is reserved for the sickest patients whose surgical risks negate fixation benefits.

 

Option C. Total hip replacement. THR appears to provide superior functional outcomes as compared to hemiarthroplasty in selected active, elderly patients, however, the rate of risk of complications is higher with THR, including dislocation.

 

Option D. Osteotomy. Valgus intertrochanteric osteotomies are done in cases of non-union of femoral neck fractures in younger patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient with neck of femur fracture, hemiarthroplasty is the treatment of choice.

choices.text: Scapular region and neck
Trunk and shoulder
Perineum and leg
Face and neck

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below the colored area. Which of the following structures are affected in a lesion to this area? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perineum and leg

 

The colored area in the sagittal section of the brain corresponds to the paracentral lobule, which is located on the medial surface of the brain. This region is responsible for the sensory and motor innervation of the perineum and leg areas.

 

Lesions in the paracentral lobule can lead to sensory and motor deficits in these regions. Bilateral involvement of this area can result in urinary incontinence due to loss of control over the muscles involved in bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scapular region and neck: These areas are innervated by regions in the lateral aspect of the motor and sensory cortices, not the medial paracentral lobule.

 

Option B. Trunk and shoulder: Similar to option A, these regions are controlled by the lateral portions of the motor and sensory cortices.

 

Option D. Face and neck: These are controlled by the lower parts of the motor and sensory cortices located laterally, not medially in the paracentral lobule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The paracentral lobule provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineum and legs. Lesions in this area can affect these regions and potentially lead to urinary incontinence.

questions.text: The surface landmark indicated by the arrow in the image corresponds to the level of which thoracic vertebra? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fourth and Fifth

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the above image represents the sternal angle (Angle of Louis), which corresponds to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc.

The "angle of Louis," also known as the "sternal angle" or "manubriosternal joint," is an anatomical landmark located in the chest area. The angle of Louis is located at the junction of two important anatomical structures:

 

  • The manubrium of the sternum: This is the uppermost part of the sternum (breastbone) and is shaped like a flat, triangular bone.
  • The body of the sternum: This is the long, flat portion of the sternum that extends downward from the manubrium.

 

Clinical Significance: The angle of Louis is a clinically significant reference point because it corresponds to the level of several important anatomical structures:

It is located at the approximate level of the second rib anteriorly. This makes it useful for counting ribs and identifying rib fractures or landmarks during clinical examinations.

It is also close to the carina of the trachea, which is a critical point in the respiratory system where the trachea divides into the left and right main bronchi.

The angle of Louis serves as a reference for the superior border of the heart and is used in clinical assessments such as cardiac auscultation.Top of Form

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) First and Second Thoracic Vertebrae (T1 and T2): The first thoracic vertebra (T1) is located just below the seventh cervical vertebra (C7). It marks the transition from the cervical spine to the thoracic spine. The second thoracic vertebra (T2) is located just below T1 and continues the thoracic spine.

 

Option B) Second and Third Thoracic Vertebrae (T2 and T3): These vertebrae are adjacent to each other, with T2 immediately below T1 and T3 following T2.

 

Option D) Fifth and sixth Thoracic Vertebrae ( T5 and T6): This option suggests that the arrow corresponds to the region between the fifth and sixth thoracic vertebrae which is lower than the marked arrow in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Sternal angle / Angle of Louis -
    • Between Manubrium & Body of sternum
    • Lies at level of Lower border of T4

choices.text: Acute respiratory distress syndrome
Acute kidney injury

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in DKA? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebral edema

 

Cerebral edema is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), particularly in children. During the treatment of DKA, rapid shifts in serum osmolality occur when blood glucose levels are lowered too quickly with insulin therapy. Initially, the patient's serum osmolality is high due to hyperglycemia. Rapid correction of blood glucose levels can lead to a decrease in serum osmolality, while the intracellular fluid (ICF) osmolality remains high. This osmotic imbalance causes water to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) into the intracellular space, resulting in cerebral edema (MC cause of death).

 

Second MCC of death is Cardiac arrythmias due to potassium disturbance – Hyperkalemia at presentation and Hypokalemia after Starting Insulin Therapy, due to the shift of potassium into cells as blood glucose levels are reduced, which affect cardiac function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory distress syndrome: While it is a serious condition, it is not a common cause of mortality in DKA.

 

Option B. Cardiac arrhythmia: Although cardiac arrhythmias due to potassium disturbances (hyperkalemia at presentation and hypokalemia during treatment) are significant, they are not the most common cause of death in DKA.

 

Option D. Acute kidney injury: This can occur in DKA but is not the primary cause of mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis, especially during the treatment phase when rapid shifts in osmolality occur.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female suffers from wheezing, cough every year at the same period of time. Degranulation of which cells will be responsible for these types of findings? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cells

 

Degranulation of Mast cell will be responsible for these type of findings

 

It is an example of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction involves immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen. This results in mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eosinophil: Eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections but do not mediate the degranulation process.

 

Option C. IgE: IgE is involved in the process but does not itself degranulate; it binds to mast cells which then degranulate.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions and do not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Degranulation of mast cells, mediated by IgE antibodies, is responsible for the symptoms observed in type I hypersensitivity reactions such as seasonal allergies.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in given barium follow-through of small intestine.(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

  • Jejunum identification: Jejunum has valves of Kerkring (Valvulae conniventes)
  • Complete mucosal folds extending through lumen of jejunum: Feathery appearance of jejunum
  • Ileum identification: Featureless loops - smooth bowel loop without any folds
  • Colon identification: Incomplete mucosal folds called as haustrations
  • For Normal Bowel Rotation: D-J flexure should be towards the left of midline and on the same plane as duodenal bulb which is L1 / transpyloric plane (if not: sign of malrotation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ileum: Characterized by featureless loops with smooth bowel loops without any folds, which are not seen in the marked area.

 

Option C. Colon: Identified by incomplete mucosal folds called haustrations, which are different from the continuous folds seen in the jejunum.

 

Option D. Duodenum: Located proximal to the jejunum and has a different radiographic appearance, typically not showing the extensive mucosal folds of the jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The jejunum can be identified in imaging by the presence of valvulae conniventes creating a feathery appearance, distinguishing it from the ileum and colon.

questions.text: A man lives with his pregnant wife and a child under 3 years old. His brother and his wife are staying with them for a month. How should this family be categorized? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nuclear family

 

A nuclear family, also known as an elementary or unitary family, consists of a married couple and their children who are still regarded as dependents. In this scenario, the core members are the man, his pregnant wife, and their young child, fitting the definition of a nuclear family.

 

Even though the man's brother and his wife are temporarily staying with them, this does not change the fundamental structure of the family. The temporary presence of additional relatives does not convert a nuclear family into an extended or joint family unless these additional members become permanent residents and contribute to the common household in a sustained manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extended family: An extended family includes additional relatives living together permanently. In this case, the brother and his wife are not permanent residents.

 

Option C. Joint family: A joint family consists of multiple married couples and their children living together permanently, holding property in common, and typically being managed by the senior male member. This structure includes familial relations that enjoy primacy over marital relations, which is not applicable here due to the temporary nature of the brother’s stay.

 

Option D. Third generation: A three-generation family includes representatives from three generations living together in one household. This scenario does not include a third generation (e.g., grandparents).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nuclear family consists of parents and their children, even if other relatives are temporarily staying with them.

questions.text: A postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contracted muscles but no primary relaxation. This can be called as? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cadaveric spasm

 

Cadaveric spasm:

 

  • Also called Instantaneous Rigor
  • Continuation of muscle contraction after death with no primary flaccidity. The muscles that were contracted during life remains so after death
  • Instantaneous onset (Immediately after death)
  • Only muscles of hand are involved
  • Intensity of muscle contraction – Extreme
  • Mechanism is not known
  • Medicolegal Importance of Cadaveric spasm:
    • Manner of Death – e.g., Dead body with gun shot wound in head, tightly holding gun in exact position suggests Suicide.
    • Cause of Death – e.g., Grass or weed tightly held in hand in a body in water suggests Antemortem Drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rigor mortis: This is the stiffening and shortening of muscle fibers due to ATP depletion. It typically sets in 2-4 hours after death and goes through a stage of primary relaxation (flaccidity) before muscle stiffening.

 

Option C. Algor mortis: This refers to the cooling of the body after death.

 

Option D. Livor mortis: This refers to the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm involves the immediate and extreme contraction of muscles without primary relaxation, occurring right at the moment of death, and is often significant in determining the circumstances surrounding the death.

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 87

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metoprolol

 

Metoprolol, specifically the succinate formulation, is a beta-blocker that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Beta-blockers like metoprolol, bisoprolol, and carvedilol improve survival, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms in heart failure patients.

 

Note - Drugs that reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, in a recommended order of use:

 

  1. First Line Drug: ACE inhibitors helps to relax blood vessels and improve blood flow, thereby decreasing the heart's workload.
  2. Second Line Drug: Beta blockers worked by slowing the heart rate and reducing blood pressure, which decreases the heart's demand for oxygen.
  3. Third Line Drug: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone helps to remove excess sodium and water from the body, relieving pressure on the heart while preserving potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that provides symptomatic relief by reducing fluid overload but does not reduce mortality in heart failure patients.

 

Option C. Prazosin: An alpha-blocker used for hypertension but not shown to reduce mortality in heart failure.

 

Option D. Torsemide: Another loop diuretic similar to furosemide, effective for symptomatic relief but not for reducing mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol succinate, are essential in reducing mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

 

Note –

 

Drugs That Reduce Mortality in Heart Failure

 

  1. ARNIs (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitors):
    • Examples: Sacubitril/Valsartan
    • Currently the first-line treatment, considered superior to ACE inhibitors and ARBs when available.
       
  2. ACE Inhibitors (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors) and ARBs (Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers):
    • Considered equally effective in efficacy; used when ARNIs are not available.
       
  3. Beta Blockers:
    • Specific agents highlighted: Metoprolol, Bisoprolol, and Carvedilol.
       
  4. MRS (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Examples: Spironolactone and Eplerenone.
       
  5. SGLT2 Inhibitors (Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 inhibitors):
    • Emerging class of drugs also showing benefits in heart failure management.
       
  6. Hydralazine and Isosorbide Dinitrate (HISDN):
    • Noted specifically for proven benefits in African American patients with heart failure.

 

Drugs with No Impact on Mortality

 

  1. Diuretics:
    • Including loop and thiazide diuretics, noted to not improve survival but are used primarily for symptom management and fluid regulation.
       
  2. Calcium Channel Blockers and Nitrates:
    • Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.

choices.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face
Ipsilateral lower half of the face
Contralateral lower half of the face

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

 

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic lower motor neuron type of facial nerve palsy that results in paralysis of both the upper and lower halves of the face on the same side (ipsilateral) as the lesion. It is characterized by sudden onset facial muscle weakness or paralysis that affects one side of the face.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face: Would suggest a central (upper motor neuron) lesion.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral lower half of the face: Indicates a central lesion affecting the facial nerve pathway above the level of the facial nucleus.

 

Option D. Contralateral lower half of the face: Also indicates a central lesion affecting the corticobulbar tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell's palsy involves ipsilateral paralysis of both the upper and lower halves of the face due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the red arrow in the given MRI image. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Internal capsule

 

Explanation:

 

Above marked structure is internal capsule.

 

The internal capsule is a critical white matter structure in the brain. It is located deep within the cerebral hemispheres and separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus. The internal capsule contains axon tracts that serve as major pathways for communication between different parts of the brain, including the cortex, thalamus, and various subcortical nuclei.

 

The internal capsule is often subdivided into three parts: the anterior limb, genu (knee), and posterior limb. Each limb contains different types of nerve fibers that transmit motor, sensory, and other information between the cerebral cortex and other brain regions.

 

The internal capsule consists of several parts and is V-shaped when cut horizontally, in a transverse plane.

 

  • the bend in the V is called the genu
  • the anterior limb or crus anterius is the part in front of the genu, between the head of the caudate nucleus and the lenticular nucleus
  • the posterior limb or crus posterius is the part behind the genu, between the thalamus and lenticular nucleus
  • the retrolenticular portion is caudal to the lenticular nucleus and carries the optic radiation (from medial part of lateral geniculate nucleus) also known as the geniculocalcarine tract. The fiber from lateral part of lateral geniculate nucleus is carried through the retrolenticular portion.
  • the sublenticular portion is beneath the lenticular nucleus and are tracts involved in the auditory pathway from the medial geniculate nucleus to the primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42)

 

Lesions or damage to the internal capsule can result in various neurological deficits, including motor and sensory impairments.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. External Capsule: The external capsule is another white matter structure located in the brain, but it is less well-known than the internal capsule. It is located lateral to the putamen and globus pallidus and is considered part of the deep gray matter of the basal ganglia. The exact function and significance of the external capsule are still a subject of ongoing research, and its role in brain function is not as well-defined as that of the internal capsule.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe: The caudate lobe, also known as the caudate nucleus, is a part of the basal ganglia. It is a C-shaped structure located within each cerebral hemisphere. The caudate nucleus is involved in various functions, including motor control, cognition, and emotional processing. It is interconnected with other basal ganglia nuclei and plays a role in regulating movement.
