Lesions or dysfunction in the caudate nucleus can lead to movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease or Huntington's disease.

 

Option D. Globus Pallidus: The globus pallidus is another component of the basal ganglia. It is divided into two segments: the external segment (GPe) and the internal segment (GPi). The globus pallidus is involved in motor control and plays a role in modulating motor signals sent from the cortex to the thalamus. Dysfunctions of the globus pallidus can result in movement disorders, including dystonia and Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule's strategic location and structure facilitate critical communication pathways in the brain, making its integrity vital for normal motor and sensory functions. Damage to this area can lead to severe neurological deficits.

questions.text: What is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crown rump length

 

Explanation:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Biparietal diameter, B. Head circumference and D. Abdominal circumference are parameters useful in second trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 84

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dermatomyositis

 

The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis. The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis

 

The following list includes several dermatomyositis symptoms:

 

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules that can appear over the elbow, knee, dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.
  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Screening:  Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

 

Diagnosis:  Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Gottron's papule, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign are associated with anti-Mi2 antibodies.

 

Mechanics hand, Myositis, and ILD (Interstitial Lung Disease) are associated with anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo-1) antibodies.

 

Prognosis: The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • Features: SLE is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a malar "butterfly" rash, arthritis, and a variety of systemic symptoms. It can affect multiple organs, including the skin, kidneys, and nervous system.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle pain and inflammation can be a part of SLE, the described presentation with a clear muscle weakness pattern, especially in the context of ovarian cancer, is more suggestive of dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Features: Systemic sclerosis (or scleroderma) primarily affects the skin, leading to thickening and hardening. It can also cause problems in blood vessels, the digestive tract, and other internal organs.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While systemic sclerosis can affect various organs and can cause muscle weakness indirectly due to skin tightening, the described presentation is more specific to dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Cushing syndrome:

 

  • Features: Cushing syndrome is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. Symptoms include weight gain, purple striae on the skin, facial puffiness, and thinning of the skin.

 

 

Cushing syndrome: Striae seen

 

  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle weakness can be a symptom of Cushing syndrome, the absence of other hallmark features and the association with ovarian cancer make dermatomyositis a more likely diagnosis in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatomyositis is diagnosed by the presence of heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules, and proximal muscle weakness, and consider its association with underlying malignancies in adult patients.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 53.5, 53.6 and 53.8, 56.12-15

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 2914

questions.text: A factory worker was brought to the emergency room after consuming wood spirt with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurred vision. What treatment will you give the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fomepizole

 

Given case is of methanol poisoning and can be managed by giving Fomepizole.

 

Methanol Poisoning

 

Symptoms – Occur 12-24 hours after ingestion.

 

Patient usually presents with nausea, vomiting, abdomen cramps, spirit-like smell from mouth and nostrils. Headache, dizziness, vertigo, restlessness, dyspnea are other features. Pupils are fixed and dilated leading to blurred vision (snowfield vision). In later stages, patient lands up in metabolic acidosis.

 

Treatment –

 

  • Gastric Lavage by 5% NaHCO3 solution.
  • Oral NaHCO3 to combat acidosis
  • Calcium folinate/leucovorin to reduce blood format levels.
  • Administration of ethanol as competitive antagonist
  • Antidote: 4-methylpyrazole (fomepizole) is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase.
  • Hemodialysis in case of severe poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flumazenil is an antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option B. N-Acetyl cysteine is an antidote for Paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option C. Naloxone is an antidote for Opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fomepizole is the appropriate treatment for methanol poisoning as it inhibits the conversion of methanol to its toxic metabolites by blocking alcohol dehydrogenase.

choices.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.text: 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic TB was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated miliary tuberculosis commonly seen in the elderly population. The term "cryptic" means hidden, indicating that the disease does not present with obvious clinical signs typically associated with TB. This includes a negative skin tuberculin test and no visible evidence of TB on a chest X-ray.

 

Microbiological confirmation of TB in these patients is challenging and often not possible with standard imaging techniques. Modern guidelines suggest using advanced imaging modalities like PET CT scans to detect enlarged lymph nodes in thoracic or abdominal areas, which can be sampled for confirmation. However, even with these methods, microbiological diagnosis is still difficult (DD – Malignancy).

 

In such cases, empirical anti-tubercular treatment is started, and diagnosis is confirmed based on the patient's response to therapy and resolution of symptoms and lymph node enlargement over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB does not typically present with a positive skin tuberculin test or obvious chest X-ray findings. The hidden nature of this form of TB means both tests are likely to be negative.

 

Option C. Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray: Incorrect. As mentioned, cryptic TB results in a negative skin tuberculin test, not a positive one, because the disease does not produce a strong immune response detectable by this test.

 

Option D. Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB is characterized by a lack of clear imaging evidence of TB, making a positive chest X-ray an unlikely finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated tuberculosis common in the elderly, characterized by a negative skin tuberculin test and no obvious imaging evidence of TB. Diagnosis is often confirmed through empirical treatment and advanced imaging techniques.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presented in OPD as shown below. She is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

Fungal Infection that can happen in uncontrolled DM – Mucormycosis, Aspergillosis.

 

Mucormycosis:

 

  • Caused by mucor, rhizopus.
  • Invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue → into orbit → cranium
  • Black eschars are formed
  • Can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and antifungal medication (Amphotericin-B).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis: This fungal infection can cause sinusitis but usually doesn't present with the rapid, aggressive invasion characteristic of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Foreign Body and Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: These are less likely given the typical presentation and risk factors, and they don't typically present with the aggressive necrotic features seen in mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetic patients presenting with black necrotic tissue and signs of invasive fungal infection in the nasal or orbital area, mucormycosis is the most likely diagnosis, requiring immediate and aggressive treatment to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is used for the purpose of disinfection, to create the plasma which of the following substance is used? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Plasma sterilization is done with hydrogen peroxide. The mechanism of action is a free radical injury with hydrogen peroxide. Plasma sterilization is commonly used for sterilizing medical instruments that are sensitive to heat and moisture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethylene oxide: Incorrect. Ethylene oxide is used for sterilizing equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, and dental instruments, but it is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option B. Glutaraldehyde: Incorrect. Glutaraldehyde is used for high-level disinfection of medical equipment like cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, and plastic endotracheal tubes but is not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Formaldehyde: Incorrect. Formaldehyde is used for fumigation of operating theaters, wards, and laboratories but is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma sterilization: Is done with hydrogen peroxide, which creates reactive species that effectively sterilize medical instruments through free radical injury.
  • Ethylene oxide - Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments etc.
  • Gluteraldehyde - Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, Plastic ETT, face masks etc.
  • Formaldehyde - Fumigation of operating theater's, wards and labs.

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding level of uterus just after delivery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Below umbilicus

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Below pubic symphysis: This is not accurate immediately after delivery as the uterus is still quite large and palpable above the pubic symphysis.

 

Option B. Above pubic symphysis: While this is true in a general sense postpartum, it is not specific enough to accurately describe the position immediately after delivery.

 

Option D. Above umbilicus: This is incorrect because the uterus immediately after delivery is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, not above it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, equivalent to the size it would be at 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: D. C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

questions.text: Testosterone is secreted by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cells

 

Leydig cells are specialized cells located within the testes that are responsible for the production of testosterone, the primary male sex hormone. This process is regulated by luteinizing hormone (LH), which is released from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Pituitary: Incorrect because the anterior pituitary secretes LH and FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone), which regulate the function of Leydig and Sertoli cells, respectively, but it does not directly secrete testosterone.

 

Option C. From the conversion of dihydrotestosterone: Incorrect as dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is actually derived from testosterone via the action of the enzyme 5α-reductase, primarily in peripheral tissues.

 

Option D. From Sertoli cells: Incorrect because Sertoli cells produce inhibin and androgen-binding protein under the stimulation of FSH, not testosterone.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Two-Cell–Two-Gonadotropin Theory: This theory explains the interaction between Leydig and Sertoli cells in the testes. LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, while FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to produce inhibin and androgen-binding globulin, which help regulate the effects of testosterone on spermatogenesis.
  • Negative Feedback Regulation: Testosterone exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary to inhibit the secretion of LH, and inhibin specifically inhibits FSH secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone is primarily produced by Leydig cells in the testes, under the regulation of LH from the anterior pituitary. This hormone is crucial for the development of male reproductive tissues, secondary sexual characteristics, and several other physiological functions such as muscle mass maintenance, bone density, and mood regulation.

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. On further testing Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody is positive, what will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Goodpasture syndrome

 

  • Given clinical scenario is suggestive of good pasture syndrome as patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis along with Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody.
  • It is type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • It belongs to type 1 RPGN
  • The autoantibodies are directed against the alpha 3 chain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group. This immunofluorescence pattern shows positivity with antibody to IgG and has a smooth, diffuse, linear pattern that is characteristic for deposition of glomerular basement membrane antibody with Goodpasture syndrome. Serologic testing for anti-GBM in patient serum is often positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glomerular nephropathy: This is a general term for diseases affecting the glomeruli, but it does not specifically fit the provided clinical scenario.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis: While Goodpasture syndrome is a type of glomerulonephritis, the specific presence of anti-GBM antibodies and the combination of hematuria and hemoptysis point directly to Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. Alport’s syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by glomerulonephritis, end-stage kidney disease, and hearing loss, and it does not typically present with anti-GBM antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, hematuria, and hemoptysis, and is a type II hypersensitivity reaction associated with type I Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to OPD with rashes around his neck region, diarrhoea from the last 3 days, and recent forgetfulness. He is hailing from the northern states in India and is mainly surviving on a maize rich diet. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is most likely associated with his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms - dermatitis (especially in areas exposed to sunlight), diarrhea, and dementia (forgetfulness) - are characteristic of pellagra, which is caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is often associated with diets high in maize (corn), as maize is a poor source of niacin and lacks the amino acid tryptophan, which the body can use to synthesize niacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency leads to beriberi, which presents with symptoms like weight loss, emotional disturbances, impaired sensory perception, weakness, and pain in the limbs, and periods of irregular heart rate. While neurological symptoms can occur, the overall clinical picture doesn't align with the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can cause ariboflavinosis, symptoms of which include sore throat, hyperemia, and edema of the pharyngeal and oral mucosa, cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and anemia. However, these symptoms are not as aligned with the patient's presentation as the symptoms of another vitamin deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to seborrheic dermatitis, microcytic anemia, electroencephalographic abnormalities, convulsions, and peripheral neuropathy. While some symptoms may overlap, the specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia is more indicative of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Casal’s Necklace shown in the figure occur due to Niacin deficiency (Pellagra)
  • Pellagra is seen in people whose staple diet is maize.
  • In maize, niacin is present but in a bound form and is unavailable to the body.
  • Symptoms of pellagra:
    • Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace.
    • Diarrhea
    • Dementia, delirium, irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, ataxia, and spasticity are seen.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557749/

choices.text: Encephalopathy, AST, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time
Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of these are the components of Child Pugh score? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time.

 

Encephalitis, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time are the components of Child Pugh score

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of the Child-Pugh score include encephalopathy, ascites, bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time (INR). This scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improve as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable cause of her headaches? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudotumor cerebri

 

Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is characterized by increased intracranial pressure without a detectable cause on imaging. The patient's headaches worsening in a recumbent position, along with papilledema, are classic signs. The history of taking oral contraceptives is a known risk factor for this condition.

 

Diagnostic confirmation typically involves elevated CSF opening pressure (Headache, papilledema) with normal imaging.

 

Treatment –

 

First-Line Treatment: Astazolamide is the treatment of choice. If astazolamide is not suitable or effective, topiramate can be used as an alternative.

 

Management of Refractory Cases: If the condition is refractory to medication (i.e., persistent headache or worsening visual field defects), surgical options may be considered.

 

  • Surgical Options:
  • Lumboperitoneal shunt: This procedure diverts cerebrospinal fluid to reduce intracranial pressure.
  • Optic nerve sheath fenestration: This surgery involves making an opening in the sheath around the optic nerve to relieve pressure, potentially preserving vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myasthenia gravis: This condition typically causes muscle weakness and fatigue, not headaches.

 

Option B. Temporal arteritis: This condition occurs more frequently in older individuals and presents with a unilateral, throbbing headache, often accompanied by other symptoms such as jaw claudication and visual disturbances.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: While migraines can cause severe headaches, they usually include symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, aura, photophobia, and phonophobia, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudotumor cerebri should be suspected in patients with chronic headaches that worsen when lying down, especially if they have papilledema and are on oral contraceptives.

questions.text: A Patient is infected with a dimorphic fungus which involves the subcutaneous layers, identify the organism responsible for it? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix

 

The clinical presentation suggests an infection with a dimorphic fungus that primarily affects the subcutaneous layers.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus known for causing subcutaneous infections. It spreads via lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes and is commonly associated with "rose gardener's disease."

 

Key Points about Sporothrix schenckii:

 

  • Dimorphic Nature: Sporothrix schenckii can exist in both mold and yeast forms.
  • Subcutaneous Infection: Typically causes chronic skin infections and spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Common Name: Often referred to as "rose gardener's disease" due to its association with thorn pricks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Incorrect. Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus but typically causes pulmonary and disseminated infections, not primarily subcutaneous infections.

 

Option B. Chromoblastomycosis: Incorrect. Chromoblastomycosis is caused by several dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungi, such as Fonsecaea pedrosoi, and is not dimorphic.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, which is not a dimorphic fungus and typically causes polypoidal masses in mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes subcutaneous infections, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease," and spreads via lymphatic channels.

 

Examples of dimorphic fungi - Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: An accused died in lock up during the police interrogation. Enquiry in this case will be done by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Judicial magistrate

 

Enquiry in a case of death of police custody/firing will be done by Executive magistrate.

 

Please remember that Custodial death is the only condition where inquest is mandatory to be done only by judicial Magistrate.

 

In India two types of Inquest are held- Police and Magistrate.

 

Magistrate inquest is of further two types- Executive magistrate and judicial Magistrate.

 

Inquest Sections:

 

  1. 174 CrPc: Police Inquest (It is the commonest inquest and Done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc)
  2. 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest. It is of two types:
  3. Executive Magistrate:  
    • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage 
    • Exhumation. 
  4. Judicial Magistrate: Done in Custodial Deaths

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Executive Magistrate: Handles inquests for dowry deaths and exhumations but not custodial deaths.

 

Option C. Police IG (Inspector General): Does not conduct inquests; senior police officer overseeing police operations.

 

Option D. Head Constable: Can conduct police inquests but not mandated for custodial deaths, which require a Judicial Magistrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

 

 

Ref: KSN Reddy, Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd Ed., p. 132

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

 

Explanation:

 

The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.

 

Contraindications to Oxytocin:

 

  • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart disease in mother: Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Premature labour: Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.

 

Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226th edition

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to assess the blood stain? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barberio’s test

 

Barberio test is a microchemical test for Semen

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Additional Information

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN

 

1) Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a resource-limited setting presents to a local health camp with complaints of chronic eye irritation and a gritty feeling in her eyes for the past few months. On examination, conjunctival scarring and inward turning of the eyelashes are noted. The physician suspects trachoma and recalls the recommended WHO's SAFE strategy for managing trachoma in endemic areas. What does the "S" in the SAFE strategy stand for in this context? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Surgery 

 

The "S" in the SAFE strategy stands for Surgery, specifically for the correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion.

 

The SAFE Strategy for Trachoma:

 

S – Surgery (for correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion)

A – Antibiotic (Azithromycin)

F – Facial cleanliness to prevent disease transmission

E - Environmental change to increase access to water and sanitation.

 

Trachoma (rough eye) 

 

A microbial infection of the eye caused due to the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is a contagious disease, that can be easily spread by direct contact with an affected person, by means of their eyes, eyelids, nasal and throat secretions and exchange of used towels and handkerchiefs. 

 

The risk factors of trachoma are poor sanitation, crowded living conditions and lack of routine hygiene practices due to poverty. Moreover, trachoma commonly occurs in children between the ages of 2-5 years, more frequently in adult women than men and in surroundings where flies are rampant, as these can serve as vectors to transmit the bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "S" in the WHO's SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery.

 

Additional Information

 

Trachoma Treatment

 

  • Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20 mg/kg oral stat
  • Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma:
    • District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
    • District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
    • District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary
  • Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO]
    • Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age
    • Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days

 

India declared ‘Trachoma-Free’ in December 2017.

choices.text: Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba → Lochia Rubra
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba → Lochia Serosa

questions.text: Mark the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium: (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba

 

Explanation:

 

Lochia is vaginal discharge after delivery.

 

It is composed of sloughed off decidua, blood, necrotic debris and secretions of the cervixand vagina.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of lochia during the puerperium is Lochia Rubra (red, first 3-4 days), Lochia Serosa (yellowish-brownish, 5-9 days), and Lochia Alba (white, lasts 10-28 days).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of New York Heart Association (NYHA) does he belong to? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II

 

NYHA Class II heart failure is characterized by slight limitation of physical activity. The patient is comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or angina. The key detail here is that ordinary activities cause symptoms, fitting the description of Class II.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: Patients have no limitation of physical activity; ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms.

 

Option C. Class III: Patients have marked limitation of physical activity; less than ordinary activity causes symptoms, but they are comfortable at rest.

 

Option D. Class IV: Patients have symptoms even at rest and are unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NYHA class –most powerful prognostic marker of HF.

 

  • Class 1 - asymptomatic with ordinary activities
  • Class 2 - symptomatic with ordinary activities, not at rest
  • Class 3 - symptomatic with < ordinary activity
  • Class 4 - symptomatic at rest

questions.text: Identify the type of epithelium shown in the given histological image. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transitional epithelium

 

The image above depicts transitional epithelium.

 

  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized type of stratified epithelium found primarily in the urinary system, particularly in the urinary bladder, ureters, and urethra. It is also present in parts of the male reproductive system.
  • This epithelium is unique because it can change its shape and stretch as needed. When the organ it lines, such as the bladder, is empty, the cells appear cuboidal or columnar. As the organ fills, the cells become more flattened (squamous) to accommodate the increased volume.
  • The ability of transitional epithelium to stretch and change shape allows the urinary system to store and expel urine efficiently without damaging the lining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratified Cuboidal Epithelium:

 

  • Stratified cuboidal epithelium consists of multiple layers of cube-shaped cells. It is relatively rare in the human body and is found in specific locations, such as certain ducts of exocrine glands and parts of the eye's retina.
  • This type of epithelium provides protection and secretion, with the cube-shaped cells in the basal layer and progressively flattened cells toward the surface.

 

Option C. Stratified Squamous Epithelium:

 

Stratified squamous epithelium is one of the most common types of epithelium in the body and can be further classified into two main types: non-keratinized and keratinized.

 

  • Non-keratinized Stratified Squamous Epithelium: This type is found in moist environments, such as the lining of the oral cavity, esophagus, vagina, and anus. It provides protection against abrasion and chemical damage.
  • Keratinized Stratified Squamous Epithelium: This type is found in the epidermis (outermost layer of the skin). It contains layers of cells that produce the protein keratin, which provides waterproofing and protection against environmental factors.

 

Option D. Pseudostratified Columnar Epithelium:

 

  • Pseudostratified columnar epithelium appears to be stratified but is actually composed of a single layer of cells, with their nuclei at varying heights. It is commonly found in the respiratory tract, particularly in the lining of the trachea and bronchi.
  • This type of epithelium has cilia on the surface of its cells, which are important for moving mucus and trapped particles out of the airways. It also contains goblet cells that produce mucus to trap debris and microorganisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transitional epithelium is crucial for the proper function of the urinary system, accommodating fluctuations in volume while protecting underlying tissues from urine’s potential chemical harm.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done and it showed lymphocytes predominantly, Glucose 50 mg/dL, and protein 300 mg/dL. Gram-staining was negative. CXR of the patient shows upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculous meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of meningitis, including fever, neck rigidity, and abnormal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings. The CSF shows lymphocyte predominance, low glucose (50 mg/dL), and high protein (300 mg/dL), which are hallmarks of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Additionally, the chest X-ray (CXR) revealing upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement further supports the diagnosis of tuberculosis, as these are common findings in pulmonary tuberculosis that can spread to the meninges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial meningitis: Typically presents with neutrophil predominance in CSF rather than lymphocytes. The CSF glucose is also usually low, but the clinical and radiological findings here are not supportive of a bacterial etiology.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis: Can present similarly with lymphocytic CSF and abnormal glucose/protein levels. However, the CXR findings of upper lobe infiltrates and hilar lymph node enlargement strongly suggest tuberculosis rather than a fungal infection.

 

Option D. Viral meningitis: Usually presents with normal glucose levels in the CSF, as viruses do not metabolize glucose. The patient’s low CSF glucose level makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with lymphocyte-predominant CSF, low glucose, high protein, and associated pulmonary findings such as upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement, tuberculous meningitis should be highly suspected.

questions.text: The following tzanck smear finding is seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV

 

Given tzanck smear finding is seen in HSV

 

The Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, which are characteristic of HSV infection. This test is commonly used to diagnose herpes infections, including HSV-1 and HSV-2, and can also detect varicella-zoster virus (the cause of chickenpox and shingles).

 

It used to diagnose some skin blistering disorders for ex: Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chicken pox: Incorrect. While Tzanck smears can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster virus infections, the specific question and provided image are more indicative of HSV.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. HIV is not typically diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HIV diagnosis is usually confirmed with blood tests, including ELISA and Western blot.

 

Option D. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is not diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HPV diagnosis usually involves DNA tests and Pap smears for cervical lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck smears are useful for diagnosing skin infections caused by herpes viruses, including HSV-1 and HSV-2. The presence of multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass chromatin is a hallmark of HSV infection.

choices.text: Medial nasal and lateral nasal process

questions.text: The congenital anomaly shown in the image results from the failure of fusion between which two embryonic prominences? (FMGE JANUARY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medial nasal and maxillary process

 

Explanation:

 

Above image is showing Cleft lip; it is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal and maxillary process.

 

In embryonic development, the face forms from a series of swellings and processes. The medial nasal process contributes to the formation of the middle part of the upper lip, philtrum, and part of the nasal septum. The maxillary process gives rise to the upper jaw and the lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Medial Nasal and Lateral Nasal Process: The medial nasal process and lateral nasal process are both involved in the formation of the nose and upper lip. The medial nasal process contributes to the middle part of the upper lip and part of the nasal septum. The lateral nasal process forms the sides of the nose.

 

Option C)  Maxillary and Mandibular Process: The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip. The mandibular process, on the other hand, forms the lower jaw or mandible. These two processes are essential for the formation of the upper and lower jaws, respectively.

 

Option D) Lateral Nasal and Maxillary Process: The lateral nasal process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the sides of the nose. The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, forms the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLEFT LIP VS CLEFT LIP AND CLEFT PALATE.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

Explanation

 

Ectopic pregnancy refers to implantation occurring outside the endometrial cavity.

 

Sites of implantation

 

 

Uterine (.5%) such as cervical (1%), caesarean scar ectopic <1%)

 

Management of tubal ectopic may be medical or surgical: medical management maybe considered if the patient is haemodynamically stable , foetal cardiac activity absent, beta HCG level less than 5000 , size of gestational sac less than 4 cm .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Accounts for 18% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option C. Isthmus: Accounts for 25% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option D. Interstitial portion: Accounts for 2% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Management of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy:

 

Management may be medical or surgical:

 

  • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 55% of cases.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207

questions.text: A city school board is determining the minimum classroom space per student for safety and well-being. What is the minimum per capita space that should be available for each child in a school classroom based on public health guidelines? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. > 10 Sqft

 

The minimum per capita space required for each child in a school classroom is greater than 10 square feet, ensuring adequate space for safety and comfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School health service guidelines recommendations are:

 

  • One class room for maximum 40 students
  • Minus type desk
  • Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area
  • 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student.
  • Natural light from left side
  • Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting.
  • School health examination every 6 months.
  • Walls should be white in colour.
  • Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has developed white patches on his anterior incisors, which have recently turned brown. His mother is concerned about the cause. Which element is most likely responsible for this discoloration? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fluorine

 

Dental fluorosis occurs when excess fluoride is ingested during first 7 years of life (years of tooth calcification). It occurs at levels above 1.5 mg/litre intake. It is characterized by ’Mottling’, which is best seen on incisors of upper jaw. 

 

Definition of Suspect case of Dental Fluorosis (in children): Any case with a history of residing in an endemic area along with one or both of the followings:

 

  • Chalky white teeth/white spots on the white enamel surface
  • Transverse yellow, brown/black bands or spots on the enamel surface

 

 

Ideally in water there should be 0.5 to 0.8 mg/l of fluorine (India). The major source of fluorine in human is Drinking water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorine: Chlorine is used for water disinfection and is not associated with dental discoloration.

 

Option C. Iodine: Iodine deficiency can cause goiter and other thyroid-related issues but not dental discoloration.

 

Option D. Iron: Excessive iron can cause dark stains on teeth but does not cause the white to brown transition seen in dental fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dental fluorosis is caused by the ingestion of excess fluoride during the early years of life, leading to characteristic tooth discoloration.

 

Additional Information

 

Fluorine is a double edged sword. 

 

  • Dental Fluorosis occurs when Fluorine level is > 0.8mg/l in water. In that case, the water should be defluoridated using Nalgonda technique. 
  • If the level of fluorine is < 0.5mg/l, then the fluorine deficiency will lead to Dental Caries. In that case, fluorine supplementation should be done.
    • Level > 1.5 ppm: Dental fluorosis (mottling)
    • Level 3.0 - 6.0 ppm: Skeletal fluorosis
    • Level > 10.0 ppm: Crippling fluorosis

 

Fluorosis endemic area: Habitation/village/town having fluoride level > 1.5 ppm in drinking water. Villages classification based on the level of fluoride content:

questions.text: Fluid of choice for a child in shock with severe acute malnutrition is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ringer lactate + 5% dextrose


In the management of a child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) who is in shock, it is crucial to select the appropriate intravenous (IV) fluid to correct fluid and electrolyte imbalances while also addressing the metabolic needs of the child. The fluid of choice in this scenario is Ringer lactate + 5% dextrose. This combination provides essential electrolytes and glucose, which is critical for children with SAM who are at high risk of hypoglycemia.

 

  • IV Fluids used in SAM with shock:
    • Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose
    • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose
    • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose

 

These fluids help manage both dehydration and electrolyte imbalances while also supplying glucose to prevent or treat hypoglycemia, which is common in children with SAM. The dextrose component is particularly important because children with SAM have depleted glycogen stores and are prone to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: This fluid is not recommend in children.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is another commonly used IV fluid but lacks both dextrose and potassium. It is not the fluid of choice in children with SAM and shock due to its lack of essential glucose and electrolytes needed for these patients.

 

Option D. Ringer lactate: Ringer lactate alone, without dextrose, is not sufficient for managing children with SAM in shock due to the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:


In children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) who are in shock, the fluid of choice is Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose to manage dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and prevent hypoglycemia.

choices.text: Tingling and numbness in peripheral areas

questions.text: Following are the features of Stage of excitement of cocaine except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine bugs

 

Cocaine bugs/Magnan’s Syndrome is a type of hallucination (Formication) seen in cocaine addicts (Chronic Poisoning). Whereas, stage of excitement is seen in acute cocaine poisoning.

 

 

 

Cocaine is obtained from leaves of Erythroxylum cocoa

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeling of well-being: Common in the excitement phase of acute cocaine poisoning.

 

Option C. Tingling and numbness in peripheral areas: A known effect due to local anesthetic properties of cocaine.

 

Option D. Dilated pupil: Cocaine causes mydriasis (dilation of pupils), often seen in the excitement stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine bugs (formication) are associated with chronic cocaine use and hallucinations, whereas the features listed for the excitement stage of acute cocaine poisoning include euphoria, numbness, and dilated pupils but not formication.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is diagnosed with amblyopia in one eye, what will be the best management?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occlusion therapy

 

The best treatment for an amblyopic 3-year-old is occlusion therapy.

Amblyopia is a primary visual pathway abnormality of the eye that affects spatial visual processing during development.

 

The period during which acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved: usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and into the teens for anisometropic amblyopia with good binocular function.

 

Organic disease needs to be excluded before commencing treatment for amblyopia.

 

(i) The most effective treatment: Occlusion of the normal eye, to encourage use of the amblyopic eye. The regimen, depends on the age of the patient and the density of amblyopia.

  • The younger the patient, the more rapid the improvement but the greater the risk of inducing amblyopia in the normal eye. Thus, it is very important to monitor VA regularly in both eyes during treatment.
  • The better the VA at the start of occlusion, the shorter the duration required, usually.
  • If there has been no improvement after 6 months of effective occlusion, further treatment is unlikely to be successful.
  • Patch occlusion is likely to produce a quicker response than atropine.
  • The single greatest barrier to improvement: Poor compliance.

 

(ii) Alternative method: Penalization, in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine.

  • It may work best for mild–moderate amblyopia (6/24 or better), especially when due to anisometropic hypermetropia.
  • Penalization offers the particular advantage of compliance in terms of lesser likelihood of being removed by the child and less psychosocial problems.

 

Occlusion therapy -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone is not recommended for amblyopia as active treatment is necessary to improve visual outcomes during the critical period of visual development.

 

Option C. Refraction with near addition: While appropriate refractive correction is important, it is not sufficient as the sole treatment for amblyopia. Occlusion therapy or penalization is needed to stimulate the amblyopic eye.

 

Option D. Laser surgery: Laser surgery is not an appropriate treatment for amblyopia. It is primarily used for correcting refractive errors or specific eye conditions like retinal issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia is occlusion therapy, which involves covering the normal eye to encourage use and development of the amblyopic eye. Regular monitoring and compliance are essential for successful treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding audit in obstetrics? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Done before analysing outcomes

 

Clinical audit in obstetrics is a method performed to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and consistently improved in line with evidence-based practice. The purpose of an obstetrics audit is to analyze the current level of care and identify areas for improvement. Therefore, it is typically conducted after analyzing outcomes to assess and enhance the quality of care provided. This helps in determining whether the current practices are effective or if changes are needed to improve patient outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improve treatment: This statement is true as clinical audits aim to improve treatment by identifying gaps in current practices and implementing evidence-based solutions to enhance patient care.

 

Option B. Fetal death rate analysis: This is also true. Clinical audits often include analyzing fetal death rates to understand the causes and contributing factors, which can lead to improved strategies to reduce such occurrences.

 

Option C. Improving hospital administration: This statement is correct. Audits can identify administrative issues that affect patient care, thereby helping to streamline processes and improve overall hospital administration and efficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical audits in obstetrics are conducted after analyzing outcomes to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and continuously improved based on evidence-based practices.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of Obstetrics page728-729

questions.text: Which gene is commonly associated with the development of a round blue cell tumor in a child who underwent surgery for ocular malignancy? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rb gene

 

Gene responsible for the tumor development is Rb gene

 

Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14 its mutation seen in retinoblastoma it is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

 

Imp. Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Leukocoria (White pupillary reflex)
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P53 Gene: The P53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in many cancers but not specifically in retinoblastoma.

 

Option C. P57 Gene: P57 is involved in the regulation of cell cycle and growth but is not associated with retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. RET: The RET gene is involved in multiple endocrine neoplasia and medullary thyroid cancer, not retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rb gene mutation is responsible for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: A patient complains of ptosis and increasing muscle weakness by evening. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A patient complaining of ptosis and increased muscle weakness by the evening, that is relieved by Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor Neostigmine is suggestive of Myasthenia Gravis. Myasthenia gravis is an auto-immune disease due to formation of antibodies against the post synaptic Ach receptors. The characteristic features of muscle weakness with activity and improvement with rest are hallmarks in myasthenia.

  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like Neostigmine and Pyridostigmine lead to an increase in the level of Acetylcholine at the receptor sites, which subsequently leads to an improvement in the muscle function.

  • Edrophonium test is used in the diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert-Eaton syndrome: This is an autoimmune disorder that affects the voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic membrane, leading to reduced acetylcholine release. It is often associated with small cell lung cancer. Unlike myasthenia gravis, muscle strength may improve with repeated use in Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: This is an inflammatory myopathy that causes muscle weakness, but it is typically proximal muscle weakness and does not present with ptosis or improvement with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: This is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to demyelination. Symptoms can include muscle weakness, but it typically involves other neurological signs and does not respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by ptosis and muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The diagnosis is supported by the relief of symptoms with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. This condition results from autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta previa: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marginal

 

Given image shows a Type 2 / Marginal Placenta Previa.

 

Other Options A, C, D are explained in the table below

 

OLDER CLASSIFICATION (BROWNE’S CLASSIFICATION)

 

 

 

NEWER CLASSIFICATION (BASED ON TRANSVAGINALSONOGRAPHY)

 

  1. Placenta Previa: Placenta partially or completely covers the internal os.
  2. Low lying placenta: implantation in the lower uterine segment is such that the placental edge does not reach the internal os and remains outside a 2-cm wide perimeter around the os.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low lying: Type 1 / Low Lying Placenta Previa is when the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment of the uterus but stays away from the internal os.

 

Option C. Incomplete: Type 3 / Incomplete Placenta Previa is when the placenta covers the internal os partially.

 

Option D. Complete: Type 4 / Complete Placenta Previa is when the placenta completely covers the internal os.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marginal Placenta Previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the margin of the internal os but not covering it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284, Williams textbook of Obstetrics  24th edition page 800

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic feature of hemolysis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin

 

Characteristic feature of hemolysis is decreased haptoglobin. Serum haptoglobin levels are decreased in hemolytic anemias.

 

There are two Types of hemolysis with following features -  

 

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels

 

Features:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs in spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

 

Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reticulocytopenia: Hemolysis typically causes reticulocytosis, not reticulocytopenia.

 

Option C. Neutropenia: Hemolysis affects red blood cells, not neutrophils.

 

Option D. Increased conjugated bilirubin: Hemolysis usually increases unconjugated bilirubin due to the breakdown of red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased haptoglobin is a characteristic feature of hemolysis, distinguishing it from other conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following has highest glycemic index: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Explanation:

 

Glucose is often used as the standard reference for measuring the glycemic index, with a value set at 100. It is absorbed rapidly into the bloodstream, causing a quick and significant increase in blood sugar levels. Thus, it has the highest glycemic index among the options listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fructose: Fructose has a lower glycemic index compared to glucose. This is because fructose is metabolized differently, primarily in the liver, and leads to a slower and lower rise in blood glucose levels compared to glucose.

 

Option C. Sucrose: Sucrose, or table sugar, is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose. Its glycemic index is lower than that of pure glucose because the presence of fructose moderates the overall blood sugar response.

 

Option D. Sugar Alcohols: Sugar alcohols, such as xylitol, sorbitol, and mannitol, generally have lower glycemic indices than glucose. They are absorbed more slowly and incompletely in the intestine, leading to a lesser impact on blood sugar levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycemic index (GI)- This is the increase in blood glucose after the test dose of a carbohydrate compared with that of an equivalent amount of glucose. GI is a value assigned to foods based on how slowly or how quickly those foods cause an increase in blood glucose levels.

 

  • GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends.
  • The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient.
  • Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient).
  • HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).

 

 

  • GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1
  • GI of Fructose = 25 %
  • GI of Sucrose = 65 %

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, ovarian drilling is beneficial? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Management of PCOS typically starts lifestyle modification.  Medical management with metformin (for insulin resistance) and then depending on the symptoms that a patient presents with such as irregular menses (OC pills, Progesterone), hirsuitism (cyproterone acetate, Spironolactone) or infertility (Oral Ovulogens such as letrozole, clomiphene) may be considered.

 

Ovarian drilling is NOT a first-line treatment and may be considered in resistant cases.

 

LAPAROSCOPIC OVARIAN DRILLING

 

  • Small holes are made in follicles to resume ovulation in women who are not responding to drugs.
  • Advantage: induce the resumption of ovulation in more than 50% females
  • Disadvantages: invasive procedure, can cause adhesion.
  • 4 drills should be done in each ovary. Depth of 4mm for 4 seconds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian tumour: Treatment would generally involve laparotomy or laparoscopy  for surgical excision depending on various factors such as whether benign or malignant, size of tumour , staging etc

 

Option C. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome:  It occurs as a complication of ovarian stimulation used in ART procedures characterized by enlarged ovaries and third space fluid loss due to increased capillary permeability progressing to ascites, pleural effusion. It is managed conservatively.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: It is characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrium in locations other than the endometrial lining. Treatment may be conservative medical management or surgical excision of the endometriotic lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology page471

questions.text: All of the following are true about Chronic starvation except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperthermia

 

In chronic starvation, the body undergoes various changes due to prolonged lack of nutrients. Hyperthermia (increased body temperature) is not associated with chronic starvation; instead, hypothermia (decreased body temperature) is more likely due to the body's reduced metabolic rate and insulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exhaustion: Commonly seen due to lack of energy intake.

 

Option C. Heart Atrophy: Occurs as the body breaks down muscle tissue, including cardiac muscle, for energy.

 

Option D. Hypotension: Common due to reduced blood volume and overall weakened condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is presenting with short stature, the height of the child to parent’s height and the chronological age of the child corresponds to bone age, what is the likely condition the child is associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial short stature


The clinical scenario described here suggests familial short stature. In cases of familial short stature, the child's height is shorter than average but consistent with the heights of the parents. The key finding is that the bone age corresponds to the chronological age, which means that the child's growth is progressing at a normal rate for their bone maturity.

 

  • Bone age = Chronological age: This is typically seen in familial short stature, where the child's growth is consistent with their genetic potential. There are no delays in bone development, and the child will likely continue to grow at a rate proportional to their bone age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constitutional delay: In constitutional delay, the bone age is usually less than the chronological age, indicating delayed growth. Children with this condition often experience a late growth spurt and may eventually reach a normal adult height.

 

Option C. GH deficiency: Growth hormone (GH) deficiency is associated with short stature, but in these cases, the bone age is typically less than the chronological age, and growth is significantly impaired due to insufficient GH.

 

Option D. Normal: A normal child would have a height and bone age consistent with their chronological age and would not present with short stature relative to their parents' heights.

 

Educational Objective:


In familial short stature, the bone age corresponds to the chronological age, and the child's short stature is consistent with their genetic potential.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision will be the management of the patient.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block
  • Pink/purple mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

Investigation:

 

  1. CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  2. MRI is complementary to CT scan
  3. Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): Not suitable for JNA: Due to the tumor's high vascularity, FNAC could result in significant bleeding and is not typically used for diagnosis or treatment in cases suspected of being JNA.

 

Option B. Biopsy: Risk of severe bleeding: Similar to FNAC, a direct biopsy of JNA is contraindicated due to the risk of triggering severe hemorrhage from the tumor’s vascular structure.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Not a primary treatment: While radiotherapy can be considered in certain cases where surgical excision is incomplete or not feasible, it is not the primary treatment method for JNA. The primary approach is surgical removal, given the effectiveness of surgery in achieving control of the tumor and minimizing long-term complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

choices.text: Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea
Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match out of the following: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

 

  • The Battle sign is indicative of a base of skull fracture and not a result of penetrating trauma to the eye.

 

Battle sign refers to bruising that appears over the mastoid bone (located just behind the ear). It is a classic sign of a base of skull fracture, particularly in the posterior cranial fossa. Penetrating trauma to the eye does not produce a Battle sign. Therefore, this statement is incorrect, making it the right answer to the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH - ipsilateral pupil dilatation: EDH stands for Extradural Hemorrhage, which occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the skull. This can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure, which may compress the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) on the same side of the injury, leading to ipsilateral (same side) pupil dilation. This statement is correct.

 

Option B. Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea: CSF Otorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ear. This can occur when there's a fracture in the base of the skull, which damages the barrier between the subarachnoid space (where CSF is present) and the inner ear, leading to CSF leakage. This statement is correct.

 

Option D. Midbrain injury – gaze paresis: The midbrain, part of the brainstem, is involved in many functions, including the control of eye movements. Damage or injury to the midbrain can affect the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement, leading to gaze paresis, which is an inability or restriction in moving the eyes in certain directions. This statement is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Battle sign is a classic indicator of a base of skull fracture and not associated with penetrating trauma to the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions Hamman’s sign can be appreciated?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman’s sign can be elicited in Pneumomediastinum.

 

Hamman's sign refers to the presence of a crunching or crackling sound that coincides with each heartbeat.

 

Pneumomediastinum occurs due to entry of gas/air into mediastinum.

 

Causes: Boerhaave Syndrome, Trauma to chest, Esophageal rupture, complication of medical procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman's sign, a crunching or crackling sound with each heartbeat, is associated with pneumomediastinum caused by the entry of air into the mediastinum.

questions.text: Identify the airway which can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60. (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venturi Mask

 

Venturi mask can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60.

 

A Venturi mask is an oxygen delivery device that provides a fixed concentration of oxygen to patients by mixing oxygen with room air based on the Venturi effect. It is commonly used for patients requiring controlled oxygen therapy, such as those with COPD.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venturi mask can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60.

choices.text: USG is nearly 100% sensitive to detect IHPS
It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone
Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.text: In Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) which of these would not be seen? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone

 

Among the given options, the statement "C. It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone" is the one that would not be seen in a case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

 

Which makes it the right answer to the question asking which wouldn't be seen in IHPS. IHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles. This hypertrophy leads to an obstruction at the gastric outlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It presents with non-bilious vomiting: This statement is correct. IHPS typically presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. This is because the pyloric stenosis obstructs the gastric outlet, but it is located before the bile duct entry into the duodenum. Therefore, vomitus will not contain bile.

 

Option B. USG is nearly 100% sensitive to detect IHPS: While ultrasonography (USG) is a highly sensitive and commonly used modality for the diagnosis of IHPS, stating that it is nearly "100% sensitive" may be an overstatement. However, for the purpose of the question, it is understood that USG is the preferred and very reliable method of diagnosis.

 

Option D. Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis: This statement is correct. Prolonged vomiting due to IHPS leads to the loss of gastric acid. This results in a metabolic alkalosis. The kidneys compensate for this by excreting more potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia. Hence, the condition termed "hypokalemic alkalosis" is a common metabolic disturbance in IHPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) involves hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction and presenting with non-bilious vomiting. It is commonly diagnosed via highly sensitive ultrasonography, and the associated metabolic disturbance is hypokalemic alkalosis.

choices.text: Stop tobacco and don’t worry about the patch
Chemical cauterization with trichloroacetic acetic acid

questions.text: A chronic tobacco chewer presents with left cheek swelling. On examination a white membrane is seen over the gingiva buccal fold, which doesn’t get rubbed off. What will be your next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical excision and biopsy

 

The patient is likely suffering from leukoplakia in the buccal mucosa. In such cases, a biopsy is crucial to rule out malignancy. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, so direct excision and biopsy are the most appropriate first steps to determine the nature of the lesion and guide further management.

 

Surgical Excision and Biopsy:

 

  • This is the preferred step when dealing with potential premalignant or malignant lesions like leukoplakia. It helps to both treat the lesion (by removing it) and diagnose its exact nature (via the biopsy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop Tobacco and Don’t Worry About the Patch: While quitting tobacco is always beneficial, merely stopping without addressing the lesion can be risky. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, and leaving it untreated without proper diagnosis could lead to missed early cancer detection.

 

Option C. Chemical Cauterization with Trichloroacetic Acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is an agent used for chemical cauterization. It has been used for benign lesions, warts, and certain other conditions, but it’s not the primary method of treatment for suspicious lesions like leukoplakia. Proper histopathological diagnosis is essential before considering treatment options.

 

Option D. MVAC Chemotherapy: MVAC is a chemotherapy regimen that includes Methotrexate, Vinblastine, Doxorubicin (Adriamycin), and Cisplatin. This regimen is typically used for treating advanced bladder cancer. It’s not a frontline treatment for an undiagnosed white patch in the oral cavity like leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia can potentially transform into a malignancy, and thus, any suspicious lesion in the oral cavity should be excised and biopsied for a definitive diagnosis and to rule out cancer.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The ptosis and muscle weakness worsening in the evening and improving in the morning, along with improvement with neostigmine (a cholinesterase inhibitor), strongly support the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington chorea: Characterized by a triad of dementia, psychiatric manifestations, and chorea movements, which are not present in this patient.

 

Option C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): Involves both upper and lower motor neuron signs, such as atrophied limbs, spasticity, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and fasciculations, none of which are described in this case.

 

Option D. External ophthalmoplegia: Refers to weakness of the extraocular muscles without the systemic features seen in myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluctuating muscle weakness with diurnal variation and improvement with cholinesterase inhibitors are hallmark features of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Defect in which of the following essential amino acids metabolism can cause cardiac problems:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methionine

 

Explanation
