Option B. Methionine: Correct Answer. Methionine metabolism defects can lead to homocystinuria, a condition characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood. High levels of homocysteine are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, such as thrombosis, atherosclerosis, and other vascular problems. The cardiac issues in homocystinuria are related to the damaging effects of high homocysteine levels on blood vessels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid involved in the synthesis of serotonin and niacin (Vitamin B3). Defects in tryptophan metabolism are more likely to affect neurological and mental health, rather than directly causing cardiac problems.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid, and while disorders in its metabolism (like Maple Syrup Urine Disease) can have serious health consequences, they are not typically known to directly cause cardiac problems. These conditions more commonly affect the nervous system and metabolic balance.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine metabolism defects lead to phenylketonuria (PKU). While untreated PKU can lead to severe neurological problems due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, it does not primarily cause cardiac problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Defect in the metabolism of methionine can cause homocystinuria which is associated with high risk of cardiovascular disease.
  • Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • Clinical features: failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4326479/

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient who underwent cataract surgery, presented with gradual diminution of vision in the operated eye, suggesting secondary cataract. Which laser is used for the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nd:YAG

 

  • Posterior capsular opacification is also known as “after cataract” or “secondary cataract”.
  • It is a late complication of cataract surgery.
  • There are three morphological types: Elschnig pearls (most common), Sommering ring, and diffuse membranous.
  • Symptoms include a gradual, painless decrease in vision.
  • Treatment involves the use of laser Nd:YAG (1064 nm wavelength). Tough and nonpliable membrane have first to be cut into smaller pieces by Ziegler knife or vitreous scissor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femto second laser: Used in LASIK, cataract surgery, corneal transplant, and keratoconus treatment, but not for treating secondary cataract.

 

Option C. EXCIMER: Used for photorefractive keratectomy (PRK), LASIK, phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK), and corneal cross-linking, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Option D. Argon laser: Used in retinal photocoagulation, trabeculoplasty, and iridotomy, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various lasers and their uses in ophthalmological procedures: -

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to a clinic in a developing region after receiving the MMR vaccination as part of a mass immunization program. Supplemental vitamin A is given alongside the vaccination. What is the appropriate dose of vitamin A to be given immediately after the MMR vaccination and then on the following day? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1,00,000 IU

 

Vitamin A is given along with MMR vaccine at 9 months of age at a dose of 1 lakh IU.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age:

 

< 6 Month – 50,000 IU orally

6-12 Months – 1,00,000 IU orally

Above 12 Months – 2,00,000 IU orally

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children aged 6-12 months, the appropriate dose of vitamin A supplementation given alongside the MMR vaccine is 1,00,000 IU.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a breast condition as demonstrated in the image below. This condition is due to invasion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dermal lymphatics

 

The image demonstrates a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the breast, which occurs due to the blockade of superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion. This blockage causes edema in the breast, making the sweat glands and hair follicles more prominent and resulting in the typical orange peel appearance. Additionally, infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper can result in dimpling of the skin.

 

  • Dermal lymphatics: Blockade by tumor invasion leads to edema, causing the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep lymphatics: Involvement would likely lead to different clinical manifestations, not specifically the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Superficial veins: Blockage would more likely result in visible vein distention or other vascular issues rather than the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep veins: Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deep lymphatics: Incorrect. While the deep lymphatics can be involved in breast cancer spread, they are not specifically responsible for the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option C. Superficial veins: Incorrect. Blockage or involvement of superficial veins would result in different symptoms, such as vein distention, and is not typically associated with the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option D. Deep veins: Incorrect. Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement of deep veins would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast is due to blockage of the superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion, leading to edema and the characteristic skin changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of intestinal inflammation? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fecal lactoferrin

 

Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation. It is commonly used as a marker for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and is useful in differentiating IBD from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which does not typically involve inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Procalcitonin: This is an acute-phase reactant produced primarily in the liver and used as a marker for bacterial infections and sepsis, not specifically for intestinal inflammation.

 

Option C. Tissue Transglutaminase: This test is used in the screening for celiac disease, which is an autoimmune disorder affecting the small intestine but not a direct marker of inflammation.

 

Option D. Albumin: Albumin is a protein produced by the liver and is a marker for liver function and nutritional status but not specific for intestinal inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation and is used to diagnose and monitor inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of painless lump in left knee. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighboring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc.
  • The physical finding usually is a palpable mass.
  • Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma is a benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand. They are the chondromas that usually arise in the medullary canal. They are treated with extended curettage.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms that are usually painless.
  • The pain can be due to bursitis (most common).
  • The physical finding is usually a palpable mass.

questions.text: While doing endoscopy a constriction is noted at the level of 25 cm from incisors. Identify the probable cause of the constriction? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, constrictions of the esophagus can be identified at specific distances from the upper incisors. These constrictions are due to anatomical structures that come in close proximity to or cross the esophagus. At the level of 25 cm from the incisors, the probable cause of constriction is the arch of the aorta.

 

Anatomical Constrictions of the Esophagus:

 

  1. Junction with Cricopharynx (15 cm from incisors):
    • The first constriction occurs where the esophagus joins the cricopharynx, at approximately 15 cm from the upper incisors.
  2. Crossed by Arch of Aorta and Left Bronchus (25 cm from incisors):
    • The second constriction is due to the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus crossing the esophagus. This occurs at about 25 cm from the upper incisors.
  3. Diaphragmatic Hiatus (40 cm from incisors):
    • The third constriction occurs where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm, at around 40 cm from the upper incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Upper Bronchus: The left principal (main) bronchus, not the left upper bronchus, can contribute to the constriction at 25 cm from the incisors.

 

Option C. Right Upper Bronchus: The right upper bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Option D. Right Lower Bronchus: The right lower bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constriction of the esophagus observed at 25 cm from the upper incisors during an endoscopy is most commonly due to the crossing of the esophagus by the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus.

questions.text: Serum osmolality is most affected by which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Na+

 

Among the following options, Serum osmolality is most affected by Na+.

 

Na+ and Cl­- are the two most osmotically active particles, hence they they contribute maximum to the osmolarity.

 

Osmolality is solute per thousand grams of solvent. Serum osmolality can be calculated by:

 

Serum osmolality = 2 Na+ + Glucose/18 + BUN/2.8

questions.text: Element iron exists in 2 states, ferrous and ferric. Which among the following possess ferric form?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methemoglobin

 

Hemoglobin consists of heme complex and a tetramer of globin chain, with a single Ferrous (Fe2+) atom.

 

Methemoglobin on the other hand consists of Ferric (Fe3+) atom, giving it property of high affinity for oxygen.

questions.text: A normal JVP and a patient’s JVP graph is shown below. Which of the following conditions patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid Regurgitation

 

Following changes are seen in JVP waveform in the given image

 

Increased V wave: The V wave represents the venous pressure generated by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve. In TR, the regurgitant flow of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium causes an increase in the V wave amplitude, indicating a higher pressure in the right atrium.

 

Abrupt occurrence of X descent even before C wave: The X descent represents the downward movement of the jugular vein during Mid diastole, when the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle. In TR, the X descent may become more prominent due to the rapid emptying of blood from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

JVP shows a dominant ‘v’ wave which is Most commonly seen in Tricuspid Regurgitation

choices.text: Kwashiorkor due to less calorie intake
Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake
Marasmus due to less calorie intake
Marasmus due to less protein intake

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

The given image is suggestive of kwashiorkor, as it shows a bulging abdomen and pedal edema along with thin limbs and prominent ribs. Kwashiorkor occurs as a result of less protein intake, whereas marasmus occurs due to less calorie intake.

 

Kwashiorkor triad - Growth retardation, Mental changes, Edema.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with fever, cough, runny nose, red eyes and rash as shown in the following image. What can be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Measles

 

 

 

About other options:

 

A) Mumps – Caused by RNA virus. Patient presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, Ear lobe pushed upwards & outwards, Orchitis, Conjunctivitis.

 

 

B) Chickenpox, caused by VZV varicella zoster virus (DNA virus), presents with Centripetal rash. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles.

 

 

D) Erythema infectiosum, aka 5th disease, caused by Parvovirus B19, characterised by Slapped cheek appearance.

choices.text: Hepatitis C in mother
Galactosemia in infant
Tuberculosis in mother

questions.text: In all of the following conditions, a mother can breastfeed her child except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Galactosemia in infant

 

Absolute C/I for breastfeeding are:

  • Baby: Galactosemia & lactose intolerance.
  • Mother: going through chemo/Radiotherapy.

 

About other options:

 

Option A) HIV +ve mother – Risk of problems caused by not breastfeeding overweighs the risk of HIV transmission.

 

Option B) Hepatitis C in mother – Not a C/I

 

Option D) Tuberculosis in mother – Breastfeeding can be done after 2 weeks of therapy.

choices.text: Lymphoid System Development

questions.text: In a growing child, gonadal growth corresponds to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Skeletal Growth

 

Gonadal growth is dormant during childhood and becomes conspicuous during pubescence.

 

The degree of skeletal maturation closely correlates with the degree of sexual maturation. A child who has advanced sexual maturity will also have earlier skeletal maturation.

questions.text: A child is brought to Emergency department with a history of consuming iron tablets of her mother. He is complaining of abdominal pain and nausea. What can be the antidote for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deferoxamine

  • Deferoxamine is an antidote for Acute iron poisoning.
  • Deferiprone can be used an antidote in Chronic iron poisoning.
  • The introduction of chelating agents is capable of removing excess iron from the body.

 

About other options:

 

Option A) EDTA is used in Lead poisoning

 

Option C) BAL is used in Arsenic poisoning, Lead poisoning, Acute mercury poisoning.

 

Option D) Penicillamine is used in Wilson disease.

choices.text: Lithium toxicity exaggerates by thiazides
Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels
Lithium is teratogenic
Lithium toxicity can’t be treated by hemodialysis

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for acute mania and was prescribed Lithium for the same. All are true statements about lithium except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lithium toxicity can’t be treated by hemodialysis

 

Drugs which are less protein bound can be eliminated through hemodialysis. Hemodialysis is often recommended to treat lithium poisoning.

 

About other options:

 

Option A) Thiazide can cause lithium toxicity by increasing tubular reabsorption

 

Option B) Lithium is concentrated by the thyroid and inhibits thyroidal iodine uptake. It also inhibits iodotyrosine coupling, alters thyroglobulin structure, and inhibits thyroid hormone secretion. 

 

Option C) Lithium is teratogenic, causes Ebstein’s Anomaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to OPD with a rash as shown below. He has a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, he has enlarged epitrochlear lymph nodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Syphilis

 

The given clinical vignette and image showing maculopapular rash points to diagnosis of Secondary Syphilis.

 

Secondary syphilis is disseminated form of syphilis with constitutional symptoms, maculopapular rash including palm and soles, condyloma lata, lymphadenopathy, patchy hair loss.

 

Characteristic lymph node enlarged in secondary syphilis -Epitrochlear group of nodes.

 

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by VDRL/RPR (Non-specific), FTA-ABS (specific).

 

 

 

About other options:

 

Option A) Steven Johnson syndrome is a severe mucocutaneous reaction. Presents as blisters and epithelial sloughing.

 

Option C) Psoriasis presents with papulosquamous rash, encircled by a peripheral zone called Woronoff ring.

 

Option D) Leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches and nerve thickening.
